Review: Love this seat, works well in providing safety and security. You do need to play with it in order to have it secure; I had to roll up a towel to get the angle needed, but that's an issue with the auto manufacturers, not Safety First.  Not a seat I'd be taking in and out of my vehicle regularly but once you have it securely installed, it stays put.

Review:
PLEASE READ-
ZERO STARS!

I bought two. My daughter is rear facing and unaffected by this major issue; However, if forward facing, your child’s head will dangerously hang forward while asleep. The position cuts off my sons breathing passageway. I have tried everything to fix this issue with no avail. Save your money and your kids neck. Absolute worst car seat ever.
Attribute_Related_Content: Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing

Review: My son is 3 and in the 90th percentile for height and weight and he fits wonderfully in the seat. We have it set up as a normal car seat for now, though I did take out the removable extra layer of padding. I didn't even realize that there are little cubby holes in the arm rests for whatever itty bitty toys he brings in the car for entertainment.  And he definitely likes the cup holder.  We haven't tested it on a long car trip yet, so I'm not sure how well he naps in it.  Over all, pretty happy with the Graco Nautilus (which came recommended by 3 fellow moms)
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: normal car seat
Material: removable extra layer of padding

Review: After much research, I decided to get this seat for my 3 year old.  He loves it as do I.  It was easy to set up and install and he is very comfortable in it.  He's already fallen asleep in it a few times and hasn't had any issues with his head falling forward.  It's a fairly big seat, but surprisingly takes up less space than his old convertible carseat.  There is more room to maneuver around him if necessary.  The cup holder is nice as are the interior compartments for storing his superhero guys.  I'm extremely happy with this purchase.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 3 year old

Review:
The seat is described to be usable either with the harness system or as a booster seat (without harness). For the booster usage, you have to remove the harness. This turns out to be nearly impossible: one has to reach a “splitter plate” inside the seat construction, which cannot be seen, but only be reached by one hand, and one has to wiggle two straps out of this metal plate with one hand in the blind.
Even if one would succeed in this nearly impossible task, obviously one will never be able to put the harness harness back in. So the claim of dual use as harness or booster seat is false; or if the harness is removed with great difficulty, it is for good.
For use only with harness it seems OK (seems safe and comfortable), but I wonder who engineered the dual use feature.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Harness Type: harness system, booster seat (without harness)

Special Features: Removable Tray, Safety Harness, Folds for Easy Transport and Storage
Review: Giving 4 starts only because the trey is a little annoying to get on and off. Other than that, I love it and so does my 15 month old!! Super easy to take with us and easy to wipe down too. But the padding on the seat looked like foam kind of and like it would break down over time and also was like 5 pieces in all. That's way too much too clean. This is simple and does the job

Review: My first concern in choosing a convertible car seat was safety.  I spent numerous hours researching safety issues & other consumer reviews.  The final decision was the Graco Nautilus 3-1 Car Seat in Matrix.  This certainly was an excellent choice.  It is a much heavier weight than anticipated, easier to buckle the belts, nicely tailored, & has the desired saftey features for a growing child.  I bought two of these for my young grandsons, as I do not like the standard booster seats.  They (booster seats) are easy for a young child to unlatch the seat belt & allow too much movement. I definitely recommend this car seat.

The only reason I wouldn't give this a 5 is that the tray is a bit difficult to get on the chair and takes a bit of getting used to. The lever to adjust the seat height is also not the easiest to use when you have the baby in one hand and only one free hand. But once you find the sweet spot, it works out pretty well! I would definitely recommend this chair to all my friends.

Review:
**Update** After 2 years of ownership and daily use, the strap to tighten the harness is frayed and hard to use. Graco says it cannot be replaced, and they won’t replace the seat. Now we’re stuck with it or face spending $$$ to replace it ourselves.**

We own two of these and we find it hard to tighten the harness on both, still, after months of use. We have just gotten used to struggling with it a little every time. When we first got the seats, I had a lot of trouble unbuckling the chest buckle, but either I have learned how to do it or the buckle has relaxed a little, because I only struggled with that for about a week. Recently we had to wash the cover on one of our seats, and we were able to put it back together with fairly little difficulty. The size of this seat makes it hard for tall people to ride in the passenger seat in front of it in one of our cars (2009 Subaru Forester), but it's not too bad. Hopefully our daughter can forward face before we need to extend the head rest further. We started using this seat when our daughter was about 11 months old and had outgrown her bucket seat by height. She had no problem with the transition to this seat. She seems comfortable on trips up to 2 hours (we haven't gone further). Now that it's summer I can say that it seems like the purple color fabric doesn't heat up very much.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: strap to tighten the harness is frayed and hard to use; hard to tighten the harness; had a lot of trouble unbuckling the chest buckle
Material: purple color fabric doesn't heat up very much; wash the cover

Review: Very easy to use and install in the car. We installed the base using the Latch system and its very very stable.  Baby loves the car seat and it clicks in so easily. The newborn insert is perfect and means we didnt need any other cushions or rolled up towels to support the baby in the car seat.

Review: Let me start off by saying, I'm a mom of 16 month old twins and I love these car seats!  I have two of them and for the price, they can't be beat!  My family is on a very tight budget and when it was time to upgrade from the infant carriers to a forward-facing seat, I had some very specific requirements in mind: price, comfort, ability to grow with child, and safety ratings.  Now obviously there are some great car seats on the market, such as Britax, but these seats also cost twice as much ($200-$300), and I could not afford to spend $400 on car seats.  After much research, including going to a local baby store and comparing the padding, weight, etc., these seemed like the best choice.  Not only are they very reasonable in price, but compared to some of the other brands in the same price range (Safety 1st), this was WAY better!  Not only is the cushioning much thicker, but the seat seems roomy and has plenty of room to grow with my boys.  An added bonus is that as long as we don't get into an accident, I can potentially use these seats until the boys are completely out of booster seats (10 years old).  The safety ratings on these seats are pretty good too from places like Consumer Report.  One complaint I've seen in other reviews is that these seats are not at a great angle for your child to sleep, however, I can report that my twins sleep in them all the time and their heads just seem to fall to the side and not at any awkward angles.  Now that I'm going back to work, I will be investing in two more of these seats for our second car, to get the boys to and from daycare.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: forward-facing
Weight Range of Child: until the boys are completely out of booster seats (10 years old)
Material: cushioning much thicker

Review: We are big fans of Britax ever since my first child was born. Britax has never failed us and most of the product we own from Britax are very well-made and durable. I want to like Parkway, however, if your child is on the heavier side then this might not be a good fit. The seat area is very narrow, unfortunately, my kids have big bottoms so they didn't feel comfortable sitting on this booster seat.

Review: We purchased this seat for our son who is now 6 and 45lbs. We were in a minor car accident and my son was in a booster that only used a seatbelt. He complained of bruising on his chest from the seatbelt after the accident and I decided that his next carseat would have a 5 point harness. It is very comfortable and looks great. Most importantly it is safe and puts my mind at ease. I much prefer my son in a 5 point harness rather than a booster that just uses a seatbelt.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: 45lbs
Installation Type: Seat Belt
Harness Type: 5 point harness

Review: I had to purchase another booster seat as my truck was hit and sadly totaled, but was told what played an important roll to my son's car seat staying put and saving his life and not being thrown out the door as his door was t-boned and opened was the LATCH system. And this seat has it. I could have been a spokes person and when I do see my friends who has those flimsy car seats, say they are not safe, and accidents will happen and sadly those seats will not stay put, and explain the latch system and that it hooks directly to the metal bars under the back seat. I had the Graco 3 in 1 from when he was born, and I had it so tight I use to say if I ever flipped my truck, I would know my son was not going anywhere, and sadly we did not flip all the way over, but when the officers and the ambulance stated that car seat kept him from being thrown about, I looked everywhere for just a booster with the Latch system.
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: LATCH system, hooks directly to the metal bars under the back seat

Its has been easy for my husband to switch it over from car to car also.  We would definitely recommend this to our friends and family!

Review: We purchased this car seat for my infant son who had outgrown his baby car seat. We purchased it based on Consumer Reports safety ratings.  We are pleased about that.  The seat clips into our car's latch system just fine.  The problem is Britax straps are not easy to adjust.  Also there is a lot of slack for the straps included for lap belt purposes. (Not removable.). This does clank and rattle in the car.  Had to use duct tape to secure on the back of the seat.

Installation Type: latch system

Review: I originally bought this car seat as an extra for my mom's car because of the affordable price and reviews. I tried to keep my 4 year old in a 5 point harness as long as possible but finally he kept telling me his buckle was "hurting his penis". I knew at that time, it was time to upgrade! This booster looks great, feels super sturdy and is easy to assemble. The pieces basically just snap together. Not long after I bought this seat my son was in the back seat of my mom's mustang and was rear ended. The car was totaled, but luckily everyone was ok! I love this booster seat and I'd love to credit my son's safety to it. A key part of this I believe is the seat belt guides that properly put the seatbelt across the shoulder position. The seat wipes down easy and the cupholders are a plus. Today, I actually bought a second one of these boosters in red from Toys 'R' Us for $39.99 for our other vehicle. We also use a Graco Turbo Booster which was priced about $49.99 at Toys 'R' Us, but yet I still find myself buying a second Evenflo. As a matter of fact I have bought a total of 5 Evenflo carseats and I always tend to find myself favoring those. I originally started out with a Tribute when my son was little. In our primary vehicle we had a Britax Marathon because it had great safety reviews and I thought because it was more expensive, it must be better. That was the 5 point harness seat that was used from age 2 until 4. After only 2 years of use it seemed like it was falling apart. The interior styrofoam seemed to detach itself from the plastic and the cloth seat was forever coming undone. It also was so large, bulky and heavy it was a pain to take out and move if needed be. My younger son also had a newer Britax Boulevard which practically fell apart as well. We did take off the cloth cover to wash a few times, but with putting it back on a piece of the styrofoam interior ripped off and eventually the whole styrofoam liner started detaching itself again. I ended up throwing out the Boulevard, then giving my younger child the Marathon, and we finally got rid of that and he is in a Evenflo Maestro. I now have 2 Evenflo Maestro's! My point is do not think you are getting a lesser quality product because it is also one of the most affordable.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster
Weight Range of Child: 4 year old
Installation Type: seat belt guides
Harness Type: 5 point harness

Review:
The carseat looks great - haven't put it into action yet, BUT beware if one of the reasons you are buying this is because of the beautiful blue looking color. It is NOT bluish at all. If you magnify the photo in the listing you can see how it 'might' be different shades of grey - But it is in NO WAY bluish.
I was positive that I was sent the wrong seat, but the box clearly says Gotham. It must have been a lighting issue. I am grieving the blue one I wanted. :(

My only complaint is that I wish it wheeled like a luggage and had those wheels that could go forward/backward or left/right. The wheels are straight so you can only either push or pull forward.

Review:
Pluses
------
- feels very safe; lots of protection and very snug
- unlike other users, we find this very easy to move from car to car. We were house hunting for 4 months and removed our car seat 2-3 times a week to move into the realtor's car and were able to do it easily. You have to loosen the 2 straps linked to the locking mechanism and then tighten after installing to make it a breeze.
- we have used it in the rear facing and front facing modes and our kid finds it comfortable

Minuses
-------
- very heavy; we traveled with it and it is heavy to lug around the airport
- CANNOT BELIEVE that the cover is not MACHINE WASHABLE
- CANNOT BELIEVE that cover cannot be put in a DRYER
What do you do, Britax, when your kid spits up or throws up? Hand wash and then drip dry and not drive for that time? For this price Britax should have given us a spare cover!!!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Front Facing
Installation Type: loosen the 2 straps linked to the locking mechanism, tighten after installing
Material: cover is not machine washable, cover cannot be put in a dryer

Review:
I bought this car seat for my grandson whom is under a year old. I love it!! It buckles very easily which makes it so nice getting him in and out of my car. Rear facing I have to put it in the middle of the car because it does not fit behind my seat. However, if you are a short person and no one else drives your car it's perfect. It fits quite nicely in the middle (I have a Honda Pilot). A lot of reviews I read said it was easy to install. Well, not so much for me. Maybe it's just me and being out of the swing for 14 years I'm a bit rusty and installation has changed since then. You do have to put towels under the front of it for stability when facing the rear. No big deal. It is a very comfortable seat, the baby loves it and never complains when I put him in it. He used to complain when I put him in his infant seat.

I would highly recommend this seat to anyone. Again the buckle is so easy and I know people with expensive car seats that have a really tough time with the buckle. The price is great!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear facing
Installation Type: easy to install

Review: We recently purchased the PP Convertible in Paloma and couldn't be more pleased. I HATED the PP infant car seat (seating angle, canopy, base, etc) and went with the Britax Chaperone (LOVED it) so I was a tad hesitant about purchasing the PP convertible despite the stellar reviews. Our 10 month old is almost too long for the Chaperone so we decided to upgrade him to a "big kid seat". Luckily we were able to compare the Britax seats the PP non-leatherette seat (Crystal Beige, they didn't have the leatherette in store) at a local store and really loved all the features especially the recline angles and general comfort of the seat, but the thought of cleaning the jersey fabric with our little mess-ball was enough to give me a panic attack. The Paloma fabric is amazing! It's really expensive for a car seat, but spend the extra money for the leatherette fabric. It's definitively worth it and will save your sanity! Just a damp cloth and whatever the little man has caked on it comes right off without any fuss. No removing the fabric (even though you can); literally just wipe it down. Also, I have no problem fitting it in a sedan, CUV and full size SUV. It's smaller than the Chaperone in that sense, but still very roomy for the little guy. It's also the most comfortable seat I have ever seen (obviously haven't tested it myself though) and I have researched them ALL! The little man looks so comfy in it and seems happy to be in his new "big kid seat". I also was pleasantly surprised at how much room rear-facing their still is for long legs... Will definitely help keep him rear-facing until closer to 2 than other seats would. Only con besides the expense is the fact there is no canopy, but that is with all the convertibles so not a big deal. You definitely get what you pay for with this seat: functional, beautiful and easy! Install was a breeze! Totally worth every penny!!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Material: Paloma fabric, leatherette fabric, jersey fabric, easy to clean with a damp cloth
Seat Type: Convertible
Installation Type: Install was a breeze

Review: We are really happy with this Chicco car seat and the Trevi stroller we bought separately to go with it. The car seat is simple to install in any car that we have tried (3 to date), is not too heavy, and has a lot of neat little features. We did a lot of research prior to our purchase, and this was rated very highly in terms of safety, ease-of-use, and overall value. Would highly recommend to any prospective parent!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: simple to install

Review: My 110lb 56in tall ten year old loves this seat. Side wings are the widest we have found. Comfortable & quality padding. The only thing that would make it  better is if the base was a smidge narrower at the back (the park that meets the backrest). We had to slide on a seatbelt guide piece to get the ridged buckle in our car to come away from the seat far enough to snap in the seatbelt. This is SO much better than the Graco Turbobooster as far as positioning the belt is concerned. We were not loving letting her ride without a seat, because the belt wasn't staying low on her lap and it was cutting into her neck. But the Graco was just not tall/wide enough to accommodate her anymore.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: 110lb
Installation Type: Seat Belt

Review: The car seat is big and built solid but lacks features and is very heavy. If you are trying to  take a family outing this thing leave no room for the driver or front passenger.  I tried in my  wife lexus nx200 and my 4 door dodge pickup and it stinks. Waste of money. I will stick with another brand

Review:
The side wing of the foam headrest is fragile and can break off easily. I sent Britax 2 complaints via their website since my product was still under warranty. Although they claim they would respond within 48 hours, they did not honor that commitment. After 10 days of non-response, I posted a public complaint via their website. The complaint was reviewed by Britax and the response I got from them was that they could not publish my complaint publicly. So, after 12 days of waiting for a response, the only response I got was that they wouldn't post my complaint. I still have not received a response on my original complaint. I'm posting the full correspondence for the public's benefit:

Original Post:
Product + Customer Service FAIL!
I bought the Boulevard in preparation to transition my son into a toddler car seat. We were switching to Britax from a competitor brand, which we used as the infant car seat, because of a friend's recommendation. After a few months of use, the side wing of the foam head rest snapped off in the action of putting my son into the seat. I would have expected this piece to be able to withstand the repetitive motion of moving back and forth. As ANY parent would know, putting a child into a car seat is NOT like an adult settling into his favorite armchair: sometimes the angle is awkward, sometimes the child resists, sometimes the child stands. When the side wing snapped, there wasn't any particular struggle and nothing noticeably harsh and it clearly gave out of repetitive (though ROUTINE) use. I contacted Britax about this July 4th. Given that this was a holiday, I didn't expect an answer and gave them 3 days. On the evening of the 7th, I sent another question/complaint through their website. Since I still have not received a response (now July 12th), not even an auto-reply, I thought this warranted a public post so that future potential customers could be aware. On a side note, though no less important for safety conscious parents, in my question to Britax, I also mentioned that the toddler shoulder belts were unevenly tensioned when I tightened them around my son's shoulder. Even though I would pull the strap to tighten the belt, my son's left shoulder strap would still be loose while his right shoulder strap was tight. There was no obvious snag when I checked the back of the car seat. This issue was present from Day 1 of using the Boulevard. I continued using it because I could set the chest buckle higher to minimize the "give" in the looser shoulder strap.

Britax Response:
Our staff has read your review and values your contribution even though it did not meet all our website guidelines. Thanks for sharing, and we hope to publish next time!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Boulevard, toddler car seat
Harness Type: toddler shoulder belts, chest buckle
Material: foam headrest

Review:
Ok, so go read the other critical reviews.

This was very attractive due to the price point. I would describe this as an OK budget option, but if you can, spring for a better quality car seat. This is the thing that will protect your child in the event of a collision, so if you can save up for a better seat, please do.

Our 11-month-old was very unhappy getting fitted in this, he hated the position, and as others have pointed out it will be hard for him to sleep in here comfortably (which is also dangerous if his head is not positioned properly).

As others pointed out, this thing feels flimsy. There are exposed parts in the back that rattle around a lot, regardless of whether there's a kid in it. It's mostly the parts that interface to raise and lower the back, so you might be able to wrap some electrical tape around the metal pieces to dampen the sound, but that seems like a silly solution to a sub-par design.

The LATCH straps. Where to start? Why did they even bother? Chicco has a latch strap with nice plastic-coated attachment points that resemble a seatbelt clipping in. This thing just has metal hooks on the end with a flimsy little retainer piece. Then you have to awkwardly try to pull it like a seatbelt to get it tight enough. All of my body weight and all of my strength trying to tighten the strap was futile, because ultimately you're pulling a strap perpendicular to the direction that you need to tighten it.

I tightened this as much as I could and still had a good 6" of play on the front of the seat -- way more than is safe. It would have been far better to drop the LATCH system entirely and require the much more complicated (read: likely to be done incorrectly) seat belt installation.

Back in the box this went. I will give credit where it's due though - the packaging was great. Literally just a car seat in a box. No foam, no plastic wrap, no waste.
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: LATCH straps, metal hooks, flimsy little retainer piece, pulling a strap perpendicular to the direction that you need to tighten it, had a good 6" of play on the front of the seat, seat belt installation

Review:
This carseat has some good features, but overall, I hate this thing with every fiber in the fabric of my being. If I had access to ballistics, I'd blow this thing up. But alas, I'm a pretty wimpy soccer mom armed only with a light sabre and a 12 pack of juice boxes, so a lousy review is all I have.

The good: The fabric is nice and cleans up easily. I don't generally let my children eat in the car, but if I did, I don't think the fabric would stain. The seat feels well made, with solid materials and heavy plastics that instill a sense of confidence. The cup holders and the ingenious toy hiding cubby are awesome. That's it. That's all the good there is. I have not had issues with the buckle. It may be because I do not let the children eat the car.

The bad: This thing is heavy. That's not always bad, but it's almost unmanageable. I have Recaro seats that I like a lot. They're heavy, too, but somehow they don't seem as bad. The seat is very hard to install, with old school latch connectors that are nearly impossible to attached to the rear deck hooks in a sedan. It takes me almost 15 minutes to install this seat properly using the latch connectors. I have yet to try installing it with the seat belt - it may take away some of the intense vitriol I feel for this seat.

The ugly: My son is 5 and 37 lbs. He cannot get himself into this seat in my relatively easy access VW Passat. The seat is "bucket" style, with a considerable incline, even after adjustment. Because of the incline, the buckle is always facing the child's posterior. As a result, he's always sitting on it and you have to reach under his hind quarters to reach the buckle. I've read other reviews, looked at the instructions and researched YouTube, but the crotch strap is surprisingly short with an insufficient number of slots. It's ok for a younger child, but as your child gets older it's an awkward exchange to get him in and out of the seat. It's actually an episode to get my son into the seat. He cries, complains, and begs me to loosen the straps. The seat hurts his butt, and as a smaller kid, he finds it difficult to overcome the incline in order to get himself out of the car. Combine that with the never ending winter and mornings consistently in the 20+ below 0F range up here in the tundra, it takes unreasonably long to get a kid comfortably and properly into this seat. I gave up and put him in a belt tensioning booster. This thing wasn't worth it, and after less than a year, I kicked it to the curb.

Yes, I know, they should be in a 5 point until they're 32 because it's just that much safer. Yes. I agree. If you have a 7 or 8 year old that is happily in a 5 point harness, you're clearly a better parent than I who has exceptionally gifted children. For us mortals who need to balance practicality with safety, this seat just doesn't cut it. I replaced it with a Recaro seat that I am very happy with. The 5 year old agrees.

Clearly, this is a very popular seat with a whole host of parents that think this bad boy is the cat's meow. Frankly, it's the worst $150 I've ever spent. I just hate it that much. Do your research, test it out. Maybe it will work for you. If it does, it stores lots of juice boxes, Superhero Action Figures and probably several My Little Ponies in a very safe and attractive package.

Rock on moms and dads! Peace.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: bucket style
Weight Range of Child: 37 lbs
Installation Type: latch connectors, seat belt
Harness Type: 5 point harness, crotch strap
Material: fabric, heavy plastics

Review:
I bought this to use in my car for my 20 month old granddaughter that I keep every Friday. It was not any harder to install than any other car seat I have dealt with but it would not tighten enough to keep it from rocking no matter what I did. I tried the rolled up towel trick but that did not work either. My son even tried to tighten it. He ended up using the tether strap on the back of the carseat and hooking it to the front of the actual seat to keep it secured. This is in addition to using the hooks and the lap belt. I am sure it will be fine once we turn her forward facing. But I am disappointed in the fact that they advertised this one for both rear and forward facing.
But the worst part aside from not fitting tight enough is the button on the 5 point harness is the most difficult button I have ever had to deal with! It takes me 3 or 4 tries and having to use all the force I have to get this button to release. I am concerned that this is a safety issue.
The seat has a nice padded cushion and it looks comfortable. I also like the 2 cup holders. That is great for snacks on the road. It seems easy to clean also. I am so disappointed that it has been so difficult to install and the release button is such a pain.

Review:
It's a little heavier than I would like, but hey, it's car seat - none of them are light as a feather. It also takes up quite a bit more room in the car than I imagined - again, I'm sure this is not an issue limited to this particular seat, but to the entire rear-facing car seat universe. Outside of that, I can't complain too much. It is a bit tricky to get the seatbelt harness to unlatch once the lil one is strapped in. It feels like I have to push way too hard on the button to get it to release, and means that I am putting pressure on her when I do so - even with a hand (or a few fingers rather) between the buckle and my baby. I'm working on technique to help get around that issue.

The ease of snapping it in and out of the base is unbelievable though. So easy. ONce you get the base secured that is. That may take a little bit of trail and error depending on your vehicle and whether or not you plan to use a seat cover to protect your car seat's surface from the bottom of the base (which we did on my wife's car, but not on mine). Still, pretty easy to get that taken care of, just means you need to check it from time to time to make sure it has't compressed the car seat cover enough to make the base a tad bit loose (has never gone from green to red - but has show a red line from time to time on the "tightness indicator").

Installing this in my car, however, was a nightmare. MY fault for driving a Mustang. To all you out there with a car that has little to no back seat room, rest assured the seat will fit - although very very tight - and to be honest, probably not meeting ALL of the manufacturer's suggested space between baby seat and back of front seat requirements if you are trying to have an adult riding shotgun comfortably. But installing the base will be a major pain in the a double-s because you have virtually no room to maneuver yourself on top of the damn thing to make sure it is secured tightly (ie - to make that "tightness indicator" go from red to green). As I said, it can be done, just be patient and do some stretching before you try to get it in there because you're going to have to play contortionist to apply the pressure needed to lock everything in place.

But back to the good stuff. It's also very nice that you can rock the seat when you put it down. So if baby gets a little fussy, you can start to gently, or quickly if you wish, rock her. And you can do so with your hand or your foot. Convenient. But that's, again, probably something most if not all baby seats will do. Anyway, yeah it's a bit pricey, but having seat that 1 - looks great, 2 - fits both of our cars, 3 - snaps into the stroller with no adaptor nonsense necessary, and 4 - has strong safety ratings, I'd say it's worth it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear-facing
Installation Type: base, snaps
Harness Type: seatbelt harness

Review:
I have purchased and used many car seats, this one is by far my favorite for a variety of reasons.
It is very user friendly. The straps do not need to be threaded, which is SO convenient! They move up and down with the head rest. It is slim fit and the cup holder function is very easy to use or take off..
It is comfortable, soft and sturdy feeling very well made. The anchor latches are SO EASY to use with any latch system. All you have to do is push it on and it clicks! The tether for the latch system also has a loop on the end for easy pulling and tightening. I highly recommend purchasing, relieving knowing my baby is safe in this car seat.

Review:
My daughter loves her seat! Just put it in yesterday (she is 4) and she immediately talked about how comfy it is. SO I will say after reading reviews everyone said how hard it was to install-NOT TRUE! If you've installed a carseat it is the exact same and technically in some ways easier than others. I like that the tethers aren't just flopping around and have a place to clip into the seat if not in use.

So don't let other reviews worry you-if you've installed one carseat they are all basically the same :)

Review: Horrible I would not buy this at all. It’s flimsy and poorly made. I don’t care how compact this is it really didn’t work for us on our east coast long drive trip. My friend actually had a immi go car seat which is way more expensive but I would rather get that. Never risk a babies life.

She can unfastened herself. Just a pain because she is in third row of minivan. Now I gave to climb in to buckle her each time.

Review:
Still waiting for my daughter's to come. So far my son loves his. I conducted a car seat test similar to when they were newborns. I had him sit in his car seat for about 30 minutes to see how he reacted while distracted. So far he's so comfortable that he's seemingly unaware or bothered by being strapped in. I'm very pleased with the appearance, how easy it is to use, and of course my son's reaction to the comfort. I'll update once I get them in the car.

That is where I worry most since I drive a "compact" suv.

Review: I gave this a 4 instead of a 5 for only 1 reason. When it is rear facing it is awkward to adjust the straps. It's not impossible, but takes a minute to figure out the best way to pull tight. My older son has the nautilus, and we were extremely disappointed that the store had it labeled as a rear facing when it wasn't. However this one truly is rear facing which is amazing! Its extremely plush and seems very comfortable. We just made a 14 hour trip that we split into 2 days and my 11 month old did great in this seat! Then again we also had mickey mouse playing for him too. It doesn't take up as much room in the car as an infant seat which is a plus because we felt cramped in our suv with the infant seat. I like that you don't have to take the straps out to adjust the height, just moving the head rest up and down works out great. I would highly recommend this seat!

Review:
Just FYI - this listing says the material type for this car seat contains no lead, BPA, Phalate, or latex. I emailed Graco directly to confirm this since the exact model different color (Graco Snugride Classic Connect Infant Car Seat, Maci) did not say it was free of these chemicals. The Amazon listing is incorrect according to Graco. They are not "free" of any of these, rather they meet the federal standards. This was the email Graco sent me below. Just in case this sort of thing was a question to anyone else, figured I'd share.

Graco's Email:

Thank you for contacting Graco Consumer Care, our goal is to provide our consumers with the highest quality and service.

Ensuring the safety and well-being of all children using our Graco branded products is our top priority. This is the reason that we manufacture and market products that are fully compliant with all applicable mandatory safety and regulatory standards.

As parents ourselves we do everything we can do to provide the safest and most innovative products possible. While as a juvenile products manufacturer we are subject to strict regulations including a requirement for products to be flame retardant, Graco continually monitors the treatments we use to ensure that they are best suited for the needs of users.

Graco can confirm that at their time of manufacture, our finished products comply with the applicable chemical substance bans. The choice of chemical compound is made after carefully considering many factors including current scientific findings and effectiveness for each specific fabric involved.

As a result there is no “one size fits all” flame retardant compound that can be used and Graco uses various proprietary compounds in the appropriate circumstances. We are committed to continued monitoring of the chemical usage on our products to ensure compliance with the most up to date regulations and ensure the products do not contain substances that are or become known to be hazardous to the children and parents who place their trust in our products.

We can confirm our current production does not use Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) as a flame retardant.

Latex - We do not specifically monitor products to make a Latex free claim. While we don’t add natural latex rubber to the products, Graco does use other forms of natural and synthetic rubbers in select products, which may be derived from natural latex/latice sources.

Phthalate - Meets limits established by federal or state law, or industry standard, for regulated substances.

Lead - Meets limits established by federal or state law, or industry standard, for regulated substances.

BPA - Graco has monitored BPA contamination in suspect plastics (hard, clear, composite, recycled). These types of plastics are rarely used in our products.
Attribute_Related_Content: Material: The listing says the material contains no lead, BPA, phthalate, or latex, but Graco states they are not free of these chemicals; they meet federal standards. Graco confirms products comply with applicable chemical substance bans, use various proprietary flame retardant compounds, and current production does not use TBBPA as a flame retardant. They do not specifically monitor for latex-free claims and do not add natural latex rubber, but may use other rubbers derived from latex sources. Phthalate, lead, and BPA meet established limits.

Review:
It looks a little cheap but it is far easier for my 5 year old to use than our other booster. I bought a Chicco highback booster and while it is comfortable, the belt routing is awful for the chicco.
This evenflo booster is a lot easier, but still feels safe. Would buy again. Wish there was more seat padding.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster
Weight Range of Child: 5 year old
Installation Type: belt routing

Review: I purchased this car seat because I frequently babysit my granddaughter. She is tall for her age, so she still needs to be rear facing and this car seat provides nice leg room for her. It is easy to install which I appreciate, and very safe with its padding and restraints. Nice cup holders for sippy cups and snacks. I and my granddaughter like this car seat very much!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear facing
Weight Range of Child: tall for her age
Installation Type: easy to install

Review:
Prior to this car seat I had an infant car seat - Graco snugride 30. My son NEVER liked riding in the car. A big problem as we do a 3 hour drive every Friday and Sunday night. It was very painful. We tried everything - even breast feeding him IN the car seat while driving down the highway - We were starting to think we had to stay home all the time. The closest we ever came to a nice ride was if he was in the front seat with the airbag off - not ideal.

A more experienced mom suggested I look into a convertible seat. Another experienced parent suggested Britax. I took my son to Baby r Us and sat him in every single car seat. I tried to pay attention to angle and cushion and how he responded. He seemed happy in this one. My 5 month old is quick to let you know when he is not comfortable.

He also liked another popular brand so we had to choose. This one just looked nicer. It seemed more low key then the sticker filled second choice

This car seat was easy to install, angled nicely for a baby with reflux and for the first time we drove home Sunday night with no baby screaming, no stops on the highway to cuddle and calm him down. He still fusses a bit in the car but once he gets comfortable he is happy and acts like a normal baby is suppose to and falls asleep!

We have only had this car seat for a weekend but already I think it is worth every penny we paid for it!

I did purchase a mirror and a sun shade - I think that is needed when you lose the ability to pull the cover on the infant seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: convertible seat
Installation Type: easy to install

Review: I liked this car seat at first.... But OMG THE SMELL 🤮. It smells like propane or something. It started smelling randomly. Makes your entire car smell absolutely terrible! I washed it twice according to the guidelines that come with this car seat. After washing it the 2nd time, the smell is still there like I have never washed it. It also tore by the arms after a was. Very disappointed in this car seat. Will not recommend to anyone. Going through the reviews of this one, I noticed I am not the only one with the smell problem.
Attribute_Related_Content: Material

Review:
I love the seat but...when I first got this I initially wanted to return it because it was $20 more than I had seen in a store but when I considered the headache to return it and buy a new one I realized I'd be spending more than $20. My toddler is now 21 months and I love the features--- lots of padding, easily removable, very easy to pop off the fabric to wash and all that good stuff.

But, the base of the seat it not as wide as the actual seat making it easy to topple over when it's in the reclined position, my son loves to sleep in it but after an hour he usually comes out dripping wet in his back, the chest clasps slips up and down easily so he has managed to slip in and out of the seat restraints which is a major concern for me especially since he does it during traffic.

It's not plane practical if you are travelling alone cause the seat weigh 18 pounds without a baby. It's very bulky to fit in a seat both lenght wise and width wise.

Ohhhh and another major thing --forget the advertising for newborn to toddler. I would not put my newborn in this, I suggest you buy a 5-22 or 5-30 pound seat for your newborn because my son is still in the smallest setting and he was 17 months when he got it at about 27 pounds and there was still space. I'm not confident this seat will be safe for a baby that can't balance it's own head.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Weight Range of Child: newborn to toddler, 5-22 or 5-30 pound seat, 27 pounds
Installation Type: 
Harness Type: chest clasps
Material: fabric

Review: This car seat is great but if you care at all about getting what you pay for color wise, as some colors are much more than others, be prepared that the colors are way off. This one looks black and blue in the picture but it's a black and very flat gray.

Review:
Great quality and easy install BUT its not really compact? I bought it for our Jetta because our $90 from sams club leaves the passenger seat pushed up pretty far (rear facing position). The base is skinnier but the top is even wider than normal seat. In my ridgeline this seat wont fit in the back middle seat between the front seats. The top is just to wide.

The seat is nice but is it worth $100 more than our other two... no... definitely not.

Seat Type: rear facing

Review: I have had the car seat for a month and I am rating it a 4 overall.  I like everything about it with the exception of two things:  the lap straps sometimes get twisted and turned around at the buckle area as my son gets in and out.  It can be difficult to get it turned back going the correct way.  Secondly, the recline feature of the seat doesn't recline much at all and in my opinion isn't a feature worth marketing.  Therefore, when my son falls asleep he is in a fairly upright position making his neck and head wobble all over as I drive.  The seat is very sturdy and safe and he says it is comfortable.  We use it in a 2012 Ford Fiesta so it works well in a smaller sedan.  Happy with my purchase.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: lap straps sometimes get twisted and turned around at the buckle area
Seat Type: recline feature of the seat doesn't recline much at all

Review:
This is our second toddler car seat, the first one was a Graco Safeseat that we bought so that it would recline while being strapped in. We took it back because it wore down after 1-2 months making it harder to use and internal straps got all screwed up.

This seat is compact, the straps are smooth. If fits nice in our more compact car and it looks comfortable. Good cup holder and side pockets for toys and such. The seat looks like it will adjust to other sizes very well and much thought was put into the child growing with it. Instead of it being just an afterthought and sales gimic that I see in a lot of other cars seats that claim to be 3-in-1.

My only complaint is that it doesn't recline well, which hasn't stopped my 14 mo daughter from sleeping. But her head does fall forward which seems to be a common complaint with just about all car seats so I think this may be hard to avoid.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Weight Range of Child: toddler
Installation Type: strapped in
Harness Type: straps
Material: smooth

Review: We have two of these seats, one in each car. The seat is easy to install. We watched a video on You Tube and followed the instructions. The seat is cushy, and my daughter is comfortable riding in it. We have taken two road trips with 7+ hours each way in the car and she did not have any issues, was able to nap comfortably in the seat. Once she is seated, it is very easy to adjust the strap to tighten it according by pulling the cord. It is very easy to get her out of the seat by releasing the click-tight button. We had the Britax B-Safe Infant seat which we were happy with, so it was a no-brainer to continue using Britax products.

My 4 month old looks very comfortable in it. I think I like it more than my Graco 4Ever but only because it isn't as bulky.

Especially in the rear facing position when it has to recline in order to be installed properly. If you have anything below a fullsize I don't think it will fit properly without pushing the front seat up into the dashboard. I bought it for my husband's Impala & it barely fits just right.

It took me 20 minutes to figure out how to install it (thanks YouTube) and it still was very unstable. Then when we were driving she loves to nap and her head was leaning forward more than I felt comfortable with. Decided I would send it back and get the grace 4 in 1 car seat. Review:
i have the Chicco convertible for my car but we needed another convertible so I wanted to try another since my son seems to be uncomfortable in Chicco. we went with britax. We installed using click tight and it is a nightmare to install properly. Once tightened in the click tight dial will not turn and you are unable to get seat out. You cannot loosen the strap to unlatch it either. I spent an hour, sweating, body shaking bc I could not get car seat adjusted due to faulty equipment. The Chicco is so easy to install properly it's a joke. I would never buy this seat again and I have no idea how I am going to take it out to make forward facing when the time comes.

Don't waste your time or mo eu when there are safe, user friendly alternatives!
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: installed using click tight, click tight dial will not turn, unable to get seat out, cannot loosen the strap to unlatch it, could not get car seat adjusted due to faulty equipment

Review: The seat is pretty light, and easy to move between cars. I was expecting it to somehow hook into the seat, but it doesn't. So if there isn't a kid in the seat, I still put the seat belt on so if we have an accident the seat doesn't go flying around the back and hit any of the other kids. The extra cup holders are great. The seat seems comfortable, except when our almost 6 year old falls asleep, then his head falls everywhere. He can't really lean his head against the sides of the seat, and if I lean the backseat back further he isn't comfortable sitting in his seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
**Seat Type:** Forward Facing  
**Installation Type:** Seat Belt

Review: This seat is easy to install and helped with a screaming baby that hated the infant car seat.  Comfy and cute.  However, baby head a blowout in the seat and I needed to wash the cover. I watched a video on how to remove it and when I removed the cover, I realized the styrofoam was cracked and broken but not out of place.  I did not hear a crack or any noise for that matter as I was removing the cover so I don’t think it happened in the removal.  This was the first time it was removed.  No accidents and hasn’t been removed from my car since purchase.  This of course is realized right after the return window closed. I’m a single mom and can’t afford to just buy another seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Material: Cover, Styrofoam

Review:
updating my review: we bought this 1.5 years ago. It has been in my vehicle and doesn't get switched between cars. The head rest will not stay up. It will come down while driving sometimes and my daughter has to lean forward because it hurts her shoulder. I have to pull over and fix it.

This was easy to put together and my daughter likes it. Very easy to adjust.

The storage compartment is hard to get open and the back of the booster is not very sturdy. It does not feel very cushioned, but my child has not complained. I like that the shoulder belt is guided so it falls correctly into position.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster
Harness Type: shoulder belt is guided

Review:
While this seat addresses adjustability in many aspects it misses in a couple of areas.
The shape of belt clips and lack of gradation in height of openings of center retaining clip (between legs). These two combined makes for uncomfortable seating as the clips dig into kids legs, my child is slim. Beyond comfort it is difficult to clip the clips in, and it doesn’t help that female portion that accepts the clips is so floppy, with gravity always letting it rest where child would sit. It would help if there was a depression in between legs for it to rest when child is not in seat, like many back seats of cars.

Also when you unzip seat pad you see that seat plastic is flat with square openings. Why not mold plastic slightly curved to accommodate shape of buttocks and area under pelvic bone?

The new strap retention is not as useful as done previously in the pria85 we have, that has plastic clips to hold belts.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Harness Type: belt clips, center retaining clip, female portion that accepts the clips, strap retention, belts
Material: seat plastic, seat pad

Review: I saw a few people complaining and I felt I needed to step in.  I bought this when it was on Kickstarter. My son had recently moved to a booster and I was pretty tired of lugging a car seat or booster when traveling... so when I saw Mifold I was really intrigued. Did my research.. decided to back it and get one as soon as it was available. It's been a game changer. No more lugging a chair around... Mifold folds up and fits in my purse.  People complain that it's complicated. It's really not. Read the instructions.. try it out a few times.. get the hang of it. It's actually really easy. My son has been securing himself for the time he was using it. Now I keep it around for young guests to my car and my son still likes to help them in.  If an 8 and 7 year old can do it.. you can too.  There was one time that I had trouble with getting my nephew out.. but upon looking at it, realized that he pushed the side latches in which locked the seat belt into place. A simple unlock maneuver under his bum and told him to not push in the sides... and we were great for the rest of his visit.  To sum up.. I love it. My son loves it.  Read the instructions.. it's not that hard once you try it a couple times.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster
Installation Type: side latches

Review: I bought this to fit in my husbands matrix. It’s fits but the passenger seat has to be all the way pushed forward leaving no room for a person to sit. However, when we switch to front facing this will fit great! Narrow enough to have someone sit in the back with the seat and we will be able to push the passenger seat back so someone can sit there too. I don’t regret the purchase

Review: We just bought this carseat and love it more than our other one, which was twice the cost.  Our daughter loves the cup holders and my husband and I love that we don't have to twist a knob (like with another brand) to tighten the straps.  It very easy to use and install.

Review:
I purchaused this seat as a replacement for a Britax Boulevard in 2015 in which was involved in an accident and had to be replaced. I did a ton of research first and decided to give this seat a try - at that time my son was 3.5 years old and was forward facing. The install on this seat is not what I would consider difficult -I read all the instructions and was able to get it installed nice and tight into our 2010 Toyota Highlander in about 10 mins.

Update - my son has been using this seat for nearly 3 years and it is great. It is made of high quality materials and is built to last - I've washed the cover a ton and it still looks like new. He loves the seat and says it is very comfortable. I recently purchaused a second one for my 15 month old and have recommended this seat to many freinds.

The one downside worth mentioning: It is heavy AF. It does fold flat and fits in the car seat travel bag nicely but it is NOT lightweight and is a bit of a pain to lug through an airport if you are traveling and gate checking the seat or installing on the plane.
Attribute_Related_Content:

Review: Haven't used yet.  But, used a chicco key fit 30 for our other children and it was great.  The seat is fairly light for an infant carrier.  It is also super easy to install and make level.  No need for rolled up towels to get seat installed correctly.

Review: LOVE!!! We love britax and upgraded to this model after our 35 elite. This car seat is so easy to install after you get the hang of it, and our daughter is so comfortable and happy in her big girl seat!

Special Features: Super Easy, Car Rental inflatable packable portable luggage travel
Review:
I am very happy with this purchase. I was planning a trip with my 5 year old and the thought of having to bring a booster seat everywhere seemed like a nightmare. We were planning on taking a lot of Lyft's and Uber's and needed something compact to store while we walked around.

After using it for 6 days it was extremely easy to carry around. It deflated enough to fit in a small child size backpack and light enough for my child to carry around. It took seconds to inflate and only a few seconds to buckle. Going forward I am definitely recommending this to anyone who has to travel with kids or anyone who needs extra space in their backseat. I definitely would not replace it with her regular booster but this would be perfect to pack for grandparents and travel

Review: Best price for a slim fit on the net. Love how slim it is compared to other car seat. My previous slim fit cost me almost $300. I got this for my second son who is 2 months. Love the price can't beat $200 for a quality car seat.
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Review: I have a rav4. This seat is a beast. My son can't buckle himself in because the seat sits on top of the belt. This is the third britax we've owned and I was just not impressed with it. The belt doesn't move freely through the shoulder loop so what happens is you end up with a ton of slack over the lap/chest that doesn't spring back into place. I thought it was rather unsafe. My son could hardly fit into the base with his coat on and everything...the arm rests were in his way and the base is just an odd shape...almost more circular. We took it out and put it into another vehicle for my smaller child but we have to really take our time to get her into it properly. She wouldn't be able to get in it alone. We have a cheaper seat that is so much easier to get in and out of and the kids are able to adjust themselves quickly and properly. I was always a fan of britax, but this seat is a clunky mess.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Installation Type: Seat Belt
Harness Type: Shoulder loop, lap/chest

Review: Love this car seat! It's definitely not for someone trying to stay compact, but compared to a normal size seat, it really isn't much bulkier. I 100% recommend this seat. Super comfortable for my little one, lots of padding, I overall know my little is safe when riding in this seat
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Special Features: Super Easy, Car Rental inflatable packable portable luggage travel
Review: This is a great product for travel.  It is lightweight and rolls up into a bag or backpack easily.  It inflates quickly and keeps children safe while traveling.  We have used in taxis and rental cars with no issues and we know that our child is safe while we are away from home.  In addition, this is a great seat for regular use as well as it is lightweight and very comfortable.  We found this to be a great solution for an older child who was still too small/young for a seatbelt only but who didn't fit in a heavier, bulky booster seat.  Finally, the customer service from this company is top notch.  They are quickly responsive to any questions on product use or issues and truly want their customers to be happy.  Overall, this is a great product for our family.

Review: My daughter was in the infant seat for too long. She is on the smaller side and I just realized at 16 mo and 19 lbs she needed this seat. I did TONS of research on seat prices and safety and found this to be the most highly rated and the best made. STEEL framed instead of plastic - most all are PLASTIC framed surprisingly - WHAT?! YEAH - AVOID GRACO! And the adjuster for the shoulder straps is great. The day before they fit and the next morning they are too big because they grow so fast - amazing - but just grab the headrest clip thing and voila in one second you are on your way with your baby fitting properly without pulling the whole darn thing out and that whole fiasco. The most persuasion for me to buy this seat was the MANY MANY reviews I read about these seats being in pretty big accidents and the baby never budged an inch. That is the bottom line. Good job Britax. Something that is actually NOT CRAP! And she can use it to 70 pounds which is well worth the cost. Will buy one for our second car.

Review:
I would absolutely rank this seat higher than I did, except for one big problem: the buckle.

The set itself is well constructed, it's a good looking seat (as far as car seats go) it's not too big to leave room for other kids in the back seat, but it has one glaring flaw: the BUCKLE.

The buckle is really difficult to unsnap, some might say impossible. Neither of the kids' grandmothers can depress the button well enough to unsnap the straps. If you have caregivers who will be using this seat with arthritis, forget it, get a different seat. I can barely get the buckle to work it's so tough. If you're putting your kid in and out of this seat many times a day, having to deal with that buckle is a dealbreaker. I wish I'd know that this was a problem so I could weigh the pros with that huge functional con. You can read other reviews that state the same thing: Some kids are getting stuck in their seats because the buckle will not budge, and this appears to be a problem the company is AWARE of, but is not fixing.

Also, the straps that go around the child's legs leave very little room once buckled in the seat. The buckle is way too far back on the seat, meaning it digs into your kid's crotch. I have a skinny kid, but if your little one has juicy thighs, the straps might be way too tight to be comfortable.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: buckle is really difficult to unsnap, buckle will not budge
Material: straps that go around the child's legs leave very little room, straps might be way too tight

Review:
This carseat is terrible. I had a different car seat on my registry and someone purchased me this seat instead, which was the worst decision anyone has ever made. First off, it's VERY difficult to install. The latch strap is impossible to tighten and the shape of the sides makes it very difficult to put your weight into the seat to tighten it. The belt or latch strap threads under the seat, and the seams on the fabric there are so sharp they have actually cut my hand trying to thread the belt. The positioning of the cupholders on the sides means that the seatbelt install pulls up that side of the carseat making it crooked.

Once (if) you manage to get the thing installed correctly, it doesn't get any better. The pieces at the top used to adjust the back height RATTLE constantly while driving. It's so aggravating. We had to keep a towel up there to stop the constant noise. Not only that, but they're SHARP! If you ever turn around to pat your kid's hair or hand them something, watch out for those things. They've left a massive scratch up my arm from getting too close.

Finally, the straps on the seat are always getting twisted. As if it's not difficult enough to get your toddler in and out of the the carseat, the openings in the clips are just large enough that the straps are always twisting around.

I would highly recommend against this seat. I have the Graco 4Ever, and it's significantly better. Better yet is the Britax Boulevard, the ClickTight installation is a game changer. If you STILL want this seat - please come take mine before I have the satisfaction of burning it or throwing it off a cliff.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: latch strap is impossible to tighten; belt or latch strap threads under the seat; seatbelt install pulls up that side of the carseat making it crooked
Harness Type: straps on the seat are always getting twisted; openings in the clips are just large enough that the straps are always twisting around

Review:
(Edited on 3/31/2018 to raise the rating from 4 to 5 stars. The lap belt guides do not move in on their own anymore on the newer models!!! A quick recap: this is basically a seatbelt repositioner. A "regular" booster's purpose is to raise the child higher so the seatbelt fits better, and the mifold is a different way of doing it. It may not be the most comfortable seat, but the mifold offers convenience and compactness without sacrificing safety. If the child is too wiggly, this isn't the best product, but then such a child should be in a 5-point harness. Be aware and reasonable about the product's limitations, and you'll be satisfied. You can disregard the below review's portion about the lap belt guides moving in, but I left it in, just so you know there may be different versions.)

******************************
(Original review)
I've been following this product since 2015, participated in the company's crowdfunding and have been eagerly waiting for my mifold to arrive for months. I haven't received that one yet, but imagine my surprise and delight when a mifold showed up in the Vine program, so I quickly grabbed one.

This is such a brilliant concept. The purpose of a traditional booster seat is to raise the child up a few inches so the car's seatbelt, designed to fit an adult, can be safely used by a smaller-sized human - the lap belt should not sit at a child's waist. What the mifold does is to bring down the seatbelt to properly restrain a child. Again, brilliant.

Part of finding a good booster seat involves how well it fits into your car's rearseat design, like the slope, shape, etc... The best booster seat is the one which fits your car properly. Because the seat portion can bend in half, this allows more flexibility in the type of backseats a booster seat can be placed. The mifold is also great for a larger child who sits too high for a booster seat but sits too low for a car's seatbelt during that in-between stage. It's not as if every child needs to be raised up about 4-5 inches for a proper fit.

On the flip side, the mifold may not work as well for shorter children. Since a car's backseat's depth is most likely deeper than the length of a shorter child's upper thighs, the child's legs would be sticking out straight when used properly. Okay, fine, but if the child wants to bend his/her legs at the knees, the child may sit closer to the edge of the backseat, which will make the butt slide farther away from the crease of the back and possibly make the child slouch. Again, depends on the car's backseat and the child.

Then, its size... OH, ITS SIZE!!! If you're short on backseat width and have a smaller child who doesn't need the entire width of a traditional booster seat, the mifold will give you those few precious inches for a better 3-across. For the caretakers of 3 kids who feel like their non-minivans/large SUVs won't accommodate multiple child restraint seats but can't afford to buy a larger vehicle, the mifold may save your budget.

It's a bit heavier than it looks. The seat bottom is rather firm and small - it's a little over 8" by 8" when unfolded. I was concerned this would be too uncomfortable for the occupant, but it wasn't, possibly because a car's rearseat is very cushioned, allowing the mifold to sink into the cushion. An adult weighing a bit over 100lbs tried it for testing purposes only, and the adult felt fine.

The width can be adjusted out to 13.5" internally at the upper thighs, then tapering to a width of 13.25" closer to the knee - the lap belt guides angle in a bit. The red lap belt guides should not be so narrow they touch the occupant.

I'd give this 5 stars for ingenuity and practicality, but there are a couple of issues:

1. The lap belt guides move in too easily. Pulling them out requires using a couple of tabs, but pushing them in requires virtually no effort. It's very easy to push in the lap belt guides. I think the intent was to make it easier for the child to adjust the lap belt guides' width, but it would've been better to make the child adjust the width to lock in the position before placing it on the car's backseat. If there is some quick, jerky movements while riding, the booster seat may shift. Also, another person sitting next to a mifold user can accidentally push in the lap belt guide. To be fair, I haven't had the lap belt guides get moved yet while in the car, but I can foresee how this may be a problem when things get bumped at a bad time.

2. The shoulder belt guide/clip is difficult to open initially. I can open it since I'm an adult who had some practice, but younger kids will need help, along with adults who may not be familiar with the mifold, like the driver for a class field trip. I don't know if the shoulder belt guide mechanism has to lock for the mifold to work properly. Other booster seats have shoulder belt guides that let the user slide in the vehicle's shoulder belt and leave at that, though having it lock does prevent the vehicle's shoulder belt from sliding out.

Other quirks that don't affect the star rating:
- The shoulder belt guide/clip is made of plastic. It seems durable, and I hope it doesn't break or get loosened after repeated use.
- There are lots of sewn-on tags and labels. Since (I assume) these are regulatory requirements, there's nothing mifold can do about them, considering the lack of available space for such items due to the compact size of the mifold.
- The manual can be stored in a slot incorporated into the mifold, but it's a little difficult to get the manual in and out - be sure to leave the manual sticking out a bit so it can be removed easier.

It's obvious a lot of thought went into designing this. With the mifold, there's no excuse for not using a booster seat, even when traveling. Besides the mechanisms of the guides, I love this product. I hope this gains more popularity so the difficulty and unfamiliarity of using the mifold disappears. Or, maybe the next generation of mifold will improve it. I don't know if this can replace traditional booster seats for some but for traveling and carpools, this is practically a must-have safety item without compromising convenience. In the meantime, I continue to wait for the mifold I ordered via crowdfunding while being grateful for the opportunity to receive one for review - many thanks to Jon Sumroy, the mifold team and Amazon's Vine program.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster seat, traditional booster seat, seatbelt repositioner
Weight Range of Child: larger child, shorter children, smaller child
Installation Type: seatbelt, lap belt guides, shoulder belt guide/clip
Harness Type: 5-point harness, seatbelt
Material: plastic, firm seat bottom

Review:
Why is choosing a carseat so difficult and emotionally fraught?! We kept our slim, average-height daughter rear-facing in her Graco Snugride 35 bucket seat until she grew too tall for the straps (22 months, 22 lbs), then started looking for a convertible seat for her to use for the next several years. After subscribing to Consumer Reports and reading everything I could find on the internet, I narrowed it down to this seat and the Maxi-Cosi Pria 70 based on safety features and user reviews, considering ease of use, comfort, and vehicle fit. I just couldn't decide, but I knew we would want two seats (one for my CRV and one for my husband's Tahoe), so we bought one of each. The Maxi-Cosi went in my car, the Britax went in the Tahoe. I really like them both (and my daughter has no complaints) but I like the Maxi-Cosi better for the following reasons:
--the fabric feels and looks nicer and like it will be cooler in the summer (we live in TX)
--the seat feels much more cushiony
--the "wings" around her head offer significantly more coverage in case of a crash. They also give her head more support. (I was afraid she wouldn't like them because she can't really turn her head to the side, but she doesn't seem to mind so far.)
--the Maxi-Cosi has a nice cupholder and more room for her toys to sit with her.
--the Britax between-the-legs buckle is strangely positioned -- she's almost sitting on it.

Both seats are attractive and fit well (enough) in the vehicles rear-facing. We have only one child, so she sits in the middle seat. If there were more than one seat, it might start to be an issue in my CRV, but she will be forward-facing before we have another kid, so I'm not too concerned.

The Britax does win, hands-down, in one area so far: cleaning. The M-C seat has to be taken apart to get the cover off, and then has to be hand-washed (what were they thinking?!). The Britax seat cover comes off easily and washes well. I know this because it got thoroughly broken in with a spilled cup of milk AND A bout of diarrhea on its very first outing -- UGH! We were grateful to be able to yank the seat cover off with no trouble, hose it down, and toss it in the washer. The trickiness of washing it is a definite downside of the Maxi-Cosi, but we're hoping to minimize the issue by not allowing her to eat or drink in that seat. So the fancy cupholder is just for toys, but that still comes in handy.

The bottom line is, both seats are terrific and seem very safe, and I would recommend either.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 22 lbs
Installation Type: rear-facing
Material: fabric feels and looks nicer, more cushiony, seat cover comes off easily and washes well

Review: Let me start off by saying...this is bulky. There is NO WAY you can fit three of these in a back seat...at least in a small suv like mine (kia sportage). However, this is the easiest car seat I have ever bought. I had a baby trend baby car seat...hated it. It's too bulky and too heavy with baby in it. I was never able to lift it and carry it comfortably. This is much better, even though, you can't really take it out of the car with baby, it's still the better option. 1) so easy to put in. The little buckles just snap in place, so cool. It has a leveler in the car seat (For rear facing) that will let you know immediately, if you're doing it right...it's foolproof. 2) the rest of the buckles and straps you'll need for forward facing are attached to the seat...so you will NEVER lose them, when the time comes to actually use them, that's cool. 3) the seat belt actually is able to be moved up and down by also moving the head rest up or down...so there is no need to take the car seat apart and thread the belts back through a taller opening to accomodate growing baby (like the graco nautilus)...you just move the headrest up and the belts move up with it...genius! Overall, very easy to use, but like I said, no way to fit three in back seat. Also, it's like a cocoon, so ,my baby has a hard time being able to see his older brother, who is facing forward.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing
Installation Type: The little buckles just snap in place
Harness Type: the seat belt actually is able to be moved up and down by also moving the head rest up or down, the belts move up with it

Review:
It only works well as an infant seat to grace our living room. Since this was our first ( and hopefully ) only infant car seat I did not know at first just how tough and lacking this seat is. The positives are that it is very soft and comfortable. Our baby loved sleeping in it. The installation with base was pretty good although it could only get JUST TIGHT ENOUGH with the latch system on our Mazda CX-5. The cord is not long enough to ratchet it tighter so it seemed tight enough but I could not pull any tighter.

Now onto the cons and these are severe enough that I would NEVER suggest this car seat to ANYONE unless it was an emergency. The Carseat attachments for the popular UPPABABY stroller are not secure and this seat moves AT LEAST 3 inches forward and backwards. Yes it does not fall but it doe snot create any confidence. ThE STRAPS.. oh the tightening straps . As you might have read countless other times. The straps get caught on the underside of the plastic bottom and you CANNOT pull them tight from the front of the unit. WE HAVE TO take the seat out of the car to tighten the straps. They get tangled underneath EVERY time. It sucks. I have had to rethread the straps at least 15 times and I have to tighten him in it outside the car. Removing the seat from the car is also really hard as you have to tilt the seat to the side and pull it sideways as the seat gets caught if you try to pull it from any other angle. The release buttons for the stroller are so deep and hidden on either side that you need 2 hands to undo the buttons even though you need another hand to lift the chair!!!

FINALLY as others have mentioned the carry bar clicks very loud and will wake any baby when you adjust it ( both hands are needed once again) . I realize this may be a safety thing to register that it is locked but the click is so loud it will wake any baby and dog sleeping nearby. I don't normally write many reviews but I just wanted to pass the word. It's a relatively affordable chair that is built well and cozy BUT you cannot loosen and tighten this 90% of the time. I wish we could have returned it but I thought they all were supposed to be crappy like this ;( .
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: infant seat
Weight Range of Child: infant
Installation Type: latch system
Harness Type: straps, tightening straps

Review:
I initially would have given this 5 stars but after having it for around 2 years I'm not in love with it. My second child will be in need in of a convertible seat soon and I will not be buying a second NextFit. While it does the job and is a solid and good seat, there are enough irritants with it that are causing me to pass a second time.

- It is HEAVY. Changing cars is almost unbearable and my parents refuse to do it because it is too heavy for them. It is very awkward getting it into the back of sedan like vehicles, all around a massive pain to move. If you NEVER or very rarely change it out this might not be a huge factor for you, but it is a bear.

- When rear facing, it can be really hard to tighten the straps because it is SO close to the seat. This might be the case with other car seats too, but my parents especially complain a lot. I can do it, but I don't love it and I have to use a lot of force. Which leads to the next issue.

- My current seat is actually a replacement from Chicco (INCREDIBLE customer service) because the plastic casing around the orange button to loosen the straps kept popping out and eventually the plastic broke because to tighten the straps you have to pull up instead of at the same angle as the strap given how close the strap is to the seat. (kinda hard to explain) Well this same issue has happened on my current seat. I cannot tell you how annoying it is trying to tighten the straps and the whole plastic bit pops off.

- The button to raise and lower the headrest which also adjusts the straps seems a little flimsy. Every now and then when my 3.5 yr old gets into the seat I notice that the headrest has gone back down. It takes a bit of wiggling and jiggling to get it lock again at the correct height.

- It's hot. The seat doesn't breath well. It's really cushiony which is nice, but at the cost of being hot. Fortunately my daughter doesn't overheat too much, but my son always is really hot in his carseats, so this seat definitely won't work for him.

- Even with the strap covers, my daughter gets lines and irritants in her neck. Maybe I'm overzealous in my tightening, but I do feel bad after a long ride and I see her neck.

- All the inclines seem kind of a waste. I can only have the seat included at 1 or 2 rear facing for it to be in the correct level. Any other inclines take the seat out of the level area. Not sure about forward facing as I haven't switched around to that yet.

All the pros that people mention are true, but for the above reasons I won't get another one.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing, Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 3.5 yr old
Harness Type: straps, strap covers
Material: plastic, cushiony, doesn't breath well, hot

The rear anchor was a little tricky to figure out, but after talking to some car seat technicians I finally figured it out. This was actually not my first choice, I really wanted the Pavilion, but it was just too expensive. I feel like this seat is almost as good though.
