Review: I purchased this car seat from Amazon and it arrived 09/29/2012. On 01/23/2013 I was unable to release the buckle when dropping my daughter off at pre-school, and returned home prepared to cut her out of the seat. When I arrived home, the buckle opened - so I took her back to pre-school. The following day, I experienced the same problem - except when I arrived home, the buckle still would not open. I came inside for the heavy-duty scissors, not sure if they would cut the straps - and my wife came out to investigate. With some effort, she was finally able to free our daughter. I did some investigating, and found this is a common problem with Graco car seats - and as the review is titled, there is a federal probe into these buckles: "The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating complaints that children have been trapped in Graco car seats because the buckles won't unlatch." The probe covers seats made between 2009 and 2011, but ours was purchased new in 2012. I would urge people NOT TO BUY THIS CAR SEAT UNTIL GRACO HAS THIS ISSUE RESOLVED. I cannot take another chance putting my daughter in this seat because of two aggravating, inconvenient, and potentially dangerous incidents where I would not have been able to extricate my child in the event of an emergency.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type
- buckle would not open/unlatch

The weight limits are awesome for maxing out rear facing and overall the seat seems to be very comfortable and roomy for our son. He was born 11.5lbs, so he outgrew the infant seat very quickly, but this seat will definitely last us a few years! It’s super easy to install and the user manual is very easy to navigate. Review:
I received my order only to find that the material on the carseat matched that exactly of the Onyx G3. It did not have the softer material on the inside, as pictured on the G4. I sent it back, and reordered, as Amazon thought they shipped the G3 by mistake. Only to receive the exact same version of the seat again. At this point, Amazon said they don't know if the picture is wrong, or if the boxes aren't accurate.

The strange thing is, the infant padding from the G3 looks on the picture like a side padding, whereas the padding shown on the G4 is a bottom padding.

So what I received is a carseat that looks like the G3, but has the infant padding from the G4. AT this point I"m frustrated.

Anyone else have this issue???
Attribute_Related_Content: Material: material on the carseat matched that exactly of the Onyx G3; did not have the softer material on the inside, as pictured on the G4

Review:
Car: 2008 Mazdaspeed3

First off: I'm a die hard Britax fan. Our stroller, infant carrier, etc. are all from Britax. I didn't hesitate to buy the Marathon G4 for my wife's Mazda CX-7 while I continued using the infant carrier in my car.

When the time came to buy a car seat for my car, I test fit the Marathon in the back seat. It's tight back there to begin with so I didn't think it would fit but it did-barely. The front passenger's seat in my car would be useless with the Marathon installed. The Marathon is taller and doesn't seem to tilt as much as I wanted so that the seat was adjusted properly and an adult would fit in the front passenger's seat. I'm not a fan of using pool noodles or rolled up towels so I decided to keep looking. After reading hundreds of reviews, I narrowed it down between the NextFit and Maxi-Cosi Pria 70.

I decided to buy the NextFit based on comments about the height, adjustability and ease of use. The Pria 70 had quite a few comments about how wide the seat was and that it didn't fit small spaces as well as expected.

Pros:
*Easy to install-takes 1/2 the time to install the NextFit vs. the Britax seat
*Easy to adjust-required no pool noodles/rolled up towels in both cars Level indicator is in a great place for seat installation
*Fits in my tiny back seat perfectly and an adult can still sit in the passenger's seat up front (not the case with the Britax seat)
*Doesn't obstruct my view out the rear passenger's side window when merging in traffic
*My son can see very well out of the back and side windows (keeps him from getting bored)
*Seated position is comfortable and doesn't 'crunch up' his legs like many rear-facing seats. It's more of a lounging position. Easier on the neck when he falls asleep.
*No mistaking that it's locked in place or latched properly.
*Red release button is easy to use (Marathon often requires two hands to release)
*MUCH easier to clean than the Britax without taking it completely apart

Cons:
*Stickers were not applied properly so there are a lot of wrinkles
*There are a lot of stickers on it

I'm seriously considering selling the Britax seat (less than 6 months old) and buying another NextFit since we'll be using it for a while.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear-facing
Installation Type: Easy to install, Level indicator for seat installation, No mistaking that it's locked in place or latched properly, Red release button is easy to use
Material: MUCH easier to clean

We tried the same seats model on sale at Costco and baby R us and were defective as well. I emailed inquiry to Graco and awaiting for response, but it's on market for few years.
Bought instead in baby r us aGraco Turbobooster LX with trueshield technology, working well.

Review:
My main car seat is the AMAZING Peg Perego Primo Viaggio SIP 5/70, which I HIGHLY recommend!!
I purchased this Graco seat as I needed a spare one for use in my mothers' truck and got tired of taking mine out for her to use. This one was on a lightening deal for $99 plus a mail in rebate of $25 AND I had a $50 Amazon gift card so I really couldn't beat getting it for only ~$30 (once you add taxes). That being said, if I hadn't gotten it at such a deal, it would have been returned right away. My daughter much prefers sitting more upright and this has her laying back too much (she is rear-facing). It is also extremely difficult to tighten/loosen the seat belt straps (which has to be done EVERY time you put baby in/out of the seat)!!! In my opinion, it's not worth the hassle.
I'll be getting her a different car seat as soon as possible.

Harness Type: seat belt straps

Review:
Very disappointed in this model compared to the Boulevard we already have. The straps are very tight and can't be loosened to a reasonable length. It's to the point that we wonder if it isn't a faulty model. Additionally, the belt latch over the crotch is very tight. We removed the cushion from that area and it's still quite snug. Our child is in the 5th % for weight and 50th % for height, so clearly our specific car seat would not fit most children.

It is installed in our 2006 4Runner and appears to sit too upright, not the recommended recline I've read about. We will be replacing it.

Meanwhile, the Boulevard model we use in our Volvo XC90 has exceeded our expectations - great fit for baby and in the car.

Review:
I purchased two of these car seats for both of our vehicles during the black friday sale ($95). This is the worst purchase ever. They are unbelievable difficult to tighten the chest straps and I have to jump through hoops to get my child strapped in. It takes several minutes and tons of tugging to tighten and it still doesn't pass the pinch test. I've tried all of the hacks and they still do not allow me to get a snug fit on my child. My babysitter has the Graco slim fit and does not have this issue. It's concerning that multiple people report this issue and Graco still keeps this carseat on the market. I did not have this issue with the chicco car seat and I wish I wasn't fooled by the price, 5 star reviews, and for whatever reason this seat passed multiple independent crash tests with higher safety ratings than the Britax I wanted. I discarded the box and cannot return. I would not trust getting in an accident with this car seat or even having to slam the breaks.

Yes, I checked strap alignment and correct height adjusted for my child. This model appears to have this issue and discussed in mutliple reviews and online search hacks. This is a terrible product to keep on the market. I will be trashing these instead of trying to resell. $200 is not worth any child's life.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: difficult to tighten the chest straps; does not pass the pinch test; cannot get a snug fit; checked strap alignment and correct height adjusted

The only negative I could say is that the color since light does show everything. I would recommend getting the darker color or more of a pattern in order to prevent if we're looking dirty. Review: We love this carseat.  It is not as heavy as other car seats. It is very comfortable. We went a 13 hour trip decided to leave at night so our 2 year old could sleep for at least some of the trip. Placed the car seat in a rear facing position at an incline and she sleeped for 7 hours (she is a  very light sleeper and 7 hours is amazing for us). Once she woke up we placed the carseat on forward facing position and it was easy to install back and forth. When the car seat is in forward facing position it won't inclide FYI. Also wanted to mention on our rental for the trip (KIA  Seronto) the installation was very easy. On the other hand on our KIA Sonata the installation is a bit of a challenge due to the latch not being long enough for easy latching. It IS possible but requires a lot of patients. Once that latch is on that carseat isn't going nowhere. This is the only down side for us.

Review: My 13 month old and I were recently in a horrible car wreck. He's small (17 lbs) and still in this car seat rear facing. Our car was totalled. I had to t-bone a Dodge Truck due to a weather related accident entirely out of my control. I have broken bones. My son (and his car seat and base) didn't have a scratch on them!!! The only mark he has is bruising on the side of his head probably from the air bag. I truly never bought our seats for safety...the color and comfort factors mattered more. After our accident I'm just so thankful that it did the job it was supposed to and my son is alive and well thanks to this car seat!!!

Review: Let me first say that this booster carseat is awesome but....and this is my own fault....it is not for children under forty pounds. When searching for a carseat that I could use for several of my grandbabies. I was delighted that I found a booster type for 30 pounds and up. Once I received the booster I read the manual. Safety standards have changed since this seat was produced and the manual clearly states forty pounds and up. I went back to the Amazon description and at the beginning it says for thirty pounds and up but scroll down and again I did find that in keeping up with standards the booster is for forty pounds and up. My error but honestly confusing. So I'd like to see the reference to thirty pounds removed. I only purchased this particular one because I thought differently.
Attribute_Related_Content: Weight Range of Child: forty pounds and up, thirty pounds and up

Review: My ONLY issue with this carseat is there is not much legroom in rear-facing mode. We also tried out the Graco Extend2fit and the Clek fllo and ended up choosing the Clek. Rear-facing for as long as possible is extremely important to me and ultimately I felt my daughter would be more comfortable in a seat that gave her more legroom. For comparison, my Chicco Nextfit infant carseat gave more legroom than this did. My daughter is only 30%ile for height and her feet already touched the seat using this one. It is otherwise comfortable, VERY easy to use and very good quality.

They've done a great job with grass roots marketing but the product is not worth a penny, in my opinion. I bought to mifolds at the beginning of their campaign. The product is so difficult to use. Review: This is nice for smaller cars and it looks cute, but there isn't much space in this seat.  I guess they had to take something away to make it easily fit into small back seats and that is why we bought it. We bought this as an extra seat and my 3 year old said she prefers her other seat over this one. The other seat is the Graco Smart Seat. This is a good seat, which is why 5 stars, I just feel certain details need to be stated. We prefer Graco for their steel reinforced frames and we bought this one because it was cheaper than another Smart Seat and meant for smaller vehicles. I think it's pretty much the same as the Nautilus by Graco honestly. We bought that one for our oldest daughter a few years ago. The only difference is they made a few slight improvements. The straps are easier to adjust, and you can choose which side your cup holder goes on, which is nice since my daughter is left handed, and of course the appearance and price is different. Overall this seat does what we bought it for but to be honest if you want comfort for long trips I would suggest investing in a more expensive seat.

Review:
The pros: The color is great! It is very comfortable for the baby - he actually smiles really big every single time I put him in here. It has a very narrow profile so it helped me get three seats in the back seat of a sedan. I love the strap height adjuster in the back. It makes it super easy to raise the strap height as they grow without having to take the straps apart. The canopy is nice and large and provides a lot of coverage from the sun.

The cons: The handle is very difficult to adjust. The buttons are super hard to push down in order to tip it into a different position. I struggle with it every single time, and my wrists and hands were really sore when we first got the seat. The seat is heavy and awkward to carry a baby around in - though I think all bucket seats are like this, which is why I don't often carry them around in the seat. The buckle is a puzzle piece, so you have to piece it together before putting both pieces into the crotch part of the buckle. This is really ridiculous as the only reason for it I can figure out is that it is preventing the child from being able to buckle themselves into the seat - it still releases just as easily. I'm not sure why we would want to prevent baby's from buckling themselves in, and none I know of would ever master this skill while still in this seat anyway, so every time I have to do the annoying puzzle piece buckle I wonder what they were thinking with that one. Also, the base doesn't fit in my car very well. It seems to sit not level from left to right and I try adjusting it all the time with no success. Without a pool noodle it sits very upright and there wasn't enough room to adjust the base so that didn't happen. With a pool noodle it sits at a better angle, but I'm having the off level issue then. This is probably specific to my car (a Saturn L300) and the fact that I have to have the seat outboard instead of in the middle.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: bucket seats
Installation Type: base
Harness Type: strap height adjuster, puzzle piece buckle

Review: Just received the car seat from Amazon and installed it in lets say 30 minutes. I struggled because it took me time to figure out how to extend the belt and locate the hook behind the seat for teether belt. Other than that my daughter was super excited to sit forward facing and the seat was super cozy. It was a bitter sweet moment to see my little one graduate from chicco cortina key fit to this forward facing seat. Sniff, sniff... Highly recommend this purchase to any parent.

I think that when she is older it will benefit us better, but for now, I think this car seat is not for us.  However, I do like the fact that every piece can be easily taken out and washed.

Review: Bought this car seat as soon as my son outgrew his infant seat, maybe around 6 months old. He’s 21 months now and we were just in a serious car accident, a head on collision with another car and then a second impact into an embankment. This car seat did EVERYTHING we needed it to do. My son came out completely unharmed without a single scratch on him. It was a little tricky to figure out the belt path and what not when we bought it but not enough to be a real issue. We also moved it from vehicle to vehicle pretty often without any problems. I would recommend this car seat 10 out of 10 times.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 6 months old, 21 months old
Installation Type: belt path

We put it behind the passenger seat, and obviously the seat can't be pushed back all the way but my fiancé can push the seat back enough. My daughter easily falls asleep on long car rides and seems to have no comfort issues. After reading the reviews on how safe it has kept children that have been in accidents I had to buy it. AND I would definitely recommend the SURE latch system. Makes moving from one car to the other very easy!

We still have ours rear-facing and will continue as long as our HUGE toddler fits that way (leg room is a little cramped, but Safety First!).  I did a lot of research on carseats and this one has continuous good reviews, fantastic safety ratings.  We trust the Britax brand and valued Safety over appearance, comfort or price.  It fits well in the middle seat of my Nissan Rogue, is very roomy in my husbands large Dodge truck, and my Aunt has two of them in the captains chairs of her Ford Explorer.

Review: Have been using this booster with my 3-year old for about a month as his younger sister needed his previous convertible (also a Graco); love the booster.  Easy to use, my son can climb in and out of the seat very easily.  Added bonus - the cup holders are in perfect position for him (location in previous seat was awkward and the cups always ended up on the floor, rolling under the front seat).  At his age on longer car trips during which he naps, I do miss the 5-point harness that kept him in a better position (he doesn't much care for the head pillow that came with the booster), but, once seated, if you pull the shoulder strap all the way out so that it retracts and "locks" it helps give him some additional support (and keeps him from wiggling side to side).  We are very pleased with this seat overall, have already been asked about it by many of our friends, and highly recommend it.

Review:
Bought the ultimate comfort series version from a BM retailer. This is a very good car seat. I was considering the regular Marathon version which was $30 less however the clicktight is so worth the extra dollars. All you have to do is line up your seat belt in the proper slots then shut the seat back down and that's it! Rock solid installation. Seat will not budge. In rear facing recline mode, it didn't take as much space from the driver seat the way my chicco keyfit 30 infant seat did. I'd say I had an inch more clearance for the driver even while reclined.

I have it in a 2014 Odyssey and am able to place in it the middle of the second row. Normally car seats in the middle slide around since the middle area has a smaller contact patch but with the clicktight, it will not budge. I also have had it rear-facing in the rear passenger seat of a 2009 Corolla and it fits and gives the front passenger enough space to be comfortable.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: Clicktight, Seat Belt
Material: Ultimate comfort series

Review:
Against my gut, I went ahead and got this to try out for my niece and it just doesn't work as a rear facing car seat. It's super slim, so it almost fits 3 across, but even in the van I would struggle to go three. It has two and would be a tight fit on three for me. The lack of a base just caused a headache. I have a newer 2019 Chevy Equinox, as well as a 2013 minivan and it is not working in either vehicle. I thought that I'd give it a go in my Dad's 05 Silverado and see if it was just something with the way the seats were in my car, versus perhaps and older vehicle and it still didn't work correctly.

I followed all of the instructions, watched videos, and even resorted to taking it to the fire house for a check. The seat just does not want to stay on the level line. My niece is only 23 lbs, well within the range of the 5-40 lbs recommended for the rear facing option. I worked with the firehouse to get it level and then put her in it. I did a few test laps out back and sure enough, after a few bumps and driving around the building, when I'd get out the level line would be off. It has a suggestion in the booklet about using a towel or rolled up blanket, but that still didn't fix the issue.

The seat is cute, and it does work when flipped around, though. I tested it out forward facing and it stays where it should and is leveled out. It's kind of frustrating after going through all the steps. What I ultimately decided to do was take my nephews EvenFlow convertible seat and flip it to rear facing for my niece and then flipped this one forward for my nephew. He doesn't seem to mind the Miney seat and once they're both big enough, I can flip the seats back around and use this for my nieces seat. It's just been a process and I cannot recommend this in good conscience as a rear facing seat. It was a hassle. I hope I explained it well enough and that someone finds this helpful.

To it's positive, the clips on this are easy to adjust. The design is great. It is cushioned and well padded on the sides. The dual cup holders are awesome for taking sippy cups and drinks along without spills. I also like that the back piece can come out and I can wash it or wet cloth wash it and it seems to dry quickly. I just can't use this rear facing. The men at the firehouse suggested that I actually flip the other seat, so that's what we're doing. The front facing option has been a non-issue thus far.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear facing, forward facing, convertible
Weight Range of Child: 5-40 lbs, 23 lbs
Installation Type: level line, using a towel or rolled up blanket
Harness Type: clips are easy to adjust
Material: cushioned and well padded on the sides, back piece can come out and I can wash it or wet cloth wash it and it seems to dry quickly

Review:
We bought this seat for our child once he was approaching about 18 lbs. At first, I thought the seat was going to swallow him, but he has grown into it nicely with the adjustable headrest. We didn't want to buy multiple seats over the next few years, and so far the quality of this seat has impressed us.

It's very easy to install and very easy to make adjustments. Our son is currently 17 months old, so we plan to keep him rear facing until at least 24 months old, and the seat is so easy to turn around sing the base does not have to be moved at all. The cup holder and arm rests are a nice feature as well.

The seat is a bit heavy for my wife to move, but it feels like quality material and the little man seems to enjoy it. You can also adjust the tilt in case you're going on longer trips.

Cons: It's a little heavy, but it feels SAFE.

Installation Type: easy to install

Review: We have only been using this seat for a month so I realize our review may change as we use it longer. I love this seat! It can be tricky to get it to go rear facing but once you figure out the straps it is super easy to install. You really can't change the recline in the rear facing position but you shouldn't need to. It is a bigger seat so if you have a small car it may be a tight fit (it fits fine in our Malibu and Accord when we had it). The knob to loosen the strap is a bit tough to use in the rear facing position with the leather seats. However, I have figured out how to turn it just right and it isn't a big deal. It is super comfy for our son. It is very nice that the strap height slides up and down to adjust. The knob to tighten is easy and makes it easy to get the baby in there secure. Despite a couple of annoyances, I really like this seat and would recommend it.

Review: We just bought 2 of these for my Subaru Forester. We had 2 Chicco Nextfits, but they were bulky and hard to tighten. So, we wanted to try something else and looked for something slimmer. This was an obvious choice, and it had good reviews and a nice price. The Slimfits came in, and compared to the Nextfits, they are almost exactly the same size. I did not gain any actual backseat room, though they do have a slimmer appearance since there's not so much padding. And that's the other reason they're getting 3 stars - they're much less cushy & comfortable. The cushioning is slim, too. The Slims feel less solid, less safe. They were also a little harder to install tightly since there's only 1 tightening strap, and the Nextfit has two. However, the harness straps seem to tighten more easily, and that's a big deal - I was struggling with the Nextfit every day. So, this may not be a bad carseat, but it doesn't look good next to a Nextfit.

My husband was the one who noticed this but the white logos on the seat had little brown spots kind of what mildew or mold may look like on fabric. In the first picture, it is not present and what the logo should look like. In the 2 pictures that follow, you can visibly see the brown specs.

Review:
I just installed this for the first time in our van. Our baby is due in a few weeks and I wanted it ready to go. The base installs SO easily with latch. You just have to pull a strap, and it gets tight enough with no problem. Every other car seat I have had has been hard to tighten, and I've used quite a few as this is for our 5th child. I didn't have to put a rolled up towel under this seat to get it to the right angle, and that is awesome! I LOVE the level on the base, it makes it easy to see that it's installed properly.

The seat isn't too heavy and we will be able to use it for quite a while. Our daughter will outgrow the maximum height long before the weight. It seems really well cushioned and cozy for a baby, and it looks like it will fit her well.

I will try to remember to update this after baby arrives and we actually use it for a while, but I am VERY happy with it so far!

Review:
I’ll say, the expandability and great safety rating make this seat almost perfect, but as some of the other reviewers have stated it does take up quite a bit of space. We have a VW Atlas (which is pretty large) and we still have a limit on how far the seat in front of this car seat can move. For me, though, the biggest pet-peeve with this car seat is how much of a headache it is to clean our other car seat is slightly worse (it’s a Cybex something or other) but they both have a solid D- in the cleanability department.

When your kid has that inevitable car spit-up (and it will happen), expect it to run down deep into the cracks and crevices of this thing and fight your every effort to get it out. Once it’s in there, your only hope is bleach water and a hose with a strong sprayer attached. If you’re ever able to purge it of that unmistakable stench of upchucked milk, you’ll now face the formidable challenge of getting it dry. You’d think that would be the easy part, but unless you live in some warm, arid climate, you’ll go through the twilight zone episode that is thinking you’ve gotten all the water out, picking it up to put it back in the vehicle, and then having it start leaking all over again. If you’re looking for a car seat, do yourself a favor and find one that’s easier to clean.
Attribute_Related_Content: Material: hard to clean, difficult to dry, requires bleach water and strong sprayer to clean

Review:
When we needed a second car seat for my husband's new car, this is the one we ended up getting (for a 2 yr old who is 36 inches tall and 32 lbs). Currently we have the Orbit toddler seat in my car (SUV) and once our daughter tried the Britax, it was apparent that it fit her much better than the Orbit has. It's roomier, it fit easily in the back seat of a MINI Cooper Countryman, it's lighter and the install was much easier. I wish we had tried it earlier and finally just broke down and ordered a second one to replace the Orbit seat.

We bought a separate cover for the first one and getting it on was easy and fast. Our daughter loves the cup holders which is a small thing but seems to make her very happy. Since we routinely travel 90 min to see family, it's nice she can have her water back there or a place to store some toys.

I guess my best detail is that if your child is on the taller and larger side, this is a great car seat (with plenty of room to grow and adjust) for a toddler! The Orbit system has always been a bit too small for us (infant seat and toddler seat especially in the shoulder area). Our child just loves it!

Installation Type: install was much easier

Review: I love the feeling that my children are safe! I’m big on careseat safety, so after a lot of research I decided to buy this car seat! I recommend it to everyone that asks because it’s easy to install, comfortable, and has a lot of extra protection. The price was a little intimidating but the peace of mind made it worth every penny!

Special Features: Car seat and suitcase sold separately
Review:
THIS WAS WORTH THE MONEY and less expensive than a dedicated car seat carrier and we didn't take a stroller.

We did not put our 2 yo in this while pulling. My husband used his Mission Critical carrier so that we didn't have to take Mini-Dragon in and out of the seat. This worked out b/c while I thought my bag was carry on size, the Southwest agent told me otherwise so we wound up checking our bag and the seat.
On the way from HOU (Hobby, Houston, TX) to CMH (Columbus, OH) the bag we strapped the carseat to was empty. My older son and I were able to squish the suitcase enough to TIGHTLY strap on the carseat.
Using the directions on the box it was super easy to put on and take off the carseat from the strap/around the suitcase.
On the reverse route we struggled to get the seat on since my In-Laws sent us home with a ton of gifts (hence the empty suitcase) and the bag was fluffy fat. I wound up swearing a few times and allowed the seat to be tipped slightly sideways since my husband again was carrying the little guy. THIS is where I wish we'd had the carabiner clips other reviewers mentioned. Even if you think you might not use them, on the off chance you do need them, keep them with the strap.
This product is ingenious and really helped us take along our own carseat and not play roulette with the rental system.

To store it, I just stuffed the strap into my carryon or the diaper bag.

TL; DR: Buy it, get some carabiners and possibly a carseat cover if you decide to check the seat. Works with carseat tightening strap completely loosened.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Weight Range of Child: 2 yo
Installation Type: strap, strap/around the suitcase, carseat tightening strap

Review: This car seat is a gorgeous design and works great in smaller cars, or if you need three seats across. It's well made, durable, and comfortable for the littles. This is really easy for switching from one car to another. Super adjustable as your child grows.

Review:
I don't have anything negative to say about this car seat.

1.) Small size
I purchased this car seat specifically, after hours of research, for its small size. I have a 2007 Subaru Impreza wagon; the back seat is not deep by any means, and in addition to that, there is really no leg room in the rear (I'm 5'8" and my husband is 6'). It is narrow and not deep at all. I was amazed at how much room I had in my car after it was installed.

2.) Using an infant seat in conjunction
With my first daughter, an infant car seat could only fit in the center seat, with both seats pushed up a few inches. We dealt with that with our daughter, however, we are expecting baby number 2! I needed a solution, otherwise I would have to trade in my car. There was no car seat that had the dimensions to be able to squeeze next to an infant car seat in the middle with the exception of this one. We could literally put 3 of these in our back seat with room to spare, which is incredible.

3.) Rear-facing recline degree/space
We have installed it behind the passenger seat as forward-facing (an infant car seat fitting perfectly beside it), however it would definitely fit rear-facing if we needed it to. If you're going to use it rear-facing, it does not recline NEAR as far back as I'm used to with other convertible car seats.

4.) Comfort/value/price
Besides the fact that it is downright adorable, I got it for $169.99 which is the cheapest I've seen the car seat on Amazon and Babies-R-Us and Target.com for months. I had to buy it then, especially with it being Prime eligible. It seems very comfortable and padded and the material looks durable. It is supposed to be incredibly easy to throw in the wash, which is why I didn't mind going with the light lime color.

5.) Installation
Installation was easy...says hubby. Very secure fit, which was hard to accomplish with the three other convertible car seats I've tried in my car. Instructions are easy to read and understand. I've heard if you have problems with it not fitting snugly, to try using a piece of pool noodle (or call Combi directly and they will ship you out something similar).

Overall, it seems to be a wonderful, thoughtful product at a great price. If I could afford to, I'd get two for each of our cars once baby #2 is born and out of infant seat!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear-facing, Forward-facing, Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 
Installation Type: 
Harness Type: 
Material: durable, easy to wash

Review: We purchased a Graco Cargo seat for my almost 4 year old son and hated it from the first moment - it never seemed secure in our Town and Country van and it was a pain in the butt to adjust the harness.  After reading lots of favorable reviews, we decided to go for the Nautilus and we're so glad we did.  It feels very secure in my van (we used the LATCH) and the harness is very easy to adjust.  The cup holder is actually useful - many other seats have it placed some place where my son couldn't even reach it.  There's plenty of padding around the head that allows for some comfort if our son falls asleep and there have been no complaints whatsoever of "pinching."  I LOVE the fact that the harness weight limit is so high and that it turns into a regular booster for down the road - we can feel good about this purchase because we will get years of use out of it. I will highly recommend it to my friends.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: harness is very easy to adjust
Installation Type: we used the LATCH
Weight Range of Child: harness weight limit is so high

Review:
Had the older version of this seat which looks similar however with a larger belt buckle. This new design has a very small buckle which is far more difficult to release and to top off the crotch protector is too large for it and interferes constantly whether putting in or removing the belts. Horrible design change. Otherwise a good seat but why did they change it for the worse? In the market for another seat and will now avoid buying this annoying seat altogether now.

Also noted that they finally test or claim they test their side impacts. Does not state the entire seat, just the side impact portion of it. I know Britax test the entire seat itself, something to consider, but at least they are headed in the right direction.

EDIT: Federal Investigation launched against this car seat for what is discussed above-latch issues AVOID!

Review: I cant imagine putting my son in this thing. First of all the front seat needed to be completely pushed up and reclined as far as it would go. This is a Ford F 150 SuperCrew. It has more backseat space than most SUVs, including a GMC Evnoy/Trailblazer and our Ford Edge. To even get it to recline to the proper angle, the instructions suggest using pool noodles. Tried 2, still not enough. Put two pieces of 1x6 underneath. Nope. Added pool noodles on top of that. Yep. Finally reclined to proper line. But now its so high up the latch belts wont reach! HA. And yes the seat is in the most reclinded position using the built in angle adjuster. Now let's just say sure, I'm going to trust the safety of my son to some 99cent pool noodles, now no one can sit in the front seat. This really could only be used front facing and even then it's a tight squeeze. My Graco infant carrier car seat fits great no problems. Guess well be using that till he grows out of it. Calling this thing in all in one was a lie, and is WAY overpriced to be a front facing booster.

Review:
We really liked this seat, at first. However, after some time using it we began experiencing a lot of difficulty tightening/securing our child into the seat. It would take so much strength to tighten it that we were afraid we were going to hurt our child, so we contacted the manufacturer who was fantastic and without hesitation, offered to replace the seat. Fast forward to now (about a year later with the new seat) and we've started having the issue again, only this time it seems much worse. We've removed the seat from our vehicle and brought inside and inspected it and found nothing wrong with it. As a trial, we put our daughter in the seat in the house and attempted to tighten and still, ot takes so much force to secure our child in the seat. We have noticed on the back of the seat the metal piece that holds the straps seems to be catching on some ridges on the underside of the seat. We have contacted the company again and are waiting to hear back.
Personally, we do NOT recommend this seat.

Update:
We've reached out to the company again in reguards to the issue we were having. They have offered us a replacement unit of an upgraded version of the seat which is the Grow n Go EX Air 3 in 1. Once we receive and us it for a bit I'll give an honest review of that seat.
To those saying that the customer service for Safety First is awful, I have to say they have been wonderful each time that I've contacted them.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: difficulty tightening/securing our child into the seat; takes so much strength to tighten; metal piece that holds the straps seems to be catching on some ridges on the underside of the seat

Review:
Jeep Wrangler 4 door owners beware. We love Britax car seats. Have had them for our older 2 children. With upcoming birth of our third we again decided to go with Britax. Me being the prepared person figured we should install car seat before baby arrival. Good thing we tried. If you own a Jeep Wrangler 4 door (ours is a 2015) you need to note this is NOT the infant car seat for you. The instructions clearly state the base of the car seat should not overhang the edge of the seat by more than 3 inches. Well - a jeep car seat is not as deep as most so the overhang is at least 5-6 inches. So sad we cannot use. We did try a Chicco Key Fit 30 - (Babies R Us will allow you to take the seats out of the store to try in your vehicle). That one will work as base is quite a few inches shorter than that of Britax and has an excellent safety rating and we can still fit the infant car seat, a Radian RXT in the middle and a Gracco backless booster behind driver safely.

Just hope to save someone the hassle of buying and having to return like we did as it was not something we would even think of until you actually read instructions.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: infant car seat
Installation Type: base of the car seat should not overhang the edge of the seat

Review:
I spent a lot of time researching and trying to decide what car seat to get once my baby outgrew his infant seat. Finally decided on this one, and I have not been disappointed! It was easy to install, fits well even in a car with a smaller back seat, the two cup holders are great for storing a sippy cup and toys, and I love how easy it is to adjust as the baby grows. Best of all, it's comfortable for him.

I did buy separate soft strap cushions for his neck because the ones it comes with are not great. It was a great call because I can actually loosen the straps to get him out while he's sleeping and remove him still asleep - small miracles!

Review:
We bought this car seat after being very happy with the Keyfit 30, which our daughter has outgrown. The Keyfit was easy to use, beautifully designed, and felt extremely safe. This one is a disaster - it is impossible to tighten the straps, leaving our child very vulnerable. I have tried repeatedly to contact Chicco support, but their customer support line has been closed every time I've called - they are only available for a few hours a day during the work-week, and never during evenings or weekends (which means, practically, that it isn't possible to reach them when I am near the car-seat.)

If I could send this thing back I would. Frankly, if my wife would let me throw it away I would - my daughter's safety is more important than the money we wasted on this piece of junk.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: impossible to tighten the straps

Special Features: Super Easy, Car Rental inflatable packable portable luggage travel
Review:
We needed a narrow booster seat to fit three across in our car. We use this for our eldest, who at 10 is about to graduate from boosters altogether. He began using it at about age 7. We don't need height from a booster for him, just the shoulder belt positioner. The seat belts in our backseat are really high, so he still needs that feature for now. I recommend this seat for older, bigger, mature kids who don't need seat height or a reminder to sit right, just a better fit to the lap and/or shoulder seat belts. It's also great for difficult three-across installations, travel, and carpools.

I think they may have fixed this since we bought ours, but we do find the lap belt guides tricky to thread. It took awhile before my son could do that part himself.

I also find the expiration date of four years to be on the low end for car seats. Then again, for the price, you get a lot of use out of it.

It's a very handy seat for travel, as we've recently found. You deflate it and toss it into whatever bag is handy — easy peasy. Blow it back up at your destination, and you're good to go. The only downside is how mucky the back of a seat gets in the car, and then you have to put your mouth on it, ha ha. This seat would also work well for carpool kids and ride-share travel and friends visiting and the like, assuming the users fit the size requirements. (With the 40-pound minimum, my skinny middle child at nearly 7 can still not use this seat.)

Comfort-wise, my son complained at the downgrade in comfort level from his previous Britax front-facing car seat. However, he stopped complaining after a few days, and he's been fine with the BubbleBum ever since. It doesn't have bells and whistles, such as arm rests or cupholders, which is what helps keep it narrow and easy to fit into a small space. My son's on the larger end of the percentile calculators for height and weight, and he does fine with it. I think his thighs spill over the sides a bit, but he doesn't seem to mind that. It's basically like sitting on a regular seat in the car with a tiny bit of air cushion. So it's not plush, but they'll be fine once they get used to it. My son's not prone to peer pressure around this issue, but I'll point out that it's a nice option for older kids who don't want an obvious booster but still need that belt positioning help.

All in all, the BubbleBum has worked nicely for us, and we'd get another one if our younger kid ever gets above 40 pounds!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster seat
Weight Range of Child: 40-pound minimum
Installation Type: seat belts, lap belt guides
Harness Type: shoulder belt positioner, belt positioning help
Material: air cushion

Review: This is an attractive car seat that feels sturdy and looks comfy for the little one. I purchased three, one for each vehicle, and ran into the same issue with each, needed a towel to balance the seat. In addition, it was not the easiest install as I literally had to stand up in my truck pulling the strap to tighten it. My wife is a pretty strong woman and she was not able to get it tight enough to avoid the seat wiggling. I would recommend this car seat but please be sure that it is balanced and tight, if you are concerned with the seat being too loose, take it to your local firehouse so they can properly install the seat. Safe driving to you and yours!
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: not the easiest install, had to stand up in my truck pulling the strap to tighten it, not able to get it tight enough to avoid the seat wiggling, if you are concerned with the seat being too loose, take it to your local firehouse so they can properly install the seat

Review:
Fits wonderful in our 2004 GMC Yukon Denali XL, and 2003 Dodge Ram 2300 Quad Cab.

We already had first generation Boulevards, which we loved (bought in May 2006). My sister recommended the Frontier 85, which she had bought. After reviewing everything I could get my hands on, we purchased 2 of the Frontier 85's (Cowmooflage and Pink Sky). Our daughter (4 years old, 42.5" and 40lbs) loves the color's and I find the fabric very nice, not too keen on the gray on the bottom of the Pink Sky though, the feel of the fabric isn't nice. At first they looked confusing to install, after reading the instructions twice, I had it in the Yukon in under 20 minutes, with my 4 year old's "help" and with the LATCH and tether. Car seat back is nice and tight to the truck seat, tether is nice and tight, that car seat is not going anywhere. Oh, and our Yukon has the captain's chairs NOT the bench.

The car seats were shipped separately and arrived 4 days apart, so this morning we moved the one in the Yukon to the Ram and put the new one in the Yukon. PIECE OF CAKE for the Ram, we can't use the tether due to the rear seat back not moving forward, but once the LATCH was tightened, that seat doesn't move an inch, and there is no gap between the bottom of the seat and the back of the trucks' seat. I installed the new seat in the Yukon next. Total time for both trucks 12 minutes.

I was hesitant on the single pull LATCH tightening, but I LOVE IT. I found it so much easier to get the seat tight, because you can't run out of strap to tighten, which was the problem I had with the Boulevard in the Yukon, I had it as tight as it would go, but is still had a little give. The new LATCH is completely locked down, and once you feed the tightening strap through the slip, you get the angle you were always trying to get on the dual strap models, and it just locks the seat in.

We found that even though this seat is bigger in size then the Boulevard, it fits better in the RAM. The back of the car seat doesn't rest against the back window like the Boulevard, there is actually a 2-3 inch clearance.

Our daughter loves the seats, they give her plenty of space, she loves the cup holders. We love the extra padding Britax put on these seat, the lighter weight, the 5 point harness up to 85lbs was a huge selling point for us, and all the safety features and standards that Britax is known for. We are looking forward to a long and happy relationship with our new Frontier 85's.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: up to 85lbs
Installation Type: LATCH and tether
Harness Type: 5 point harness

Review:
About me:
- I have owned this car seat for more than three years.
- Successfully installed rear and forward facing in:
- the center backseat of a 2008 Mitsubishi Spyder Eclipse Convertible
- all six rear positions of a 2009 Chevy Traverse
- all three positions of a 2011 GMC Terrain
- bucket seats of a 1997 Chevy Minivan
- DD is currently 3ft tall/30 lbs, and she still fits well in this seat!

Things I love:
- Color combos and fabric choices are awesome. Padding is easy to remove and washes well.
- Seat belt button is nice and stiff! Easy for adults, but my three year old has not figured out how to get out of this one.
- Easy to install and very light weight. No base to adjust. Easy to get proper horizontal line.
- Not tall or bulky, so you can see out the back window over the seat. If you're trying to fit three across, this is also a good choice. Nice and narrow.
- Child sits deep in the seat. I feel like this one provides a lot of side impact protection. Also, easier to keep a child rear facing, because their legs are not bunched up against the seat.
- Rated for rear tethering, which very few seats allow. This gives you better protection against rebounding in a crash.
Things that I don't love:
- Newborn padding puts newborns in an awkward position, significant recline compared to Britax Marathon and Combi Shuttle, head is pushed forward more than I would like.
- You have to overlap the two parts of the bottom clip and insert them together. My solution: always loosen the straps before buckling, then tighten back up with the pull strap. You'll get a better fit that way, anyways.

FYI:
- You cannot install this one using an inflatable seat belt. Although I don't see why you'd need to, since vehicles with the new seat belts are also new enough to have latch.
- The weight limit is 40lbs / height limit is 40". If you really think you'll leave your child in a convertible seat until they're in kindergarten or later, then you may want to invest in one that has a higher height limit (like a Radian). If you plan on buying a booster with a five point harness, then don't stress about it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing, Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 30 lbs, 40lbs, height limit is 40"
Installation Type: rear tethering, install using an inflatable seat belt, latch
Harness Type: bottom clip, straps, pull strap
Material: fabric, Padding

Review:
We bought this convertible car seat because our kids were getting too big for their older Graco car seats ( which by the way were really good).

- Very easy to fix and remove.
- Well padded; hence, very soft to touch.
- No sweat stains yet; maybe it's because I don't see them sweating much in it.
- Lightweight.
- Straps are comfortable and easy to click in and unstrap for adults but not for babies.
So these are all the plus.

The one con I found was that when my babies fall asleep in this rear facing positioned car seat, their head/neck seems very uncomfortable. They are not able to lean back while sleeping, and I hate it when I see their head dropping to their chest once they are asleep. If this car seat could be positioned such that it provides a comfortable sleeping position for little babies, that would be perfect.

Review:
I ordered Graco SnugRide for a baby shower present through a Target Gift Registry, processed through Amazon. It was shipped to me in the same thin single-ply cardboard box you buy it in stores. The box is very large and flimsy. It arrived with the box seriously dented on all sides, hardly worthy of presentation. But worse, when I opened it up, I found a 2 inch white stress line in the plastic, where apparently the beige plastic of the car seat (which seems fairly thin) was over stressed during shipping. The box had no padding inside whatsoever, the car set is simply wrapped in a plastic cover. I've done a lot of shipping, and I know you have to have 2 inches or more of padding on all sides, or double boxing, and a box this large should be double corrugated for strength.

It was convenient to be able to return the car set at a local Target store, but I was not refunded the shipping cost of $15, even though it was very clearly the faulty packaging by Amazon/Target that caused the unit to get damaged. I was also informed that Target does not carry the item in their stores, so it is only available through mail order. I'm going to try to find some other local seller.

The Super Saurus model in the Gift Registry that I ordered is apparently in the premium line of SnugRide car seats, having the "GracoPedic" foam padding for comfort (in addition to the EPS which is in all Snug Rides for safety). I wouldn't buy one of these without the GracoPedic foam. Baby should not be resting on the hard plastic (oh, well, maybe the plastic isn't that hard anyway). I think they should all come with the extra GracoPedic foam (though reportedly it doesn't hold up to washing), or at least it should be mentioned on the box. But it didn't mention the GracoPedic foam on the box, I only learned it from a review, and it is hard to tell otherwise.

For a top-rated product like this, I was not impressed by the thin plastic construction, which looks and feels cheap and flexible. more like a toy than a car safety device. And if you look at the 1-star reviews, these things can break in normal use, which I don't find reassuring. But I'm not sure what if anything is actually better than this from a safety perspective, as long as you replace it at the first sign of damage so it doesn't actually come apart in use.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Material: GracoPedic foam padding, EPS, thin plastic, beige plastic, plastic cover

She is only 2 years old and we realized that the next time she visits we will need to lengthen the harness to give her more room.  The click and release does not work.  We cannot lengthen the harness strap.  We have communicated with the company and they have not given us any information on how to clear the jam.  It appears the straps are inaccessible to the size of a hand.  Expensive car seat for not being able to use.  The company knows we have an issue but does not respond back.

Review: Overall we like the car seat. Installation was super complicated for us. I was disappointed that Diono doesn’t include a manual in the box. You follow minimal instructions on the car seat itself. Days later I found a QR code on the box that I can scan to open the manual online. Initially when installing no where told me to use the anchor that attaches to the top back part of the car seat... I had to do lots of video searching to finally find someone installing using that. Our car seat seemed like it wasn’t secure and I figured that was why but I couldn’t figure out how or where to attach the anchor. Lastly, when installed the car seat as it comes it takes so up much room. My husband has a full sized truck and I as the front passenger had to push the seat all the way to the dash and raise the back of the seat to more than 90 degrees for the car seat to fit behind me. We finally figured out(after much video searching) that you can purchase and angle adjuster that helped with this issue a lot. A little disappointed it wasn’t included initially. I can’t imagine what installation in a medium to small sized car would look like. Hope this helps.
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: Installation was super complicated; follow minimal instructions on the car seat itself; use the anchor that attaches to the top back part of the car seat; attach the anchor; purchase an angle adjuster

Review: While I'm satisfied with the construction and materials, this thing is a nightmare to install, maneuver, and wash. The belt slot is wide enough for maybe a puppet's arm, but if you have normal human hands expect a painful squeeze and scrapped up hands and arms just to get the buckle through. Even my teenage sister has trouble getting through with her bird arms - it's ridiculous! The strap system is difficult to get correctly adjusted. And the cover is a nightmare to get on and off!!! We switched from a Maxi Cosi infant seat that had a cover that popped off without even having to take the seat out of the car. This one not only requires you to remove the seat but to completely undo the straps, flip the seat upside down, and otherwise screw with it. So freaking unnecessary! And I can now look forward to an hour of reassembly, readjusting screwy straps, and scrapped up hands getting it back in the car. 3 stars because it fulfills it's basic purpose, but it's senselessly difficult and annoying.

Review:
I have used this strap on multiple trips overall rather easy to clip together, even considering the security obstacles, and problems with carry-on limitations on small planes. However, if they check your carry-on through to baggage claim because of a lack of storage space on the aircraft you will be carrying the carseat and loose toddler around the airport--yikes.

Here are my other downsides:

(1) It puts significant wear and tear on your baggage, especially if you try to push, rather than pull the bag. Baggage is not designed for this use. One of our baggage handles died this way. To be fair, it was already a pretty beaten up bag, but it is a consideration.

(2) Black is the worst possible color for this. It is easily lost among other toddler junk, and then you find yourself far from home with a carseat and toddler. We have had several near misses. Our strap is now covered with bright electrical tape.

In spite of the downsides, this is the best alternative. Checking a carseat is dangerous, and rental car carseats are not better. Plus, we like having the carseat on the plane, as [[ASIN:B0012E4FV8 CARES Child Aviation Restraint System]] does not restrain our toddler as well or provide as much comfort.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: carseat
Installation Type: strap, clip together

Review: I just got mine unstuck! I took the whole thing out of the car to do this, but the gal on the phone said in the car might be easier so you have some leverage... anyway. Hold the top of the seat at the recline lever with one hand (pulling the lever) and with the other hand hold the bottom of the front, as if you’re going to pick up the car seat. Lift and slam down quickly! (I put a foot on the base to hold it down) When I did it, I heard a kind of click and release and the seat rotated! Then immediately put it in the right position so you don’t get it stuck again :) Hope that helps!
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type

Review:
This seat seems to work well and my daughter likes it. I was worried she wouldn't sleep well in it on long car rides but she just leans her head against the side and doesn't seem to have a problem. It does have a strong chemical smell coming out of the box, so I would recommend airing it out before use.

Installation was fairly easy as carseats go. I did have to basically get in the seat to tighten the straps but that's par for the course. The latch connections are easier than the hook style so thats nice. I also had to remove the headrest in the back seat of my Ford edge because the back is so tall I couldn't get it to sit correctly without doing that. Haven't used it rear facing mode but it seems like you'd need a pretty big car because the seat is so tall.

Edit: I just installed a second seat in our Nissan Maxima and also had to remove the headrest as it won't fit when the seat is installed.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: latch connections are easier than the hook style; had to remove the headrest in the back seat of my Ford edge because the back is so tall I couldn't get it to sit correctly without doing that; installed a second seat in our Nissan Maxima and also had to remove the headrest as it won't fit when the seat is installed
Seat Type: Haven't used it rear facing mode but it seems like you'd need a pretty big car because the seat is so tall

Review:
We bought this car seat from a different source after finding a better sale price, but thought I would share my thoughts here.

Great, quality car seat that I felt met my high safety expectations, after a different high-end brand let me down (having had recalls regarding their China-made plastic and removal of their anti-rebound bar design in the new bases). I read many safety websites and comparisons regarding this car seat and other competitors', but seeing the actual results of the crash safety tests and the amount of G-Force transferred to the baby (this car seat rated among the best for dispersal of G-Force and impact energy) I felt happy going with it. The fabric looks like it will breath well and I'm impressed by the different inserts and quality of construction. The base is also narrower so it has a better fit if you want to try doing the three-across car seat setup in your truck or car. My husband loves that the seatbelt lockoff is a big panel that easily pushes down instead of those flimsy narrow lockoffs you see on other car seats. I love the European belt routing if you're installing without the base. Honestly, it's everything I've come to expect from a modern car seat.

Cons:
The shoulder pads - someone else mentioned that the velcro is sewn on the inside where the fabric meets the harness belts, and it is still this way with the one we purchased. It catches on EVERYTHING, including the harness belts themselves at times. We tried different dolls and stuffed animals in the car seat for fun, my children enjoy it, but I have to be careful they don't get caught by this velcro. I can foresee issues with this and will probably remove them and use a different brand or something. They are great material other than this one design flaw.

The canopy - it's a great UPF protected canopy made of breathable fabric, again quality materials. but it CLICKS loudly into place once fully extended, and I can see this startling a baby. Also, as many others have mentioned, the clearance for your hands is barely there while trying to carry. Honestly, I bought the car seat anyway knowing this and having seen it in many videos. I am not bothered by it as much because the car seat is so light and easy to handle that I don't need to do too much "manhandling." I'm sure my husband might disagree with his bigger hands, but we will see.

I'm happy I went with it, and look forward to lots of road trips! The car seat should last past baby's first year!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: seatbelt lockoff, European belt routing
Harness Type: shoulder pads, harness belts
Material: fabric, breathable fabric, quality materials

Review:
UPDATED NOV 2008
I have owned this car seat since March and have it installed with Latch long method since my daughter is still under 40 lbs (see manual) with the incline bar in place in the back of the seat. It is installed in a 2003 Honda Odyssey in the bucket seat behind the driver's seat.

I came home from shopping today to find my daughter in the seat and the end of one of the shoulder straps in her lap! Broken. I removed the seat from my car and upon turning it over found that the strap had completely frayed in the spot where it comes to end in the black metal clip underneath the seat. The elastic piece that holds the seat cover onto the seat has snapped in several places also. The other shoulder strap is about 50% frayed in its black metal clip. The seat elastic on that side looks undamaged.

I called Britax and was told that there is no recall on any of the Regents. They are sending me replacement straps and buckles free of charge. They were nice but did not seem concerned.

My daughter is only 38 pounds, so we have a long way to go to the 80 pound limit. I am of course disappointed and alarmed.

And now for the if's:
If the straps frayed once, what are the chances that the new ones will do the same? When I originally installed the seat I took it to the police station and they confirmed that the seat was installed properly. However, in looking at the seat in my living room, I am wondering if the seat itself was reclined too far, thus putting all of the weight of the seat onto the back where the straps are and not on the seat bottom and causing the damage. If that is the case I feel like there is a design flaw, considering that I did have the incline bar installed.

I am just left wondering, what happened?! I feel like I wasted $200, and am trying to decide whether to purchase something else altogether or try installing this seat differently when I receive the replacement parts... I was really hoping that this seat would be the one that would last until we didn't need any type of seat anymore, as I prefer the 5 point harness over the shoulder/lap belt on a regular booster. If you own this seat, PLEASE check it to make sure your straps are still intact.

Original Review
We purchased this seat for our three year old and gave the Roundabout to her infant brother. The seat is very roomy, and has lots of positions to adjust the straps. The straps have extra cushions on them and they don't tangle. The seat is huge, but since it's in a minivan in a single bucket seat it fits pretty well. Because the seat is so large I do worry that as my daughter's legs get longer she's going to be somewhat crunched; she sits behind the driver's seat, and I can only move my seat so far forward to give her room. The seat was easy to install with LATCH.

The reason I am only giving the seat four stars is because even though the five point harness can be used up to 80 lbs, the seat is only supposed to be installed with LATCH up to 50 lbs. This is per the manual that comes with the seat. After that the seat is supposed to be installed with a regular seatbelt. The whole reason I wanted this seat is because it went up to 80 with the 5 point harness, and I thought that was using LATCH the whole time; I would have liked to know that it only went up to 50 with LATCH before I bought it. I just wonder how much safer it is having a seat with the five point harness when it's only installed with the seatbelt.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: 38 pounds, 80 pound limit
Installation Type: Latch, seatbelt
Harness Type: 5 point harness
Material: straps, elastic, seat cover

Review:
Here's a quick breakdown on the pro's and con's of this seat and some simple tips on adjusting the seat.

Quick adjustment overview.

TILT adjustment: Under the front strap is a lever you pull towards you and allows you to tilt the seat to desired angle.

STRAP adjustment: To tighten PULL the front strap. to loosen push on the button hidden where the strap drops into the cushion and pull the shoulders straps at the same time.

HEIGHT: Pull the tap at the top of the seat while pushing down or pulling up on the head restraint foam part of the seat to set desired height.

PROs:

-same controls as our 4-35 Viaggio Enfant Seat so it's very easy to use if you have other Peg Perego seats
-high quality italian made cushions and fabrics
-compact size and easy to use controls
-easy to use seatbelt and tether system
-has front tether which most seats don't
-has a holder for the instruction manual so you never loose it
-tons of angle flexibility and easy to adjust

CONs:

-Manufacturer suggested 7 year life limit. My opinion is you could use the seat longer if you maintain it's condition and adhere to current child seat laws.
-instruction manual is very complex and quite thick.
-seatbelt cushions are too thick for small infants

I installed the seat in a FORD F-350 Superduty for comparison using the seatbelt as those trucks do not have latch system. I included a picture of the seat compared to a Viaggio 4-35 for comparison.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: 
Installation Type: seatbelt, tether system, front tether, latch system
Harness Type: 
Material: cushions, fabrics

Review: Was very excited at first when I got this in the mail.... then the baby came and it was time to take her home. After an hour of multiple people and nurses trying to get her in without the bottom part squeezing and scratching her legs, we ended up taking out the newborn insert (baby left the hospital at 5 pounds and didn’t fit in the newborn insert?) and put a blanket under so her the buckle stopped pinching and scratching her little legs. It felt so unsafe and hurt my heart to put her in the car that car seat even tho everyone in the hospital said she was ok. We went home and we tried to mess with it more, we looked in line and saw the same complaints About the buckle! Do not buy... I got it because I wanted the jogger to connect.. also you have to connect the two prongs together before inserting it into the buckle.... who ever designed that didn’t not work with a newborn that loves to kick around.... went with an even flow safe max car seat instead.... spend the extra money please.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Weight Range of Child: 5 pounds
Harness Type: buckle, two prongs

Review: Love how easy this is to install and adjust.  We use this as an extra car seat for Grandma and Grandpa.  They need to be able to adjust the seat to different kiddos (there are more grandkids) and they love that they can just do it quickly by pulling up or pushing down on the back handle.  The instructions are printed right on the outside of the seat too, so they don't have to try to find the owner's manual every time they have to adjust.  As someone who has threaded belts in and out of seats like the Diono multiple times, I can say I never want to do that again.  The two cup holders are nice for the kiddos, so they can store juice and snacks, and the fabric cleans up nicely.  Great seat!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: easy to install
Harness Type: adjust the seat to different kiddos, adjust quickly by pulling up or pushing down on the back handle

Review: I am very happy with this carseat purchase for my two year old daughter to replace a Graco carseat that was a hand-me-down. The Graco was over six years old, so I felt that it was not up-to-date with the most current safety standards. I watched the Britax movie clip on it's safety features and was very impressed. This is very sturdy! Much more sturdy than the Graco one that we had.  It just looks safer.  For example, there are sides to the car seat to protect the side of your child's head... which our Graco one did not have. This car seast just seems very safe. I also like the fact that it is made in the US. This is my first Britax purchase, and I am so happy that for future children, I plan to stay with the Britax brand. I know understand why this brand is much more expensive than other brands. I've seen cheaper car seats... but the plastic is thin and wobbly. Like I said, if you shake this car seat around in the store, the plastic seems more thick/solid/sturdy than other brands.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing
Material: plastic

Review: I have both this carrier and the smaller, lighter Wipha carrier. This model definitely feels like an upgrade and a more premium product, but you do pay for it in weight. At 6lbs though this is still very reasonable and feels a lot lighter than my backpacking pack. This baby carrier is super comfortable and has plenty of adjustments if you plan to share it with someone of different heights. There's lots of storage space to bring your stuff along with the items you need for your little one. It's really easy to get this pack on and off and it sets down on the bar without an issue, which works out great for a quick nap! Everything about this carrier feels like a premium product and I enjoyed using it to get the kids outdoors. The mustard color is great too!

Review:
I purchased two of these from Albee Baby and we love them! First off Albee Baby has very fast shipping!

I have a two year old son and he needed a few more car seats because I was tired of installing my Britax marathon in different cars every few days. I bought two gracos so my husband and I each have one in our cars and that way the marathon can stay in grandma's car because it so easy to buckle him properly for her hands.

I like everything about these seats! They installed with latch super easy and the install is so tight, it's as if it was built into my cars.

I love the fit. My son fits so comfortable in these seats and with the recline feature, plus the natural recline of my back seats it makes naps comfortable for him.

Right now he is on the lowest setting and middle crotch buckle slot. I like that there are 3 crotch slots it will make extended harnessing longer easier as he grows.

I also love the 10 year expiration(from the date of manufacture). That truly means this seat will last him until he no longer needs a seat, so now I Will just have to replace the britax marathon when he outgrows it.

I do love the no rethread harness feature as well, it makes it so much easier not having to take the seat out(which is what I love about my britax.

I don't know what some reviews are talking about when they say they can't get the straps tight enough and that it's hard to adjust the straps. On both of our seats it's super easy. Actually it easier to adjust these straps then on my britax.

My son loves his new seats!

I would recommend these and I love our new seats! I'm glad I opted for two of these instead of the britax frontier.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Installation Type: latch
Harness Type: no rethread harness, 3 crotch slots

Review:
This is my first Diono. I’ve always used chicco car seats with my kids, but after researching this company and having the opportunity to try this car seat out for free I jumped at the chance.

I love that Diono is a US based company, and one that works prioritizes safety. Like I’ve said I’ve always used chicco, and while I’ve had no complaints about their car seats I do feel like Diono is a step up, though the prices are fairly comparable.

First impressions of the Radian 3RXT….. WOW! It was packaged nicely. And the instruction booklet has a handy little pocket on the side for storage! I know that doesn’t seem like a big deal, but when you’re transitioning the car seat with your growing child and you can’t remember what’s what because you can’t find the booklet, this will be so nice.

Loved the bright red color. The fabric is very nice, quality stitching. Chest straps are cushioned well and have sort of an anti-slip texture on the back side. That comes in super handy for us parents with those kids that love to adjust their own straps when they shouldn’t!

It folds for travel, although you might rethink that because this thing is BEAST! It is heavy! I’ve lugged caresses through the airport before, but I’m not sure I’d recommend this one for travel.

It also has a nice memory foam cushion in the seat.

Now as far as using the seat, I don’t have much input on the infant or reverse stages. I used it for a few months in the forward facing five point harness stage. And currently using the high back booster. I felt comfortable with my daughter’s safety in both stages. It was just as easy to install as our chicco.

Initially I was not a fan of the seat belt placement of the chest strap. On our other booster there is a plastic holder that you slide the belt into and with the Diono you just slide it beside the headrest. It just seemed a little awkward for placement, but it’s worked fine and I used to it now.

I love the slim design. I always have two car seats in my vehicle and it can be difficult squeezing between them, when you need that third seat. I wish my other car seat was like this one! And even though it’s slimmer, my little still had plenty of seat room.

It took my a second to figure out the cup holder! Just shove it in there and turn! Again another thing that initially threw me, but now it makes so much more sense!

And with the 120 lb weight maximum, I don’t anticipate ever having to buy another car seat!

Overall, I’m really impressed. This is definitely a car seat company I’ll be recommending in the future.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: forward facing five point harness stage, high back booster
Weight Range of Child: 120 lb weight maximum
Installation Type: easy to install
Harness Type: five point harness, chest strap
Material: fabric, memory foam cushion

Review:
There is so much about this car seat that makes it awesome! The way this is designed makes me think they actually asked people what they don’t like about car seats and didn’t do that.

Starting at the base, I LOVE that it has a flat bottom so that it doesn’t make weird indentions in
my seat. The push button quick connects on this seat make it amazingly easy to take this seat in and out if needed quickly. The arm rests on this seat are low enough not to get in the way when getting the little on into the car and are still useful to her as well. I really like the way the extra headrest fits securely and seemingly comfortable. Best of all though every adjustment is done with a single button press, with the exception of the straps in the bottom part of the seat, but were very easy to adjust as well. Overall, I couldn’t be happier with this purchase. It’s clear that this chair meets and exceeds all safety requirements without breaking the bank. GREAT BUY!
