Review: This car seat was very easy to install (compared to our old one), and it fit without problem in our 2013 CR-V, which had a smallish back seat. There are a lot of built-in features that make it so easy to install correctly. For a while the harness would dig into our son's neck when putting him in, which caused a lot of discomfort for him, but we figured out that if you only snap the chest clip in once until you're done tightening the harness, then snap the chest clip in the second time, it doesn't dig into his neck. Everyone's happy!

I'll Update later..

Update: 04/04/2016
Visor kept coming apart & minnie headrest was useless. I took them both out.
I could not find an expiration date on car seat, only that it was made in 2015.
Our lil girl was 6lb 5oz, is 10 days old & car seat has been working perfectly.
Only thing i needed to buy for it was a sun & bug cover & a head positioner support..

2nd UPDATE: 06/22/2016
Our lil girl is now 3 months old and i'm starting to feel the handle has flex now when i carry her.
I don't like that. The heavier she gets the more i notice it. I feel she's secure when strapped in.
Base doesn't sit level in our jeep with her brothers car seat next to it, it has give & no matter how i tighten it it's still doing it :-(
I'm considering going with another brand. I liked this pattern but safety is more important. only plus is that it did fit in our sons stroller.. so we didn't need anything special for that at least.

Review: I don't usually write reviews but seeing as I hadn't been sure about this product because of how expensive it was and because of the accident I just got into, I felt like I must. It totally is worth every penny; I was hit by a driver, that I was told was by witnesses was driving recklessly (which I wish on no one! I had never felt such fear for my child) they hit my car twice causing me to spin completely around and ending up in the center island. I jumped out to run to my 17 month old who was screaming her head off. I am so grateful that the car seat kept her safe and no harm had come to her! So I highly recommend this car seat not to mention its easy to install and the fabric is easy to clean. Also really like the recline options.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: easy to install
Material: fabric is easy to clean

Review: In case it's helpful for any shoppers to know-- we were unable to get this seat secure enough in a Rear Facing position in our 2005 Ford Escape w/ leather seats. We tried every tip and trick. Even had a car seat tech try to help. No luck. We used the seat once our son was big enough to face forward, and it works great that way. We really like the car seat, but just bummed it wouldn't work rear facing with our Escape.
Attribute_Related_Content: Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing

Review:
I have to give this car seat props. A few weeks ago, we had a front-end impact with an oncoming car. The air bag deployed, my glasses flew off, my four year-old son's iPad flew out of his hand along with his drink, I saw stars and burned my hand, and the car was totaled.

After prying myself out of the car, I ran around the car to get him out of his back seat. I found him perfectly okay. This car seat did a GREAT job, and I'm just so thankful that we walked away from the wreck.

So my only review is reporting the aftermath of an accident that showed the effectiveness of this car seat. The five-point restraint is a real plus, and I'd urge everyone to use car seats with this restraint, regardless of the seat you purchase. It spreads out the energy across the front of the body rather than concentrating it on focused points, which could result in fractures or internal injuries. I had bad clavicle pain from my seatbelt, but my son was fine.

Five stars!
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: five-point restraint

Review:
I haven't purchased this car seat but I couldn't help myself while reading one particular review. To the smart person (or anyone that doesn't know) that says the car seat is terribly made because it can't fit on top of the shopping cart, you need to do some research for the sake of your child!

CAR SEATS DO NOT BELONG ON TOP OF THE SHOPPING CART, IT IS VERY DANGEROUS TO DO SO!!!! PUTTING THE BABY IN THE BODY OF THE CART IS THE SAFEST OPTION. DONT LIKE THAT OPTION, INVEST IN A BABY CARRIER.
Attribute_Related_Content: No

One thing I wish the slim fit did was make a little more leg room for rear facing but in all honesty that’s all car seats nowadays since babes have to be rear facing until 2! If it ad the extend to fit for the legs I’d love it even more!

Review: Love this car seat! It's sturdy, safe and durable. Our friends went through several models throughout the years; our Diono outlasted all of them. Best baby purchase! Our two boys are now 5 and 9 and still fit in their car seats quite comfortably.

Review:
It's a good car seat but "slim" is definitely misleading. Looking at it, the only slim feature would be the cup holders but the carseat itself is very long when positioned for rear facing. There's a level on the side that helps you get it oriented correctly but I have to move the front seat all the way forward to get it set right, eliminating the front seat for anyone else. Definitely couldn't put it behind the driver. If you have a center seat in the back, that might work but I drive a van so no help there.

Other than that, the car seat is everything to expect from graco as far as quality and I definitely love the self adjusting shoulder straps. No more having to take the whole thing out to adjust strap height, just adjust the headrest up and your golden.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: (implied by positioning/orientation details)

Review:
Other things we love about it:
-Easy-adjust angle with TEN settings-makes it a snap to get the right pitch for your toddler’s neck and the right level for safety.
-One-handed easy adjust height (no belt rethread).
-Super easy install means we only had to buy 1 seat for all 3 cars, making it even cheaper than the 3 extended fit Evenflo Titansu we got 5 years ago for our then 1-year-old ($100 each).

Cons: it’s so wide compared to our Even-Flo Titans that it doesn’t fit next to her sib in our car like they prefer; they have to be on opposite sides. The built-in cup holders don’t help with that.
It’s also super heavy (30lbs), whereas the Evenflo is only 10!

It’s a hard choice for travelers on a budget: take one that’s easy to fit anywhere and super light to tote around, or one that’s super easy to move between Ubers.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Installation Type: Super easy install
Material: Super heavy (30lbs)

Review: This is second seat I have purchased.  The built in cup holder and snack/toy holders are awesome.  My only complaint is that neither my 6 year old or 4 year old can undo the bottom buckles.  On the upside they were never able to learn to unbuckle themselves when they shouldn't.  I love this seat.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: neither my 6 year old or 4 year old can undo the bottom buckles

Review: We got a few Car seats and this was the most expensive and looking back not worth that.  I love how it looks, but it is hard to take in and out of the car and the straps ALWAYS get tangled.  It is very hard to get them back in the right position especially while the seat is facing backwards.  Would not recommend spending the extra money!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: facing backwards
Harness Type: straps

Review:
I purchased this seat in Fall 2012 and it now comes with a rear-facing tether strap and instructions on how to use it in the manual. I'm able to get it very secure rear-facing, in the center seat of my Honda Civic, with no pool noodle, and room for 2 passengers. Driver and front passenger seats can still go back because the seat is narrow. I love this seat, the only con for us is that it's not too tall, so my tall son will likely outgrow it in height before he reaches the rear-facing weight limit, but I think he'll still be able to use this rear-facing until at least age 2. Installation is a snap with the seat belt and the seat is very comfortable, apparently. My son falls asleep in here all the time, even on 5-minute car rides :)

We purchased an infant car seat when he was born, the Chicco key fit 30, because other parents told me I'd want to be able to remove him from the car in the seat while he was asleep. I guess that was convenient for the first 3-4 months, as sometimes he would continue his nap in the car seat once we got home, or sleep in the car seat in a restaurant, etc. However, the key fit 30 is wide because of the handle, and did not fit nearly as well in my 2007 civic. It was do-able, but the front seats couldn't go back very far, which was an issue for my 6'4" husband. Plus, the key fit is a small seat - my son has outgrown it in height and he's only 11 months and 22 pounds (he has a huge head, though, so most won't have this problem, LOL). And, once your baby weighs over 15 pounds, you're not going to want to carry them in an infant carrier. I don't care how strong you are, it's just not ergonomic.

So, if you're looking for a great car seat that's smaller, but still very safe and well-made, consider just getting this one, you'll save yourself money and I don't think infant seats are really worth it. If and when we have another kid, I'll be using this seat from the start.

A couple other minor points - the seat is really soft/padded - this is a plus. It has a nice cushion over the crotch strap, which I like for my little dude :) The crotch strap releases by pressing on the top, which I like now, but might be an issue if my son decides he wants to escape some day. We have another seat that requires you to press a button inward to release the straps - this requires you to put a finger behind it to get some leverage, which is awkward. I don't mind the puzzle fit of the strap latch - you get used to it fast. It's really easy to tighten the straps. It's also easy to remove the cover to clean it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear-facing
Weight Range of Child: rear-facing weight limit
Installation Type: seat belt
Material: soft/padded, cushion over the crotch strap, easy to remove the cover to clean it

Review: Perfect. Can't go wrong with Britax. My baby falls asleep in this seat all the time so it must be comfortable and I know it's safe because I trust this brand. The black and design is a great unisex choice. Easy to install. I'm just going to be sad when my baby out grows this !

We never had that with the last one. We are going to ask a car seat tech soon about it.

Seat Type: infant seat

Review:
This car seat is a beast to install rear facing. We purchased it to replace the Graco Click Connect infant seat, because our 13 month old son had reached the height limit on it. My husband and I tried to install it in the backseat of my four door Honda Civic one night after putting our son to bed. We read the directions and used a rolled up towel to try and get the right level on the seats. My car has the latch system, but we just couldn't get the strap to pull tightly enough to keep the seat from wiggling significantly. After almost an hour, we gave up and put his old seat base back in. My husband called one of his friends (with two kids a bit older than ours, so he's an experienced car seat installer) to come over the next night. It took too grown men about half an hour of tugging, pulling and pushing to finally get the seat installed tight enough for us to feel our son would be safe sitting in it.

Also, once installed rear facing the seat's tilt can't be adjusted, so make sure you have it set to the recline level you want before installing it rear facing. I wouldn't recommend this for an infant, because I don't think it reclines enough for a baby that can't support it's own head, even with the insert. (Unless you have miraculously flat back seats.) We have it on the most reclined position, but even with a towel the tilt of my rear seats makes it so that it's sitting almost upright. Once installed, I've had no problems with the seat. It's very easy to adjust the height of the shoulder straps and to tighten and loosen the straps. Also, this seat allows the front passenger seat to go back farther than our previous infant car seat. I'd recommend getting a seat cover, to protect against any puking, accidents, or food spills, because trying to clean the seat itself is a nightmare. I look forward to when my son is old enough to sit forward facing, because I think this will make a much better forward facing seat than rear facing.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: 13 month old, height limit
Installation Type: latch system
Harness Type: shoulder straps

Review: We purchased the Britax Frontier booster car seat 2 years ago for our children who were 5 and 3 at the time.  I picked the Britax Frontier because it covers such a wide range of height and weight.  I thought it would be the car seat that would take them until the end of needing car seats.  I was wrong.  My children are small for their ages (now 7 and 5) with neither of them weighing 40 lbs yet.  They still cannot do the buckles on the 5 point harness themselves.  I find it annoying that I have to unbuckle my 7 year old because the buckle is too difficult for her to undo.  Sometimes I even have difficulty with the buckles.  This is our 3rd version of Britax car seats and this seems to be a very common problem with them.  Plus the fabric is terrible.  We have the red/black seat and it was stained within the first month of use.  Plus when washed it piled and looked even worse.  It is not worth the amount of money you pay for this seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster car seat
Weight Range of Child: wide range of height and weight, neither of them weighing 40 lbs yet
Harness Type: 5 point harness
Material: fabric is terrible, red/black seat, stained, when washed it piled and looked even worse

Review:
As soon as my daughter was able to, she started complaining that the seat was uncomfortable. Taking off the bottom cover, it was obvious why: the piece of foam on the seat is 2-3" too short! It slides to the back, and the child's legs end up resting on the hard, sharp plastic edge in the front. The result is a whiny, unhappy kid in the car on trips longer than, say, 20 minutes - and you won't know why until the kid becomes old enough to understand and communicate it.

I ended up spending an extra $20 online to buy a replacement piece of foam and cutting it to shape myself.

Review:
After much research and reading of reviews, I purchased this carseat when my son was about to outgrow his infant seat. Boy did i make the right choice!! The easy adjusting nobs on the sides that tighten the harness straps are SUPER!! SO many people have commented on how neat and easy and QUICK it is to tighten down the straps to a perfect fit. Plus, it's almost as easy to loosen the straps when taking out your child. One thing i was pleasantly suprised about was the amount of padding/cushion. Other brands like Cosco, have very hard seat bottoms...not this one! It's a close second to Saftey 1st seats i've found. The cover comes off easily for washing, the headrest easily adjusts and does help a bit in keeping my sons head from flopping all over. You can easily slide the harness straps up with a simple tug as your child grows.
A person can look and look and still not find the "perfect" car seat, but I think this one is close. I call it our deluxe, BMW car seat :) Very pleased and i think you will be also.

Review:
I purchased the updated Britax Boulevard (ClickTight) about a year ago after owning two previous versions of the Britax Boulevard 70 (about 3 years old). Based on the pictures I see on Amazon, my older version is similar to the Britax Boulevard G4 and not the 'new' ClickTight version which was not available 3 years ago. In my opinion, this is a case where newer is not better.

I believe that this new version has a number of serious flaws as I will describe below, the biggest of which is the ClickTight feature. If you try to install the seat tightly (which is a fundamental goal when installing a car seat), you will find that, because of the way the ClickTight feature works, it is possible to lock the seat in so tightly that it cannot easily be uninstalled -- while I understand that is in part by design, it is very difficult to predict how loosely you have to install the seat in order for the tightness to be appropriate. To uninstall the seat, you are forced to turn a small disk using your fingers in a way that you cannot generate sufficent leverage if you install the seat too tightly (which, as I mention, is part of the goal), and I ultimately had to use a vise grip just to uninstall the seat, causing damage to the car seat. Prior to my involvement in installing the seat, my wife was completely unable to remove the seat as she could not turn the ClickTight disc at all. I have installed/uninstalled this seat several times, and the difficulty of unlatching and removing the seat has been an issue nearly every time.

The seat is also unnecessarily difficult to install, particularly in comparison to our prior Boulevard but also compared to other model car seats that we have used. If you are used to having easy-on/off LATCH connectors (that's language from the description of the Boulevard G4, which has such easy to use connectors like most other carseats), forget about it here -- the Boulevard ClickTight has metal anchors which are both difficult to install and difficult to remove, forcing you to put pressure on the latch to hold it open while trying to latch blindly to the LATCH tethers. Depending on your car, this could be a very difficult task.

The ClickTight harness only allows certain degrees of snugness, often resulting in the harness feeling too tight or too loose. I am used to pulling the harness strap tightly enough so that it feels snug but not so tightly that you feel like you're squeezing the air out of your child; with the new ClickTight harness, I find that, depending on how my child is dressed, I am either harnessing too tightly or too loosely, and rarely at the level of snugness and comfort that I can achieve with my other car seats. I am not confident that the seat is sufficiently snug because there are only certain predefined levels of tightness.

Once harnessed in, the release button is buried in a hold between your childs legs. If you don't have particularly long fingers or are wearing gloves, you will likely find it difficult to conveniently push the button such that it releases the harness. Keep in mind that you have to apply pressure to the button in the hole while at the same time pulling the straps forward in order to release them; it's not an impossible task, just made more difficult by Britax's design decision to put the button in a hole. On the plus side, as I've discovered, the hole is a great place to store lost crumbs, cereal, dust, lint, etc. (I'm kidding of course, it's just a terrible design).

I can't speak to issues like length of strap or buckle discomfort as mentioned by other reviewers as the child who sits in this seat is not old enough where these are an issue. Once you get past the ClickTight issue and are able to unlatch the seat, it is just as easy to uninstall as other seats I have used, though it is more difficult to install than any other seat I have used largely due to the type of anchors used. As it's too late for me to return this seat, I've finally made the decision to put the seat in the dumpster, it's just not worth the frustration -- I would not recommend that anyone buy or use this car seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: Clicktight, Latch
Harness Type: ClickTight harness

Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: Installation isn’t terrible but it can be hard to get the seatbelt across.

Review:
We bought a Radian RXT in 2018 for our second child and loved it. It is easily the most secure car seat I have ever strapped my kid into, and we have owned a lot of Graco and installed in several different models and types of car. Also the easiest install, I've fought for more than 30 minutes in my mom's Ford Explorer with Graco and wanted to set the car on fire afterward for her making me move it over in 105 degree Texas weather. It is heavy, but I install mine and won't move it for any force in heaven or hell unless I am flying, so its not like I do a daily ruck march with it.

Unfortunately, Diono is charging the same price they did for once a premium fabric car seat cover and giving you a crappy, thin car seat cover. Just feeling the difference between the two year models, you can tell they downgraded for the 3RXT severely since putting out the RXT. It has less padding, it is much thinner and I don't see how it isn't going to pill in the wash. My kid is going to destroy it.

I've included pics of old versus new for reference, but most of it is in the "feel".

I find this very disappointing, because you want a quality fabric in a "upper trim" series car seat that is supposed to last 10 years and costs $300. It's the same cheap, slick microfiber that I have on a couple of wal-mart $30 booster seats, or on universal car covers. I imagine it will turn green/gray in the sun just like those did. My Radian RXT is the same color it was when I bought it and even at two years older, looks better and its been washed a zillion times.

At first, I thought they sent me a car seat with the wrong cover, because it says "Radian R" and my RXT was embroidered on, not stamped on the fabric like this one. It also shows on the box as "Radian RXT", so I think my confusion is reasonable. Then I looked at the pictures on their website and Amazon. Nope. They are all universally the same crappy fabric across the entire Radian series.

Shame on you, Diono, car seats are expensive enough when you have to replace them constantly as you have kids, or have more than one so you aren't dealing with the logistics of switching cars with your spouse or parents just to get kids from point A to point B. And parents could easily save themselves $100 or $200 by buying something a little less "premium".

Removing a star for the cheapness, because seeing it there makes me wonder if they are as "premium and innovative" as Diono claims. Companies that do things well would do well to do it across the board, especially if they want repeat business. I came back because I loved the RTX so much. Not sure if I needed another one that I would come back for a "4RTX" or whatever comes next unless they go back to better covers.

For reference, these install amazingly well in Toyota Corolla, Sienna and Highlander and even the tiny Prius, but rear face in a Prius puts the front seat up too far for anyone over 5'6 to sit comfortably (basically every adult in our family). It will install in a Ford Explorer, but you will still be angry if its leather, cause they really didn't want anyone to get anywhere near their latch to actually use them and they are set too close together, so actually cranking down and getting the seat tight enough is a hassle, but easier than installing a Graco carrier or convertible car seat. Don't let an entertainment package on a Ford Explorer fool you, not a young family with car seats car. :p
Attribute_Related_Content:
Material: crappy, thin car seat cover; less padding, much thinner; cheap, slick microfiber; same cheap, slick microfiber that I have on a couple of wal-mart $30 booster seats, or on universal car covers; same crappy fabric across the entire Radian series; better covers

Installation Type: easiest install; install amazingly well in Toyota Corolla, Sienna and Highlander and even the tiny Prius; install in a Ford Explorer; latch; cranking down and getting the seat tight enough

Seat Type: rear face in a Prius

Review:
Warning ⚠️
Ease of installation should never out weight the safety of your child(red)’s safety. We were picking up grandchildren and were giving the Mifold booster seats to use. We were less than an hour on the road when our children had fallen asleep- now slumped over in their seats and no longer safely restrained in their booster seats caused great alarm. ( both seats were properly installed per manufacture’s Instructions/and video)
Had we been in an accident both children could have been ejected from the vehicle or at the very least sustained injuries from not being properly restrained.
At best, the mifold is a portable seatbelt adjustment for the car. The company itself reminds parents to have the child seat properly in the seat at ALL times to Add void Abdominal injuries from him proper placement of the seatbelt. Ask yourself, do 5 year olds always seat perfectly still in the backseat, never reach for a fallen toy?

Review:
At first I thought this is a good seat. Now that my baby is 5 months I wish I would have chosen a different carrier/seat. The two big cons for me are that the canopy is too short and lets too much sun in and that my baby has a soaking wet back every time I take him out of the seat. This is very unfortunate and I assume that the fabric is cheap. The carrier is fairly heavy and doesn't quiet fit all that well with the stroller base I chose.

If I had to do it all over again, I would probably choose a convertible seat right away and go with a Maxi-Cosi. If I would choose an infant carrier seat again I would also go with a different brand that doesn't get so hot. The baby sits in it very deep and it seems to be uncomfortable. Wish I had known this before.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Material: fabric is cheap, gets so hot, baby has a soaking wet back every time
Seat Type: infant carrier seat

Special Features: Car seat and suitcase sold separately
Review: Unfortunately this didn't work for our carry-on, the car seat (Britax) kept slipping down and dragging on the ground. I think that this might work if you really make sure that your carry-on is full and that the wheels are high enough off of the ground.  Test it at home first with baby in it!
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Review:
We got this seat for an amazing price through Amazon's lightning deals. We had been eyeing it for a long time and when we saw it on a lightning deal we finally snagged it up.

We were very happy with it at first, before we actually used it. We got our baby in and out of it easily while it was inside our house, but once it was in the car it was a whole other story.

(1) This seat is huge. We have a Nissan Rogue, and with the carseat in the second position rear facing it was touching the back of the front seats. It's also very wide. The base is narrow, but it fans out wider at the seat area and it literally made it so I couldn't sit in the back with my baby anymore when we had her in the middle.
(2) It is so difficult to tighten the harness! Way, way too difficult. We pride ourselves on proper car seat safety, so I am never willing to compromise when it comes to how tight a harness is or where the chest clip rests. When this seat was not in the car, we didn't have any issues getting it tight enough, but for some reason when it was in the car it was nearly impossible to get it right. I would literally spend 2 or 3 minutes tugging on it, trying to tighten it. Very frustrating.
(3) Installation is a joke. I have never had such trouble installing a carseat before. The path for the seat belt is awful -- it took both my husband and me to get it through the path. We ultimately decided on using the lower anchors, but were really disappointed that we couldn't get the seat belt install tight enough.

My baby (8 months) did enjoy sitting in it, which is why I'm not giving this 1 star. We knew she was getting fed up with not being able to see much while in the car, so we switched from her infant seat to a convertible. She looked comfortable in it and she was super happy the whole time.

We ended up returning this carseat, which is a bummer because, like I said, we got an amazing deal on it. I read the majority of the reviews before we bought it, so I'm really disappointed that it didn't work out for us because it is so highly rated. We switched to the Britax Boulevard Clicktight -- much more expensive, but we tested it out in our car at one of the baby stores, and it is a dream to use, especially in comparison to this one.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Harness Type: difficult to tighten
Installation Type: lower anchors, seat belt

Review:
I currently own this car seat and the Diono Rainier.
This car seat far surpasses the Rainier in ways of space and ease of install. I currently drive a Honda Fit and the Rainier does not fit without buying an angle adjuster and even then it is a tight squeeze. I now switched the Rainier to our second car (that rarely takes the kids) and the Extend2Fit is our "daily driver". The Extend2Fit still has my 40lb, 2 1/2 yo son rear-facing without any issue or complaint. I will be using this car seat until he meets the limits of rear-facing or when my 2-month-old grows out of her Graco infant seat; whichever comes first.

Review: Overall, this is a good carseat.  While it has a fairly narrow base (which allows it to fit three across in an mid-size SUV like a Durango) it is somewhat long, especially when rear facing.  That means that the person in the seat in front of this carseat cannot be more than average height.  Having said that, this carseat is extremely sturdy, and very solidly built.  The tradeoff is that this carseat is *heavy*.  I haven't actually weighed the seat itself, but it's easily twice as heavy as our old Graco seat, if not heavier.  Keep that in mind if you are traveling with this seat, especially if you are traveling with more than one of these seats.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing

Review: Great durable car seat! It will last forever if you take care of it. Be sure to have your local fire house install it for you because it's a doozy to install properly & your local fire department guys/gals are more than happy to assist.

Right when you have the seatbelt as tight as you can get it, it bunches up and you have to start over again.  I did end up getting a great workout trying to put this seat in.  Ended up returning it for a Britax Marathon.  The Chicco is large, and the only real way I could get this to fit in the double cab was the middle seat.

Also, it's a little difficult to get the straps adjusted, but once they're in correctly its fine... hoping to not have to adjust them too often, just with a growth spurt or two. The chest clip was a little hard for me to unbuckle at first. then i figured out its bc i was trying to open it wrong, now its a breeze. My point is, it takes some time to get use to (i've had it for 3 wks), but for the price, its definitely a good deal... compared to the 300 chicco next fit i originally wanted and I'm sure would have been super easy to use... then i  came to my senses and thought it was ridiculous to spend that much on a car seat!

We bought this one assuming that the high cost would mean high quality.  We were wrong.  The “core” construction is solid but it seems as if the team that designed the soft cloth and upholstery (if you will) were not holding themselves to any goal beyond satisfying short term cosmetic appearance needs for “wow-ing” consumers.

Review:
My kids absolutely love these seats!! I bought these after trying a different travel size booster that my kids complained were really uncomfortable. The BubbleBums have now replaced their hard plastic seats as their daily booster.
We had an issue with one of the bladders not holding air after only a few months so I reached out to the company. They quickly replaced the bladder and gave me tips on how to keep the bladders from leaking again. You will want to always release the valve when the seat is not in use and store it either on the floor or trunk of your vehicle to keep the seals intact. My kids are old enough to release the valve and put the seats on the floor whenever we arrive at our destination.
One of the best customer service experiences that I’ve ever had. I will always recommend BubbleBum seats!

Review: When buying a seat for your child, why buy anything other than the safest seat available? This is my second britax advocate clicktight, and I'll never buy anything but Britax. I've had another kind of seat, and just no. It's for emergencies only. I'm very thankful for the addition of the safewash fabric. This was not available when I had my first. I definitely recommend buying the liner, too. Crumbs collect in the bottom, under the clicktight lid, and cleaning under there is a major pain. Also, this is a pretty large seat. I drive a Ford fusion and from having two in the back I can tell that there is no way a third can fit. I can sit inbetween, so there is room for a smaller adult or child, but it's not somewhere I would want to ride for a long period of time. Also, both of my littles are rear facing and that greatly reduces the amount of legroom for the driver and front passenger. Being 5ft 5 inches I can drive comfortably but it's a different story for my 6ft 1in husband. He drives a Jeep Grand Cherokee and we find that he has the legroom issue in it, as well. It doesnt matter to me though, I'd rather get a larger vehicle than compromise on safety. Also, these are made in the USA, which is icing on the cake for me.

Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: Clicktight

It's a bit hard to use the seat insert cushion in the winter with layers on our 10 month old, but the seat is comfy enough without it we figure.  The best part about the seat is the level on the side to let you know you are installing correctly before you get too far and the easy adjustments on the side that are all color coded.  An added bonus is the storage pocket for the directions in the back of the chair - brilliant!  I'm hoping this one will really last for the life of her needing a car seat - if it does well, her (smaller) twin will get a matching one when she outgrows her carrier seat!

She is 7 pounds and on the smallest setting I just don’t feel like she is secure enough in there compared to the infant carrier my husband went with. That being said I would still purchase it again, we got great feedback about it as a seat from our hospital nurses and once my daughter hits 9 or 10 pounds I’m sure thebfit will be perfect, just not practical for these first couple of weekends with a tiny baby.

Review:
The WORST!!! The states specificstions on the item are false. My daughter is well below the weight, height and "seated height" for the product yet, she no longer fits into it.

I contacted Britax. They were dismissive and finally, after several calls, a supervisor suggested that I call customer service and order an extended harness. I'd have to pay around $25 plus shipping. This isn't a huge amount but is an unacceptable solution for an item that states it should work for my child for at least another year or longer.

I've now purchased a booster seat, far sooner than I wanted. The goal was to keep my daughter in the car seat as long as possible (as recommended by all safety agencies).

Last note, not only is their product horrible, but the customer service is outrageously poor!!!

Review:
I wanted to love this seat. I really did. I bought two of them. But I just can’t.

Pros:
-Very nice comfortable fabric, that reminds me of a much more expensive Chicco nextfit.

-Easy to clean and pull off fabric cover and throw in the wash.

-Super safe if you can get a good install, and made in the USA.

Cons:
-Difficult to install. The Latch system is one strap with two buckles that runs through the back of the seat. I purchased this seat after we were in an accident, and this seat replaced a Britax seat. Britax seats come with two individual straps/buckles that attach to a steel bar that then attach to your latch system. This method is infinitely easier to install and get a tight install in minutes, every time. I have never been able to get a tight install with the latch system with this evenflo seat. Yes, you can put pool noodles underneath the seat to get a tighter install as other reviewers have mentioned, but who wants to deal with that? I have gotten a good/tight install with the seatbelt installation though. So take that for what it’s worth.

-The harness is hard to adjust. On both of my seats, the harness can get stuck in one position and I’ve had to yank on it so hard that I thought I was going to break it, just to adjust it. This is a no-go if you have multiple kids at different heights using the seat, or if you just need to change the harness height in a hurry. Maybe it’s just my two seats, but both of them are not easy to adjust.

-The harness is difficult to tighten. Enough said.

-To adjust the headrest height of the seat, there’s a lever you push down on the BACK of the headrest to move the headrest up and down. Not a big deal, right? It’s not, if the seat isn’t already installed. If it is, you can’t do it. You have to take the seat out of the car and adjust the headrest. Again, pain in the A** if you’re in a hurry and trying to adjust it for another kid.

-This may not be a con to some, but this seat is huge. If you need room in your car for additional passengers, I’d suggest the Graco Slimfit.

-The base of this seat has no level indicator just a line that should run parallel to the ground. This isn’t a huge deal, but considering the price of this seat, and it’s competitors all do, I was surprised it didn’t come with this option.

Overall I’m debating getting rid of both of these seats and replacing them with the Graco 4ever, that’s how much I dislike them. My kids say they’re very comfortable, that’s the only reason I’ve kept them for as long as I have. If you don’t have to move these seats from vehicle to vehicle, they’re fine, but the fact that the harness is difficult to tighten on ours every single time we get in the vehicle is enough to make me want to get a new seat. I don’t recommend.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: Difficult to install. The Latch system is one strap with two buckles that runs through the back of the seat. I have never been able to get a tight install with the latch system with this evenflo seat. I have gotten a good/tight install with the seatbelt installation though.
Harness Type: The harness is hard to adjust. The harness can get stuck in one position. The harness is difficult to tighten.
Material: Very nice comfortable fabric, easy to clean and pull off fabric cover and throw in the wash.

Review:
We bought this for my son when he was 6 months old because the infant carrier we had plus the chunky monkey was just too heavy. He's now just over 3 years old (36lbs & 36in) and still fits in it, rear-facing, perfectly! He honestly never complains about it being uncomfortable, so it must fit him well. It's pretty easy to install and wash (we've gotten lots of practice over the past 2.5 years), and always feels really sturdy when installed, not wiggly at all. We take pretty long trips regularly and have even taken this along on a plane, no complaints from anyone!
The only con is that we got the tan and black version, and after 2.5 years there are some visible stains on the seat that I can't get out, but that's not a deal breaker for us. I wish it was a darker color or a bit more stain resistant.
We drive a Toyota Venza and have the seat installed behind the passenger. The seat does have to be forward a bit, but I (5'6") still fit very comfortably, even for long trips. It's a little bit of a tighter fit for my husband (6'1"), but it works!

Review:
Overall love the car seat. Pretty easy to install and use. I love that it has a spot to hold the straps out of the way while you are getting your child in the seat. I have not had to wash it yet so I will update once I have. My one complaint: it's hard to tighten the harness straps. I found that once I have my little guy strapped in if I first tighten the straps from the back of the seat (we are still rear facing) it becomes much easier to tighten. Grab right above the metal piece that is holding the straps on the back of the seat and then pull down, this pulls most of the slack and you are able to tighten the harness, then make your adjustments to the chest clip and shoulder pads etc. and then a final pull to tighten. This has made the process much easier to get the right fit without feeling like you need to be He-man to do it.
I have seen a lot of complaints about the cup holders, they are square in shape and most cups do not fit. They work well for holding small toys though and it hasn't really bothered me. However, I was able to find a water bottle to fit! The Disney store is selling square shaped water bottles right now! It was about $10 bucks and fits perfectly!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: hard to tighten the harness straps; tighten the straps from the back of the seat; pull down right above the metal piece holding the straps on the back; final pull to tighten; easier to get the right fit
Seat Type: rear facing

Review: I have the Britax Advocate 70-CS and the G3 and we LOVE them! Once our son turned 7 months we decided to move him into a convertible car seat and after much research we decided upon the Advocate 70-CS, we continued to use his Britax infant car seat as our back up car seat. As he began to outgrow the back up, I began my search again. Although, we were very happy with the advocate, it is a huge car seat and I thought it might be a good opportunity to cheat on Britax with the Radian, I was enticed by it's slim design. So I began to research the Radian and went to our local store to see it in person. After weighing the pros and cons, I decided to stay with the Advocate. So what keeps me loyal to the advocate you ask? those side protection air bubbles! As of now my son is in the middle but one day we will have another baby and the new baby will have to go in the middle so I want my son to have all the side protection I can give. Yes, it's huge and some people argue that the air bubbles are overboard but when it involves your child safety you cannot go overboard. Also the installation is AWESOME! I'm one of those crazy moms that would rather bring in the car seat than wake my son from his nap, so ya it's huge and heavy but I can carry it and my 25 lb son through a garage up an elevator to our apartment (if the hubby's around I make him do it) and I probably should not mention this but... it also fits in the Britax B-ready stroller so sometimes if I can't muster the strength, I'll just sit it in the stroller facing me. Britax you might want to bust an Orbit! (they have a convertible car seat that attaches to the stroller). Anyway, we are constantly re-installing our car seat and it's simple and secure every time. And I'm loving the new features on the G3 especially the buckle staying up and the hugs strap is cool, whatever offers my son greater protection is good with me!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: convertible car seat
Installation Type: simple and secure every time
Material: side protection air bubbles

Review:
Maxi Cosi is high end European brand trying to make presence on the US market. I’ve seen some of their other products but this car seat, Pria 3 in 1 tops it all off. Firstly this car seat is a TANK. It’s sturdy, it’s strong, it’s protective. So how do they do it? Infant to 10 years old? It’s a lot of padding. It’s customizable as other convertible seats we’ve seen, you remove the infant inserts to convert to toddler but adjustable head rest is what’s making it suitable for big kids. It’s quite brilliant actually. The seat itself doesn’t go through any adjustments so it’s still solid seat body that will protect the child in case of impact. Padding is DENSE, it’s not just soft cushion, it’s really dense and firm. It’s easy to install but it’s big, I wouldn’t recommend for the small car. My 2year old is very comfy in this seat which just replaced our Britax Boulevard. Where we live is hot and humid and my boy doesn’t get got, we do use moderate AC in the vehicle.
I couldn’t be happier with this seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Weight Range of Child: Infant to 10 years old
Installation Type: easy to install
Material: padding, dense and firm padding

Review:
Me: father of two, one rear-facing and one front-facing.

Pros:
* It is truly narrow, only slightly wider than a roll of paper towel
* The hip flaps cleverly expand to accommodate bigger kids and the seat base folds-up on mechanical hinge for travelling (handy for airport scanners, I suspect).
* It’s also built like a tank, the all-steel construction adds peace-of-mind. Even the head side cushions are super sturdy.

Cons:
* This thing weighs a ton. But as heavy as it is, it doesn’t even have any handles, so it feels even heavier. Despite the folding base, I would never take this on a plane on account of how heavy and awkward it is.
* Also, despite the fancy folding seats, this seat doesn’t even recline! Instead, it comes with a separate attachment (another thing to carry for travelling…) for rear-facing installation that just sort of props it up on one side, which is kind of like shoving a bunch of books underneath to tilt it. This is truly stupid for a $330 car seat. You can acquire their foam pad to shim the seat to different angles, but this doesn’t seem very tasteful to me and the pads are not even included in the box. I suppose anything could be as small as you want it to be, if it was infinitely disassembled into "separate" parts...
* Lastly, this seat leans sideways because of its slimness. I tend to position car seats nearer to the doors to widen the middle seat (the whole point of a slim seat is to salvage the middle seat, after all) and, while other wider child seats would just bridge over minor bumps in the car’s seat cushions, this seat’s narrowness makes it lean into those bumps, making it hard straighten. I suppose some shims would be helpful in this case to level the seat.

If Diono is reading, here are my recommendations for the future:
* Handles or hand-slots for carrying
* If you have room for a folding base, you should find room for an articulating reclining mechanism. Otherwise, if both won’t fit, replace the folding base with a recline mech.
* If you still must keep the prop-up legs, make it collapsible under the seat instead being a separate attachment.
* Consider some kind of a lateral stabilizer like turn-out feet or a tilt-table base. Or in this case, I suppose some shims might be okay, but just include them in the box please!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear-facing, front-facing
Weight Range of Child: bigger kids
Installation Type: rear-facing installation
Material: all-steel construction

Review:
All around, this seat was a no for us.

(1) Latch is impossible. Maybe it works better for others based on their type of vehicle, but I could NOT get this to tighten down using the Latch system in our Acura RDX. I finally caved and asked my husband for help. I was pushing on the seat with all my might while my husband pulled the strap with all his might (we're not weaklings!) and we were barely able to tighten it down. Moving the seat between vehicles, or leaving it at daycare for field trips, could absolutely not happen.

(2) The dreaded head-flop. I drove my daughter (18 months old) to school in it this morning and noticed that she just didn't look comfortable. Even with the seat reclined back to the 3 position she was still leaning forward. She fell asleep on the drive and immediately her head fell forward. Ugh.

(3) Straps are difficult to tighten and the chest buckle is flimsy and difficult. And the seat buckle is really bulky and difficult to keep out of the way when you're putting your kiddo in.

Needless to say this is going back and I just ordered the Graco 4-ever. Was hoping for a carseat that was less expensive but still safe and effective, but I'd rather spend the money and get something that really works. I'm surprised this seat has the positive reviews that it has. We weren't impressed.

Review:
We have twins so for us there were 3 major deciding factors: 1) How easy is it to pop in and out of the base? 2) What is the safety rating, and 3) Is it compatible with the stroller we want?

Since there are few twin strollers on the market, we tackled the stroller question first and settled on the City Select.

Pros:
1) This car seat is really easy to pop in and out of the base. There is a simple latch in the back of the seat that you pull and the car seat pops out.
2) The canopy is excellent and provides a decent amount of coverage.
3) Great safety rating.
4) Our babies were small when we left the hospital and we needed an insert (Summer Infant Snuzzler) to stabilize their head but they did really well with that simple fix.
5) It fits the City Select stroller with a simple adapter. The adapter snaps into the stroller and then the car seat snaps into the adapter without requiring any complicated or bulky stabilizing bars or straps. The adapters do not have to be removed to collapse the stroller. If you have twins, the only way both car seats will fit the stroller is if they are both facing you. This places the rear baby below the front baby.

Cons:
1) We struggled a bit with the base installation (rear facing) because our back seats are sloped (bucket like). Even though the marker was within the limits of the level and should have been fine, the car seat was tilted slightly forward causing the babies' heads to flop forward as well. There is a recline adjustment button for the base but it wasn't nearly enough to rectify the tilt. It turns out this is not an infrequent problem and Britax has a youtube video on correcting this. I'm not sure if other car seats have more range in the tilt to accommodate for this problem.
2) For installing without the base, the seat belt guides are hidden under the cover so it's a pain to access them to install the seat.
3) The cushion coverings can be removed but they're not machine washable.
4) The car seats are wide relative to some others so it makes your middle seat virtually useless unless you have a really skinny person.
5) This is a MAJOR con. Because the car seats are wide, there isn't a single or double snap-n-go on the market that fits the car seats. That means you are committed to your stroller as your only travel system. We like our City Select stroller but the frame is heavy and requires removal of the 2nd seat mounting brackets to fit in the trunk. For short distances, it's a drag to have to set up the frame. At the same time, carrying 2 car seats by yourself is never an option. In retrospect, this may have been a deal breaker and I think I would have tried to come up with another car seat that fit the City Select.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: base installation, seat belt guides
Material: cushion coverings

When your child falls asleep theres a lot of head bobbing, no support for them to lean their head on in the front facing position. When I received the car seat it had no shoulder strap covers as it was pictured on the one I bought. It came in no plastic covering, just in a box. The fabric stains very easy and the cover is a pain to pull off. When the seat is set to its lowest shoulder position mine would not lock in place and there was a four finger gap between the seat and its sliding adjustable part backing. Over all I just didn't like this car seat. I returned it for the Maxi Cosi Pria 70 which was amazing and worth every penny compared to this.

Review: We looked at a LOT of convertible carseats, and this is the best we found.  We can still have our son rear-facing, even though he is 19 months old (24 lbs, almost 33 inches long), and we will be able to continue having him rear-facing way past his 2nd birthday, which is very much safer than forward-facing for little ones.  It was also one of the only ones that made it easy to put our son in and out of, since some were SO large that they left no room for getting him in and out of our Chevy Malibu.  Our son is very comfortable in it and he LOVES being able (finally!) to see out of the car.  It is a very nice-looking carseat too, and easy to wipe clean.  It is also just very well-made, unlike many others, which simply feel and look cheap.  We had bought a cheap convertible carseat (Cosco brand) for a plane trip over the summer, and it is already tearing a little at the seams after a total of about a week of use.  Yes, this Peg Perego carseat  is more expensive than many carseats out there, but why do you want a cheap and poorly-made carseat to protect your most precious possession in the world?  If you paid more for your cell phone than for your carseat, you may want to rethink your priorities.  We highly recommend it for anyone interested in the best for their child.

Review: It should be made clear that the base is NOT required to safely and securely install the infant car seat. The installation and use of bases in multiple vehicles is only a convenience, not a necessity.  The Chicco KeyFit 30 user guide on pages 37 and 38 describes "installation without a base" and "installation in aircraft".  As far as I can determine, it is not possible to purchase a seat without the base; however, it is possible to purchase only a base (i.e., without the seat). Of course, Chicco would love to sell you multiple bases at around $85-90 each.  And yes, having multiple bases installed does make it easier to just "snap in" the car seat without having to deal with the seat belt each time; but again, a base is not a requirement, only a convenience.  Please note that the Chicco KeyFit 30 user guide does warn: "NEVER install the CARRIER without Base using a non-locking vehicle belt.  The installation will NOT be secure.  Refer to your vehicle owner's manual for detailed vehicle belt information".
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: installation without a base, installation in aircraft, seat belt, base is not required, base is a convenience, base is not a necessity, snap in the car seat, NEVER install the CARRIER without Base using a non-locking vehicle belt

The only thing I didn't like about it was after we converted it to a high back booster for my daughter. We found it too difficult to get her buckled up and the belt where it needed to be. The reach around the seat was awkward because of the width and she could not do it herself. We ordered her the Evenflo Big Kid Amp (which she loves) and it is much easier to deal with. My son's was ordered after we already switched my daughter into the Amp.

In terms of delivery of this item, I was having troubles finding them in stores and was worried about the "usually ships in 3-6 weeks" that I found on the listing. I phoned Evenflo and they told me that a shipment was scheduled to arrive at Amazon's warehouse on April 15. I was beyond impressed (and surprised) to have my son's new car seat sitting on my porch by 10am on April 18th. And the box itself didn't have a single mark on it. Well done Amazon.

Review: It's OK, it does the job just fine, but it's not great for extended use. The bottom buckle near the groin does not have the ability to adjust outwards, and you can't make that buckle strap longer. So while you can adjust the straps near the shoulders as your kid grows taller, you cannot adjust the bottom buckle as your child grows wider. My 4 year old is super skinny and still requires a 5 point harness since he only weighs 33 pounds, but because he's so tall, he complains about the buckle hurting his groin every time I buckle him into the car. I'm actually going to buy a different car seat because of this, even though my son won't grow out of the weight limit for this seat for a long time. It's a shame, I was really looking forward to not having to buy him another car seat again, but here we are.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: bottom buckle near the groin does not have the ability to adjust outwards, you can't make that buckle strap longer, complains about the buckle hurting his groin
Weight Range of Child: only weighs 33 pounds

Review: We purchased the Evenflo Stratos for a spare car seat. I have two Graco Extend2Fits for my 27 month old son(one in each parent's car). I wished I had gotten another one of those rather than this seat for a few reasons. This seat is difficult for me to install. I can't seem to get it tight enough with LATCH, but got a better and more secure install using the seat belt. This seat came with LATCH connector "guides" to help find the LATCH hooks. It was horrible trying to install this seat without those. It was so frustrating! While the seat isn't very plush, my child seemed to be comfortable and had enough leg room. He is pretty petite anyway(25lbs and 33in tall). This seat isn't very compact front to back and only offers two recline settings, but still fit well in my 2015 Ford Fusion SE. I love the fact that this seat will still last my son awhile(probably until he is at least five or six years old). It can fit children from 5-40lbs and 19-40in rear facing and goes up to 65lbs and 54in forward facing. The cup holders are ok, my son puts snacks in them because his sippy cups do not fit in them at all(we use Gerber Essentials cups). I like the seat overall, I feel my child is safe in this seat, but I just love my Graco seats and wished I had spent the extra money.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing, Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 5-40lbs, up to 65lbs
Installation Type: LATCH, seat belt
Harness Type: 
Material: not very plush

Review:
We have a Graco Turbo Booster as a secondary seat for my 5.5-year-old. We needed a second high-back booster for a short-term transport of one of his friends and since this was cheaper than the Graco and pretty well-reviewed, I bought it. However, were this a long-term-use purchase, I would have sent it back and spent the extra $10-$15 on the Graco, no question whatsoever. I do like the cupholders on the Evenflo, but the padding is inferior to the Graco and the Evenflo would be difficult for napping - the Graco has an extra layer of padding at the head, which is nice for my son, who still zonks out in the car pretty frequently. The Graco also has better padding overall. The Evenflo IS slightly more narrow than the Graco, if space is at a premium, but I would never pick this seat over the Graco for significant use.

As a side note, as many people have pointed out in these reviews, these seats are for kids who are at least 4 years old, and this actually printed on the instruction manual for this seat, even though it's not prominent in the Amazon description. Skeletal maturity is important, not just hitting the height/weight standards.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: high-back booster
Weight Range of Child: at least 4 years old
Material: padding is inferior, extra layer of padding at the head, better padding overall

Review:
We have had this car seat as well as a Graco model for around a year now and wow, what a difference. The straps on the Graco are constantly twisted, the fabric is a pain to get off to wash, and it just feels cheap.

The Britax, however, is wonderful. Excellent safety ratings, the fabric is a breeze to take off for washing, the straps always stay smoothed and therefore don't bother my son, and (minor but nice for us) the slot for the cupholder is under the fabric and isn't always slipping off like the screw-on models for other brands do.

The safety features are why we bought the Britax but the overall ease of use and my son's preference for it is what makes us love it. When it is outgrown, we will definitely be purchasing a Britax replacement!!!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Material: fabric is a breeze to take off for washing, fabric is under the fabric and isn't always slipping off like the screw-on models for other brands do
Harness Type: straps always stay smoothed

Literally the best car seat. So easy to extending the head / shoulder straps. Instead of completely taking the car seat out and taking the straps off and going through the holes you just lift it up. Sooooo much easier omg.

Just all around a great car seat.

Review:
I have three kids so I have a lot of experience with car seats. From Britax to Graco to Chicco to Baby Jogger to now Maxi-Cosi. So far the Chicco Zip convertible is my favorite but this is a close second. My 3 year old primarily uses this car seat and so far he seems to like it a lot. It looks super comfortable and my son has not complained about it at all. The quality of the seat is pretty good and it was very simple to install. Probably took 10 minutes for the initial set up. My only complaint is how easily the harness gets twisted. This is a common issue with car seats but several manufacturers have figured out ways to prevent this. Maxi-Cosi is not one of those companies. That being said, I can highly recommend this car seat.

Pros:
-Easy to install
-Very comfortable for the kids. It's really soft.
-Installed in 10 minutes
-Grows with your kids

Cons:
- The belt keeps getting twisted when you buckle your kid into the car seat. This is a common problem with many car seats but several companies have developed methods to prevent it.

We dont have to move the passenger seat all the way forward just slightly in rear facing.  Very comfortable for the baby.  Easy to adjust.  Have been using it for about two months now and no real complaints.  I'm satisfied with this purchase.

Review: There is something seriously wrong with this seat. I think I need to return it because it's not safe. The straps do not tighten. And it's not just because it's in the rear facing position or that he's in the seat when I'm trying to tighten. I have taken this seat out several times, looked the whole thing over, checked the manual and nothing fixes it nor addresses the issue. The straps are far too loose and even when I don't have it installed it only tightens as far as the seam on the underside of the strap. When I look on the underside there's no more strap to pull through, it's at the limit of how tight it will go. I don't know if we're missing a part? Additional straps for a smaller size?? But it's not right. My child is 20# and when it's as tight as it'll go it's still way too loose!! He can pull the straps right off his shoulders without even undoing the chest clip. It's scary! There is NO EARTHLY WAY this would work on a 5# infant if it doesn't even go small enough for a 20# toddler!!!! WTH!?! This wasn't a "cheap" seat either. I bought it only after reading tons of great reviews and safety rating, so I must have gotten a defective seat.

I love that it’s secures in the tether hooks of my car, no more seats sliding all around my back seat or the kids fumbling to get in it in the pickup line. It’s nice and secure. Review:
We were recently in a car accident (Everyone is fine) with the Chicco keyfit. I was relieved with the protection it provided for my son that when it came to replace it I just wanted to but the same one. My son is 14 months and was nearing the size restrictions to use the keyfit so we opted for this nextfit. Let's just say you get use to a product. We had to use a Graco snugride and an evenflo tritan as we waited for it to ship, neither one came close. The next fit is extremely user friendly (even for grandparents) and includes little extras that other car seats don't have for baby's comfort that I found out are a must . Most notably the strap covers that rest on baby's shoulder to prevent rubbing and irritating their neck as you tighten and loosen straps.
Side note - the other named car seats were difficult to install. The new car seat could not come fast enough.

Review: I have bought and installed many car seats. My biggest issue has always been leveling and installing with latch. Nothing seems tight enough and I'm never 100% confident in the install. This seat is different. We bought the maroon color which looks great. The seat is heavy, but I don't have to move it so it isn't an issue. What I love is the bubble level on both sides so I know the angle is right. Also the dual cinch latch belt is awesome. Pull them in the right order and the seat was super secure without killing myself. Install took less than 10 minutes and part of that time was spent reading directions. I was nervous about buying an expensive seat, but it was worth every penny.

Review: I have 4 kids under 6 years old, so I have 4 car seats/boosters in my car. I have HATED moving car seats with a passion. I once saw a meme that said something like “I’d rather eat a Jean jacket than move car seats around” and I resonated with that completely. I always asked my husband to do it because I’d end up a sweaty mess trying to get the old convertible car seat tight enough. Not with this seat. It’s SO easy. If you’re like me and you’re looking for something simple to get in and out, this is the one.
Attribute_Related_Content: Seat Type: convertible car seat

Review:
I was lucky enough to score this seat in the cyber Monday hidden deal, and since I am a CPST, I wanted one as a backup as well as for education. My 4 month old is currently using this seat installed with the seat belt in the middle of our "13 Ford Explorer.
Pros:
*Ease of installation. It wasn't the easiest I've ever done, and I made the mistake of expecting to be able to reach in through the belt path. You can't, instead you pull back the cover and reach in that way. But overall, I'd say this is a pretty easy installation. The recline adjustment is awesome. Follow the manual!
*It's a nicely compact seat that is also long-lasting, which is a fantastic combination.
*I love how organized it is designed and the very clear instructions and stickers on the seat. Chicco did a great job wording the manual and clearly marking the seat. I also love the little compartments for storage on the seat.
* Kudos of Chicco for listening to their customers and allowing the strap covers to be optional (go to their website for more information)

Cons:
*It's a big seat. While it is nicely compact front to back, it is still quite heavy and bulky. Loading a child in and out can be a challenge and it's more of a bucket-shaped seat, which some kids may not like. It is also moderately wide at the widest parts of the sides, so puzzling with other seats may be a challenge if you are lacking in space.
*The harness tends to be very hard to tighten. I'm not sure if that will improve once the strap covers are removed. The pads also get in the way of being able to do the pinch test, and practically choke my son once I finally wrestle the chest clip high enough (have almost hit him in the face several times trying to pull/push the clip up!).
*The adjustable headrest can be frustrating to use. It's clunky and takes some finesse to figure out how to press the stiff button and raise the headrest and then find the locked position.

Overall, this seat is worth some of the day to day annoyances, and I'm sure with extended use, things loosen up and it becomes easier to do the necessary adjustments. But for me personally, this will be our #2 seat, behind the Radian RXT. There's just no contest when it comes to getting the baby in the seat and buckled and adjusted with ease.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 4 month old
Installation Type: seat belt
Harness Type: harness tends to be very hard to tighten, chest clip
Material: strap covers, pads

It's a bit of a tight squeeze front to back in airline seats (when rear-facing, anyway), and can be a little tough to maneuver in smaller aircraft (the ones with one seat on one side, and two seats on the other side). If you're taking it on a plane, do yourself a favor and get a cart for it. Britax makes one that we used with great success. You really, really don't want to lug this thing through an airport and also have to wrangle a baby/toddler.

While it might be heavier that competing products, that's what adds to its safety and awesomeness.

Also, if she fell asleep she'd "noodle neck" or fall over sideways because there is no support for her to rest her head (like on her high back booster).

It is really small, light, and convenient for travel which is why I'm keeping it but I am not using it for everyday travel.

Review: I am surprisingly pleased with this product. One would think that you would get a subpar car seat for the awesome price of the Graco Nautilus but that is not the case. This seat is very comfortable for my twin 3 year olds. I was initially concerned when we first installed the seat that the straps would be too short. However, you are able to modify the location of where the straps start from the back and that helped alot. One of my daughters is very tall for her age but she sits comfortably in this seat. The head rest is adjustable and isn't too confining for the head. I absolutely LOVE the beverage holders and the little cubbies within the inside of the arm rests. Can't tell you how handy these spots are. The locking mechanism sometimes get stuck when trying to get them out of their seats but I think it's more me than the seat. Overall, I would highly recommend this product to anyone.

Review: Had this car seat for about 6 months when we (husband, my father, my sister and myself) started noticing that the buckle was getting harder and harder to unlatch. Then one day, I went to get my son out of it and COULDN'T. The buckle was completely jammed. Had to cut the straps. Called Graco and they issued me a replacement. Got it in yesterday, took it out of the box and had THE EXACT SAME ISSUE! I posted a pic of the car seat on my facebook and IMMEDIATELY had 8 people comment saying they were having the same problem. Most of them were able to call Graco and get a REFUND. I took this carseat back to the store today and exchanged it for a comparable EvenFlo seat. Very disappointed.

Review: I bought this seat for my three year old. My one year old is ready to move out of his current car seat. Therefore, my youngest is getting my oldest's hand me down Britax Boulevard. I can't help but compare the two. This car seat requires some assembly. My previous, Britax Boulevard, arrived ready to go into the car. The shoulder harness straps do have to be rethreaded as the child grows. I loved the color scheme, but I purchased this for my 3 year old and he has already outgrown the removable comfort padding (most of the orange shown in pic). Without the comfort padding, it feels pretty hard on the seat area. Does anyone make a cushy car seat??? I do agree with others, the crotch harness area is pretty tight. I do wish that I bought another Britax (even with the major price difference). It was a big hassle assembling this car seat. Others have brushed off the buckle issue. The big deal with the buckle is that it is unreasonably hard to unbuckle. Which is normally not a big deal in case of an accident. Unless, seconds mean the difference between life and death should your car catch on fire. That's the case for one of the lawsuits against the company.

You simply pull up the red handle to adjust the strap height. The diono, however, seems like a more comfortable seat, the low profile makes getting the baby in and out a breeze, and the clip is easy to move up and down. The clip on this graco is hard to move up but too easy to move down and slips down during the trip.

I didn't know about this, that some of this chairs come with out any way to attach them to the car seat other than the child weight, and was very surprised when I didn't find anything (it actually took me a while trying and looking before finally realizing there's nothing more) to attach it, so hope this help someone else.

Review: I know this is a popular product and many moms love this car seat. My son fits well, but the overall quality is a bit lacking. The only ones I could order aren't the right ones for the car seat...but we'll make due. The car seat we have for our other car is more comfortable for the little one and we've had zero issues with it in the same 6 months. And, BRITAX was 3 times as expensive! Wouldn't buy BRITAX again.

Review:
I really like this stroller. I LOVE that my carseat (the Safety 1st OnBoard 35) clicks right into it without any problems and that it's so lightweight and easy to set up. However, I wish that 1) it was easier to turn; it is almost impossible to maneuver one-handed and sometimes it has problems not wanting to turn on linoleum. It feels like it's dragging sideways rather than having the wheels actually turn. 2) the underneath storage was a little more accessible; it's quite a large storage space, but in order to get my diaper bag in there I have to pop the carseat all the way out. The opening between the carseat and the top of the storage compartment is fairly narrow. 3) it was easier to tell if the carseat was all the way in; sometimes we'll put it in and it'll seem to be all the way in, but a little later we hear a click telling us that NOW it's all the way in, whereas before it wasn't. 4 my husband) it had better shock absorbency. I understand it's not a jogging stroller, but you can definitely tell when you're going over a crack in the sidewalk. However, my baby seems to enjoy the off-roading type feeling ;)

Also, the two parts that are red in the picture (the side clip and the button on the handlebar) are actually gray on my stroller.

Aside from these minor complaints, I absolutely LOVE this stroller. I am so glad I bought it and I would definitely recommend it! It is super convenient and doesn't take up much room in the car at all.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: Clicktight

Review:
Seat is very easy to carry, install and move around. Also the kids can easily get used to the seat and they can be seated easily on it. It also gives ample leg space and convenient to sit with the handle.

Review: Stop your search now - Britax makes the best car seat products.  We have had the Roundabout, the Marathon and now the Frontier.  No complaints.  The Frontier is beautifully designed, comfortable and, most importantly, has great safety features:  5 point harness, side impact protection and plenty of shock absorbing material - and it is comfortable.  My child likes the cup holders that fold out of the base.  Excellent product.

Review: I too am wondering why the price is so expensive on here, compared to Walmart (where we bought ours).  The only thing I can think of is that this carseat is so high in demand, and sold out at many places, that they are selling it from a company with a really high price.  I would definately wait until the price goes down to get this seat.  That said, this carseat is absolutely the best one yet.  I origally wanted to buy one for my three year old nephew (who I care for) because his seat was getting outdated.  Instead, I ended up buying two of these, one for him and one for his 5 year old sister.  She was already in a plain booster seat, but I decided to buy this so she can be in a harness longer.  Now, she should fit with the harness until she is at least 7, which is a whole lot safer.  She actually doesn't mind being back in a carseat, because this seat is so cool, with it's cup holder and two "secret treasure holders."  I also love the buckle (which I can open with one hand) compared to my nephew's old system.  It is also easier for my neice to buckle the harness then to buckle herself into her booster seat using the car seat belt.  So much faster!  Another bonus, this carseat is also safe for one year olds on up.  I do home daycare and occasionally have different kids using the seats.  This carseat has straps that are the absolute easiest to adjust.  It litterally takes seconds. I origally thought the price of $150 was high (and that was when I was planning on buying just one!), but it truly is the last carseat you will need to buy.  It is a fantasic carseat and soo worth the price.  There are probably more expensive carseats that aren't as nice.  And for the added piece of mind of having them in a harness longer, priceless.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: harness; easier to buckle; straps that are the absolute easiest to adjust
Weight Range of Child: safe for one year olds on up; should fit with the harness until she is at least 7

I was worried about size and space in my jeep but it fits great. Best part is it will grow with us and last until booster time.Cute neutral design as well. Baby girl loves it too. Review:
My son normally rides in a [[ASIN:B005MQRAAK Diono Radian RXT Convertible Car Seat, Shadow]] but I wanted something small and lightweight for flying. This seat did the trick. Easy to carry through the airports and easy to install on the plane.

I wouldn't use it as a daily seat unless I truly needed a budget option because the straps twist easily (a common issue I've found on inexpensive seats). It also has a low height and weight limit so it won't last long.

Seat Type: Convertible Car Seat
