Review: Overall the car seat is fine, but I dont know who they think they are to include this infant insert. It's absolutely useless. My son was 7lbs 14oz at birth. I had a home birth so I had to bring him to the pediatricians office at two days old. I was petrified! I ended up adding padding to keep his head supported. I know they say that's not safe, but I had to make a judgement. It's SO thin and flimsy. An absolute joke. My son is now almost 14lbs at 2 months and the insert is still doing zero. The couple times I forgot the other padding, my heart wrenched as I watched his head rolling around the entire ride in the mirror. I do NOT recommend this seat for a newborn.

Review:
Piece of garbage that is placing my child at risk. Buyer beware. The straps on this seat are able to be pulled completely free of their securing points by my 15 month old. He is strong but no infant should be able to disable their car seat . The top of the straps are able to be pullex free of the toggles on the back side. This allows my son to get himself out of the car seat. I have ensured the seat is properly configured and adjusted. This is not a user error issue but rather graco utilizing sub standard securing methods.

If a infant can pull the straps free using his upper body what's the chance this will fail in an impact. The chance is too high for me to take. I am purchasing a competitors seat and will never use your products again further I am so upset that I will recommend to anyone I know that they not use your seats either.

Child safety is the most important aspect of your business you fail at the only thing that matters .

-Kyle

Review:
We tried several boosters and this was the one we ended up with. Tried the Clek booster, Maxi Cosi, over priced Volvo booster, Graco, and Diono boosters. Diono was hard and too wide on top for three across. The top corners of the head rest made it very difficult to close the door in my 2020 xc90. Graco is narrow in the shoulder area. Liked the Clek booster but the seat has crazy hard cushion and the worse part was the height of the back of the seat. Height of the seat reached under my son’s mid back and the seat bottom was under his mid thigh. My son could not stand it. It’s very simple, sleek and stylish but maybe not the most comfortable for my son at least. Great rigid latch system on the Clek but my son literally asked me to send it back after our test ride in it. My son liked the Maxi Cosi. The cushion was very comfortable but like the Graco we tried, it restricted his arm movements as the shoulder width was narrow. The Volvo seat is not worth mentioning. What a piece of crap! Literally was like taking some hard plastic and covering in a few spots of leather. You might think that being expensive and a car with great safety specs, they might create an innovative and safe seat. Yeah, about that...Hard, uncomfortable, no latch, useless and over $400 for some piece of garbage. For us, the seats all fell short in one or another area.
My 7 year old loves everything about this seat. Easy to use the rigid latch, color is nice, cushion is comfy and easy to clean (fabric zips off) no complaints. He has good arm space and his legs have good seat support underneath. Just happy to have finally found a good, comfortable booster seat without any extra complaints from my gremlin passengers.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster
Weight Range of Child: 7 year old
Installation Type: rigid latch
Material: cushion is comfy, easy to clean, fabric zips off

Review:
This is a great asset to have to be able to tote around an extra little munchkin.😁 It’s easy to set up and has multiple options to secure it safely, depending on your vehicle. It’s really lightweight, weighing only 8lbs and seems to be made Very well with the use of an Aerospace rated aluminum frame. It also meets all Safety Standards for the NTSB and the FAA, so you’re ready for a Road Trip and an Air Trip.
It comes with a bag to store it and the seat itself is made to be easily portable by the other nice case that you zip it into to seal it up and it has straps to carry it like a backpack. The backpack bag has a pocket on the inside of the top for extra storage and an information pocket, like on any piece of luggage, that you can have your information on it to verify it’s yours.
The headrest is easily adjusted up or down for kids from 30 to 45 inches tall and the seat is rated for a weight between 22 and 50 pounds.
Note: If I were to change anything, I would have suggested a bit of padding on the backpack straps. The good thing is, is that it only weighs 8lbs.
I think this is a nice travel seat and would definitely recommend it.

Seat Type: Convertible

Installation Type: multiple options to secure it safely

Review:
The Hiccapop UberBoost is the perfect portable car seat for kids about toddler age and up, to about age 10 or 12, depending on your child's size and weight. It's easy to inflate, deploy, and deflate. The carrying bag makes it perfect for travel. We also now use it every day, as our kids are older and don't need more than a booster.

A few years ago, we spend several months researching portable booster seats for travel, with a lot of confusing reviews and advice. After an initial look through US, UK, and European approved models, we were down to a few brands, using the top car seat review websites.

A look at reviews narrowed the choice to the two that we tried, the Mifold and the Hiccapop. While a little bulkier, the Hiccapop is lighter in weight and was our kids' clear preference in terms of comfort. Hiccapop has a great line of products overall and excellent support as well.

Review:
**I want to start this review off saying that I am extremely unimpressed that Graco markets this seat for children as young as three years old. Three year olds and most four year olds do NOT belong in belt positioning boosters as their bones are much too immature to withstand the forces of a crash with the adult seatbelt, and the kids themselves are also not mature enough to stay in position so the belt can do it's job. Car seat manufacturers are just now starting to take the initiative to raise their minimums for their car seats, so it would be wonderful if Graco can do that too.**

As for the actual seat itself, this is a good budget seat for children over the age of 5. It is not extremely wide so it can fit in a variety of vehicles, and it provides a great belt fit where the shoulder belt lies firmly in the middle of the shoulder and the lap belt lies flat on the child's hips/top of their thighs. It is very lightweight and easy to move around to other vehicles, and it is also comfortable for kids of all different sizes. The headwings are substantial enough to support the child's head when they are sleeping, and many kids can comfortably rest their heads on the side instead of flopping out of position.

Downsides: There is assembly required when you buy this booster, and often times parents throw out or misplace the bag that comes with two little screws which you're supposed to put in the armrests of the booster. This is an extremely important step that will make the seat work correctly in a crash. I think it would be very beneficial for the manufacturer to either have the screws pre-installed, or put a large indication right on the seat itself that the screws need to be in there.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: belt positioning booster
Weight Range of Child: children over the age of 5
Installation Type: screws in the armrests

I didn’t see any other booster seats with a better anchor design and many don’t anchor at all until the child is in it and seat belt secure, so there’s that. My 5 year old granddaughter seems comfortable and she likes  the cup holder which was tucked under the seat upon arrival and needed to be placed in the hole provided. It’s a good size and can be adjusted to fit different heights as she grows.

Review:
This car seat appears very comfortable, but you have to know it is incredibly difficult to clean.

Others will say that it is easy, and that is because all of the fabric pieces come off to throw in the wash. That part is good, but there’s so many nooks and crannies and pieces of moving parts that when your child throws up, which all of us know will happen multiple times. Review: If I could give it a 4.5 I would. Seat is a little heavy which to me means sturdy, safe and will withstand a car accident. I love the shoulder straps and the chest straps that are designed to absorb impact. Installation is a breeze. If you watch a few videos on YouTube it’s the easiest to install while guaranteeing safety and sturdiness. We have 2 cars and just 1 seat for now and moving from car to car is not that bad if you can handle  the weight. The steel frame is visible and makes me feel comfortable. A little more difficult for my wife but we will eventually get two. The click tight feature is really nice. It can sometimes be difficult to pull to tighten but once in place it’s a sure thing. My 14 month old is comfortable and because I have a SUV, when rear facing I can recline pretty well. I do think this seat will be much better once forward facing but that’s my opinion. I looked at competitors like Gravo 4 Ever and the top of the line Chicco seat and I chose this because all the videos and reviews are focused on safety, safety safety over convincnce and look. I will buy this again and highly reccomend this product as you transition to a convertible seat for your little one.

room for kid's feet. The seat is solid and belts don't twist. Thats it for the pros. The crotch strap is too tight!!! Graco, if you are reading this, please add the 3rd slot! How hard could it be?! My daughter is almost 4, weighs 34 pounds. It is super tight. I hope we can get her to be in it, till she is 5, after which
we will switch it to booster mode. I would like to see a 65 pound child, who would fit in it! There is no way we will pass this seat to my son, after he outgrows his Roundabout ,for obvious reasons :) . Also, her head slumps in it, while sleeping. That being said, I still would get it for my girl, because of space issues in my car. If you have a large van, please look at Frontier as well. Hope it helps.

Review:
We own two of these seats. One we purchased in December 2010, and the second we purchased on December 2011 (we have two kids, one year apart). The first one we absolutely loved and still love. The seat is great, sturdy, easily adjustable, heavy enough, and our son quit screaming in the car ever since he's been facing forward. If you have light-colored seats, just a note of warning, with kids things get dirty very quickly, and these seats don't help (I end up cleaning the seats after we take them out, as they get dirty really fast, but I'm sure this is the case for every car seat).

The second one we received in 2011... well, let's just start with my main complaint: locking that sucker in, it's as difficult as installing and reinstalling the seat, or performing brain surgery. The front button with the red in the middle: it was previously a push down mechanism and it locked well, and if pressed well, then it'll unlock - a system that works seemlessly and was easy on your fingers. On the newer version, it's not a push down, but you have to press the button (a much smaller button than the old one), which not only breaks your nails, but requires some muscle.

The design is different and not quite as good as the old one. Moreover, you bring the two belts together and clip them, then you insert the little handles into the center red button and let me tell you... on the newer design, that task is nearly impossible. To lock your child, especially a wiggly one, is a task that takes us at least 10 minutes each time. It just doesn't lock, and it only does when you're stubborn enough to spend the time and patience to lock it. The clips and handles and all of that good stuff is at least 40% smaller on the newer model than it was on the older one. There's a front cover at the croch area, and in the old one it stays in place, it's thick and comfortable. On the newer version, it's smaller, thinner, and what's more, it falls off every time - we removed it permanently. The cover kept covering the locking mechanism making it astronomically harder to lock the belts, than it already is without it.

When you want a car seat for a toddler, you need something that locks easily and fast (I'm good with unlocking being difficult). On the newer seats, unlocking it is easy, but locking your child into the seat is so hard and time consuming it makes me wonder... how many people would give it up. I know that I'm less open to making stops, so that I won't have to take him in and out of his seat - it's just so painful.

The seat itself is great, but if the company would replace those straps and locks for something more functional, it would be a great improvement. The only reason it actually got the 3 stars instead of 1, is because we still love the first seat we bought, we just hate the newer one.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: locking that sucker in, it's as difficult; The front button with the red in the middle: it was previously a push down mechanism and it locked well; press the button (a much smaller button than the old one); you bring the two belts together and clip them, then you insert the little handles into the center red button; To lock your child, especially a wiggly one, is a task; It just doesn't lock; The clips and handles and all of that good stuff is at least 40% smaller; unlocking it is easy, but locking your child into the seat is so hard; replace those straps and locks

On the newer version, it's smaller, thinner, and what's more, it falls off every time - we removed it permanently. The cover kept covering the locking mechanism

Review:
We switched from the Graco car seat and immediately noticed a huge difference. This seat has much more cushioning and looks like it's much more comfortable for the baby. In addition to the extra built in cushioning, there's an extra cushion for around the rear and legs (removable for when baby's bigger), a cushion for the crotch area where the buckle is, and cushions for the harness straps. This seat also feels very sturdy with the steel support beams. The safety rating is the primary reason we bought this seat. We love the pattern, it's very gender neutral.

The baby seems to be comfortable in the chair. He didn't sleep in it in the beginning but that's probably because it was new. My only real complaint with it is that since we still have it rear-facing and my baby is very long/tall for his age, his legs hit the back of the car seat and he has to bend his knees or spread his legs apart to fit in it. We are hoping to be able to turn him around soon.

Seat Type: Rear-facing

Review: Love the compact size and bright color.  The only annoying thing is the crotch buckle.  You need to line up both sides and insert them simultaneously into the clip.  As long as your kid is perfectly still and your hands are both free and not sweaty, it works great.  BUT the reality is that one of those obstacles always seems to be present when you are trying to wrestle your kid into the car making it just a little harder than it should be.  So far we have used this only rear facing for infant and toddler and taken it on an extended road and plane trip and have been happy with it.

Special Features: Car seat and suitcase sold separately
Review:
This is a fantastic idea, but just isn't easy enough to take on/off quickly and with ease.

I bought this before traveling alone with my toddler, hoping it would provide a solution for easy travel. The reviews seemed really positive and encouraging. My husband and I spent 30 minutes just trying to get our Graco Nautilus carseat securely fastened to our carry-on. Once it was on, I struggled and struggled to take the strap off. We quickly realized this wasn't going to work. I couldn't imagine having to take this on and off in an airport while also holding on to 1-year-old toddler.

In addition, I wouldn't trust the handle on my suitcase to support the weight of a 25 lb. child plus the carseat. It was acting like it was ready to bend or break with just the carseat alone.

I may be more inclined to use this if there is another traveler with me to help, but would definitely not recommend for flying solo with a small child. In the end, we returned it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Graco Nautilus carseat
Weight Range of Child: 25 lb. child, 1-year-old toddler

Review: I really love this infant seat. The product is exactly as described and the sure latch works great. No instructions needed, I just looked at the few words on the box and the latch itself indicates the right way to attach to the car, clicked, clicked and then pushed forward-took less than 2 minutes. The fabric and colors look great and do not seem too blue or too purple and works well for both genders. I will be using the seat for our son. The seat does seem a little heavier then my previous experience with anohter infant car seat I used for my daughter 5 years ago but I was able to fit it into my cross country with putting the passenger seat further forward. I also did this with the adjustable base in the reclined position, especially for a newborn. The straps are very easy to adjust and the canapy provides for full coverage. I love this car seat and would absolutely recommend it for moms. The only thing I would be concerned about is the size length for smaller vehicles, although I was able to make it work for my wagon.

This seat works great and is easy to install and remove. However I have two major complaints:

1) It rattles a LOT. If your kiddo is not in it, there is a metallic rattle that will drive you nuts. I broke it down to the styrofoam and still cannot figure out how to stop the rattle. Very frustrating. I think it is the metal frame piece vibrating against something underneath the bottom of the seat. I am going to try to figure out how to take the recline base off to see if I can fix it. Frustrating.

2) The cup holders are worthless. Absolute trash. The first corner you turn the sippy cup will flip right out of it into the seat or worse into the crevice between the seat and the door. My 4 yr old has even learned to just not use them and hold the sippy in her lap.

Review:
I am very happy with the seat so far. It's unused as baby is not yet here. It is very intuitive and easy to set up. It's very different from the cheaper Graco seats I often see in stores. High quality with good head protection! It comes in/out of the base easily. It's for a 6th baby so we've used almost every infant carseat out there! And none of them did we really love, except the Britax Chaperone that just expired. But I wanted the 40 lb. weight limit and the 35" height limit. My kids are tall and hit that height before age 2, but this seat will get us close to 2. Then we'll use a rear-facing convertible until 3 or 4.

It's important I have the option to simply lift carseat out of car if my older baby is sleeping and I don't want to wake him! I don't plan to always remove it from the car as he gets heavier, but the OPTION is key. We bought the infant stroller carrier by Graco that this clicks into, as well.

Review:
1st off I ordered in January 2015 and got a unit made in Sept 2014. It's updated for proper lap belt seating and it costs less than the "new version".

I don't give 5 stars for anything not manufactured in the USA or made with anything toxic - so a 4 star rating means the product is solid but core manufacturing methods are at issue with my preferences.

This seat is comfortable for my 5 year old boy. He enjoys it, it is reclined and his head does not nod forward when he's asleep, and I'm at ease knowing all risk has been seriously mitigated in the event of an accident. For him and for passengers next to him.

The securing method is honestly great. Once you understand it, you can take it out of one car and place in another in 4 very realistic minutes, maybe less.

I bought this for my new 2015 vehicle and it's going to jack up the seat and the seat belt but I do not care. Seriously. My new vehicle means nothing to me if it's not as safe as possible for my son.

The roads are crowded with more and more people every day. More people choose to text, email, and take selfies while driving because they haven't lost someone dear to them over distracted driving. These people make my blood boil. The selfishness is absolutely mind blowing for me - I could never understand the self absorbed reasoning behind this junk.

So if you think accidents don't happen and little kids/babies don't get violently injured or killed due to dumb ignorant and vain worthless humans, go talk to a first responder about what they witness - then make a choice on how safe you want your child.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: 5 year old
Installation Type: lap belt, seat belt
Harness Type: securing method

Review: this is the BEST car seat ever!!!! my son is 2.5 and about 40lbs, he is tall and big, looks 3 and needed more space in his other car seat. this one goes all the way to 70 lbs, YAY!!! there is plenty of room for him now and it reclines too, also works as a rear facing for newborns/babies. I have used a peg perego, maxi cosi priori and a graco, this is the very BEST hands down. if you are looking for a compact carseat, this is NOT it. i can still fit it next to my older daughters high back booster and have a seat for someone medium sized to sit on the bench seat. this is in a Lexus GX470 SUV, not sure if you would be able to do that in a smaller SUV. Wish it came with a cupholder.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Weight Range of Child: 40lbs, goes all the way to 70 lbs

Review:
Initially we bought a more expensive car seat because as a first time mom you tend to think that the more expensive something is, the better it is. Sigh. I was wrong. The (ridiculously) expensive car seat we initially bought is way more awkward of a fit compared to this one. We only got this one as an extra, but now it's our favorite! I vastly prefer the Graco. Did I mention the Graco Extend2Fit was HALF the price?!

As far as safety goes.. I would imagine they are all subjected to the same tests and standards so.. while we haven't experienced a crash (knock on wood & cross everything that we never do) I would imagine safety wise they are the same. In hindsight, I should have just gotten two of these and left the bigger price tag car seat out of the equation. Oh well, you live & learn.

We had to return this car seat, and we got the SnugRide 30, which does come with the harness adjuster in the front.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: harness adjustment was on the back; front harness adjuster

Review:
We bought this one for our second vehicle; the one the kiddo will be in less. Our main vehicle has the Graco 4Ever 4-in-1, which I love.

This Safety 1st Car Seat is pretty comfortable for the tiny. I only have two minor issues.
* One - the click-in straps for the rear-facing direction don't get tight enough in my Dodge Caliber. Your vehicle may not have this issue. Instead, I have to run the seatbelt through the bottom (where it's designed to go) and click the seatbelt into its normal receptor. Then I have to pull the seat belt out all the way until it starts ratcheting, then get it as tight as I can. The car seat is designed for this contingency.
*Two - the child's shoulder strap webbing regularly get twisted in their buckle when I'm trying to get it pulled out from underneath her when she sits down. That design could be a bit better. I rarely have that issue with the Graco seat.

I regularly have to pull the car seat out of the Dodge for the nanny, and reinstall it later. It's not difficult, just takes a few minutes.

Besides that, it seems safe and comfortable. The only two things that truly matter.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear-facing
Installation Type: seatbelt
Harness Type: shoulder strap

Review: First let me say I love this car seat. I've been using it for almost 3 years now. Best money ever spent. We travel a lot. We switch it to numerous families vehicles while visiting. The ease of use allows almost anyone to install it. It's dummy proof. My 8 year old can even install it. :) It's comfy, it's washable, and we have the black version which hide all stains! I've bought many car seats over the years. This is my offical go to baby shower gift. My friends love it! It doesn't even compare to latch car seats. I only wish they shipped it in another box and NOT the original box it comes in. My last box was damaged beyond belief but I didn't have time to order again before the baby shower. I was embarrassed at the price point and box shape.

Review:
I love this car seat! We're getting into a point where the infant seat is too small for our toddler. I originally ordered another Graco *forward* facing car seat (Tranzitions 3-in-1), but wanted to keep him rear facing for as long as possible. This works well as a rear-facing seat with the recline feature allowing room for his legs to stretch out and up a bit. I do notice some squeaking/rubbing on the back of the front driver's/passenger seats, but I'm 6'2", so my seat is all the way back and probably isn't an issue for *most* drivers. I added a car-seat seat protector so his shoes/feet won't mark up the seat back, and there aren't any issues with this on the seat protector.

It's really quick and easy to install with the seatbelt, but I've so far struggled to get the LATCH anchors free from the base. When I take it out of my car and install it in my girlfriend's car again, I'll spend some more time figuring that out and will update if there were any issues.

Graco is a trusted child safety brand, so I'm trusting the brand that it's safe and hope that I never need to test it first hand.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear-facing
Weight Range of Child: toddler
Installation Type: seatbelt, LATCH anchors
Harness Type: 
Material:

Review: I bought this car seat based upon the written reviews here. Well, after having baby and working with this super-wide car seat, you quickly realize your walking is limited to about 10 steps. Now my baby is four days short of 5 months old and over 20 lbs. (! I know! Huge!) and together, this car seat and baby are approaching 40 lbs! I can barely lift it into my car, and cannot maneuver it at all. I am now moving him out of it and straight into a Britax Marathon and giving up on the "systems." Also, I did move the straps on the Graco to the middle level and they are getting tight on junior, and I moved them to the top level and there is NO SLACK whatsoever - I almost cannot buckle in a 5-month old baby.

The only complaint I have is that once installed (right now we are rear facing still), the seat does not recline enough to my liking. This will become less of an issue as my son gets older, but for a newborn I think you would need more of a recline. Other than that minor issue, this seat is great so far!

Review: I checked out the Sit N Stroll and the Go Go Kidz TravelMate before deciding to try the Traveling Toddler.  The Sit N Stroll seemed really great, switched easily from car seat to stroller and would have been one less thing to travel with, but the back recline does not adjust and it was too far back for my 2 year old to use as a stroller all day.  I really liked the Traveling Toddler.  It works great.  It's a little annoying that you have to take it apart to go through security etc but it's easy enough to put back together.  I used the largest carry-on I was allowed and it worked beautifully.  My daughter loves her carseat (Britax Marathon) and was loving sitting in and being pushed around.  (Make sure your carry-on pull locks upright or you can't push it in front of you, you'll have to pull it and I found it easier to push.)  I saw someone else with the Go Go thing and it looks great but for nearly triple the price, I got this one since I don't fly often.  A must-have if you need the car seat on the plane or your destination b/c you can also check the car seat and use this strap before/after in the airport instead of carrying it.

Review: I have never written a review but I was in LOVE with this product as soon as I took it out of the box!!! We are traveling out of the country for the first time and will be taking my son's car seat with us through the airports. We were looking for something sturdy and easy to pull the big car seat around. We had purchased another product similar to this and it was AWFUL!!!! It was so flimsy and the seat wouldn't hook securely to it. With this Britax travel cart, the car seat attaches to it using the LATCH tethers. It's such a tight fit that I have no worries about it falling off or tipping. It'd even be sturdy enough to roll my toddler around in it through the airport if we weren't also traveling with his stroller. Our travel car seat is a Graco Contender 65 (which proves that it doesn't have to be a Britax model to work). I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND this to anyone who needs a travel cart for your car seat. It is very well made, rolls smoothly, and folds up to place in an overhead bin. You will not be disappointed!

Review:
I just bought this car seat today and our son spent 8 hours in it throughout the day, and love is not a strong enough word. Our son was in a Chicco KeyFit30 as an infant and then an Evenflo Symphony until he was 3 1/2, at which point we bought him the Evenflo Securekid. The Securekid fit our needs at the time of being much more narrow than the Symphony and allowing an adult to sit in between two car seats in the back seat, however, it had one huge down side for our family. The moment that our son fell asleep his head would drop dramatically to the side. He was only able to sleep for 20-30 minutes and would wake up screaming.

We had done extensive research and decided to spend the money and replace the SecureKid with the Nautilus today before traveling for a wedding. It was worth every penny. Our son is now 5, 52 lbs and 46" and he loves his new car seat. He took an hour and a half nap in his car seat today, which hasn't happened in almost 2 years. He then slept in his Nautilus for 3 hours while we traveled home after his bedtime. It is comfortable. Safe. and the front recline allows a bigger child to sleep comfortably when just tuckered out or traveling after their bed time.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Nautilus
Weight Range of Child: 52 lbs
Installation Type: 
Harness Type: 
Material:

This is NOT one size fits all and, sadly, not a safe alternative to the traditional booster. Even when using for travel only, I did not feel comfortable at all using it, and it did not remain completely inflated no matter how hard I tried.

Review: This car seat, especially considering the price, is a very good car seat.  I haven't had much difficulty with the harness, and my nine year old son can buckle and un-buckle it with minimal difficulty (he did pinch a finger the first time he tried it).  Other than that, I love that I can adjust the strap height with a button in the back, and not have to re-thread the belts every time the baby grows.  I also really like how comfortable it is to detach the seat from the base.  I'm not sure how else to word it, I just really like where my hands go and how easy it is to pull the handle to unlatch the seat/carrier as I'm taking it out of the car.

Review:
Pros: Grippy triangle handle.

Cons: Like another reviewer said, whenever you need to raise or lower the handle, the buttons on the sides are darn near impossible to push in. I can't get them with my thumbs or from any sort of angle--the only way for me to apply enough force is to use my palms and really lean in on the darn things. As a new mom with already-sore wrists from picking up a new baby, this terrible design just makes my wrists and hands hurt even more. The whole seat feels like a very cheap design that's shoddily assembled. I HATE this car seat and can't wait to get rid of it.

Seat Type: Right Handle
Installation Type: Clicktight

Review:
I like this seat, and my son thinks its a great big kid seat. Its got a lot of potential to stay with him til he doesn't require a carseat at all. He's 4, 39" and 34lbs so he's got a ways to go. I'm not loving this seat as much as I thought I would, I just don't feel like the 5pt harness has him secure. If I pull the straps so they're snug like I'm used to with a convertible seat, they're pinching his shoulders. If I don't I feel like he's got too much room to move and isn't in 'right'. I've had him checked by a car seat tech, and they assured me he's in and good even without the straps being 'fighter pilot tight'. Other than that, its a really great seat. It goes in and out easily (not that we move it much) but the LATCH works as well and easily as a seat belt with the 5 pt harness (we're not ready for the belt alone!!). My son loves the 'cubbies' and cup holder, he thinks he's pretty cool stuff.
If I were able to be more confident about his security with the loose appearance of the straps, this would be a 100% hit. As it is, its about 85%. That said, even knowing what I know, I'd recommend it and buy it again.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: 5pt harness
Installation Type: LATCH, seat belt

Review: This is the 2nd Extend2Fit I’ve purchased for my son, and the only car seat I will ever purchase ever again! I didn’t necessarily need a new car seat, but we’ve had our original one for 2 years now so I felt it was time to order a new one. The first one we had, had a light grey color and it stained easily so instead of wanting to risk damaging it/making it less effective while cleaning it, I just bought a new one. Figured it was best to do that anyways. I’ve bought both of them on amazon prime days to save money, and I don’t regret spending a single penny. I would buy this again even if not on sale! I trust these to keep my son safe (still rear-facing at 3 years old), and he doesn’t seem to complain about the comfort level. Coming from a crazy car-seat mom, I recommend these for parents who are interested in rear-facing their child for the max amount of time. I love that they can remain rear-facing at such a higher weight and that this seat also comes with a pull out foot rest to make it even more comfortable! It’s easy to install, and especially easy to adjust the straps’ length! 10/10 would recommend for safety, comfort, appearance, weight and size. I do drive an SUV so I have the extra room in my backseat (it is a tiny bit bulky) but I know it would’ve fit in my Toyota Camry I had pre-child just fine!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear-facing
Weight Range of Child: higher weight
Installation Type: easy to install
Harness Type: adjust the straps' length

Review: So cool! Easy install and adjustment. Even the packaging was easy to unpack (relative to my old infant car seat). I thought the base/seat install was going to be more complex because of the swivel, but it wasn’t. It was actually easier since you’re not reaching around the whole seat for the initial attachment!  Both seat into base and the swivel into place offer clear click-ins that made me feel extremely secure that my little girl is securely locked in. Also my old car seat needed a re-thread to adjust the straps. That pull-up head positioning feature is really easy! My daughter is rear facing, so really excited that I’ll just be able to spin this around when she’s ready to face forward.

Review: The best, affordable booster. The safety features to this seat are amazing. So many boosters don't latch into car anchors like this one, and the release/tighten mechanism on the side is super easy. I like my son being able to use the regular car seat-belt, but with his old booster it never really seemed as safe as it should be. The middle clip that loops onto the lap belt is the perfect secure fit. This booster is also so comfortable and cushy. My little dude was so excited to sit in it! Also, it looks great in my Murano!

Review: I really like this seat and my 2 1/2 year old says its really comfortable.  Its nice that we will be able to use this seat through booster and hopefully it is the last one we have to buy!  I read some of the other reviews about having issues feeding the crotch strap buckle through the hole to move it to a different position.  I had some difficulty at first, but called Graco's 800 number and received help promptly!  The secret to moving it is not in the manual but the very nice rep said they will be adding it.  *****HERE'S THE SECRET: Slide the clip flat against the bottom of the seat towards the back of the seat until the edge is even with the hole.  Then tuck the corner of the clip through the hole and feed it through the other side.  Don't put any slack in the strap or it will bunch and won't go through*****  I might not have that word for word but call Graco and they can certainly talk you through it.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: difficulty feeding the crotch strap buckle through the hole to move it to a different position; secret to moving the clip and strap

My kids like them, they look nice, and they can sit next to a rear-facing Graco baby seat without feeling crammed. The only thing I’d change about them is switching out the strap covers since they’re pretty bulky.

Seat Type: Rear-facing

Review: I read countless reviews on this seat and the Chicco Nextfit trying to decide which to purchase. I ended up buying both to test them out at home. Every time I put my 6 month old in the Britax, he cried. Maybe a coincidence, but odd. He also looked uncomfortable even in the most reclined setting. I also didn't like the shock absorber pads. They were awkward, stiff and uncomfortable looking. With the strap pads and the shock absorber pads on the straps at the same time, it made it impossible to get a correct fit on my baby--the chest clip was on his belly when fully tightened. I assume they expect you to remove the strap pads in this scenario because the shock absorbers can not be removed (from what I could tell). Overall, the Britax seemed to be a better fit for an older baby or toddler, not for my (very tall) 6 month old. I ended up keeping the Nextfit. He never cried when I put him in it, and still doesn't. A huge improvement from his Britax Bsafe car seat which was so narrow he always cried in it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Weight Range of Child: 6 month old
Harness Type: strap pads, shock absorber pads, chest clip

Review: I have had this carseat for five years now and have used it for two children.  And it's ok.  My children are still alive after driving all over the country  in it, so I like that.  But it is HUGE!  I have a Honda Odyssey and have this seat and a high back booster on the back row.  A normal sized adult cannot sit between them and only most of the time can I fit a third carseat.  Really it's the useless armrests that do it in.  Neither one of my children have ever used them--their little arms aren't long enough to reach them.  And the cupholder.  It's just stuck to the side of the seat and is pretty flimsy and takes up even more room.  It doesn't hold cups--they just flop out and makes it impossible to have a third person on my back row so we just took the seat out, end of story.  It's ok.  Like I said, I've used it continuously for five years and haven't felt the need to replace it, but I'm now looking for a second convertable seat for baby #3 and will not be purchasing another one of these.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Weight Range of Child: five years, two children, baby #3

Review: We bought this to enable us to transfer our 1 1/2 old out of the infant carrier seat and keep her rear facing. We have been using it since July and have very few complaints. It is so easy to adjust the shoulder harness height, it just slides up and down. On the con side, be prepared to adjust it often it seems that the straps often slide down after you remove your child. We love the cranks on the side for adjusting the tightness of the lap belt, very easy to use. Be aware that, unlike many car seats, this seat tightens from the lap so you need to tighten it BEFORE you fasten the chest harness. (I took the seat for a car seat installation check and even the technician had to be reminded of this).  I can't speak for our daughter but she appears comfy in it. She just turned 2 and is still happily rear facing. Installation was as easy as any other seat. My only wish is that there was an actual level on the side of the seat like graco seats have instead of a sticker saying "this line must be level with the ground" ugh! So hard to decide by eyeballing it.

Special Features: Car seat and suitcase sold separately
Review: The traveling toddler car seat accessory is a simple but genius idea!  After dragging my car seat through several airports while pushing my toddler in the stroller and rolling my suitcase at the same time, I was desperate for a better alternative.  I have seen other similar products that are more like at trolly and cost over $75.  $75 more than I wanted to pay.  When I saw this I was intrigued and loved the price.  Several comments complained about the price for such a simple device, but I had neither the time or inclination to fashion my own.  And for less than $20 I figured it would be worth a try.  It worked perfectly!  I did not put my toddler in the seat only because I didn't need to for this trip.  But she walked beside me while I only had to pull ONE thing instead of 2 plus carry the car seat on my back!  This was a huge lifesaver & I would recommend it to anyone.
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Review:
Britax instructions and customer service is AWFUL! Let me say this--I really like this car seat.
PROS:
- super-easy to install with seatbelt
- the click feature when tightening the straps is really helpful (clicks when straps are appropriately tight around baby)
- decent safety rating last time I checked

CONS:
- Britax communication is horrendous--from their "instructions" to their customer service reps
- the clicktight knob that opens the seat (to remove the car seat) won't turn unless you push down on the seat part...but of course, that's not written anywhere letting you know
- have to buy cupholder separately (after spending $300-400 on the car seat?!?!?!?!)
- the cupholder SUCK, SUCK, SUCKS (very difficult to install and eventually broke trying to re-install it)
- The tether and anchor strap compartments constantly pop open
- if you try to take this on an airplane, it's very heavy. But it doesn't work with Britax's wheeled car seat cart made for that exact purpose.

If you ever have to get in touch with Britax, brace yourself. When I called, I got an incredibly unhelpful, unfriendly customer rep named Brenda, who basically informed me that I've been using it improperly ever since we purchased it! I was calling to ask Britax to explain the bubble diagram on the sides of the seat because, ya know, kinda important to have it installed properly. I found their description of their recline positions to be somewhat confusing. The manual says lighter blue is infant, darker blue is toddler. In another place, it describes the blue for "larger children with head and neck control." In the third place, it says it's important that the seat be reclined to maintain proper head and neck control with "smaller infants." Then a new guideline popped up when their oh-so-friendly phone rep Brenda tells me the bubble should be in the light blue section if the child is under 2 years. I asked sweetheart Brenda if that was written anywhere and she said no. I told her that's a pretty crucial piece of information to not have written anywhere (using my best polite words as opposed WTF ARE YOU GUYS THINKING?!?!) and asked her to pass that along as customer input. She said she would but it seemed that she couldn't care less. Awesome. Since there are NO WORDS on the recline diagram sticker ON the actual car seat describing infant/toddler/age/weight limits, I assumed from the pictures in the bubble area that a younger baby should be reclined further back, but since the standing baby picture is in the darker blue rear-facing and forward-facing, I thought okay, maybe once the baby is 1 year or 20 lbs or maybe standing, you can have it up higher in the dark blue? Apparently, wrong! WTF, Britax?! This is SO important, how could you not have that in writing--like, BOLD writing, too?? It's mind-boggling.

Then I asked lovely Brenda about the cup holder (that I'm sure we all love having to buy separately with such an expensive seat). I ordered it on amazon, but again, their "instructions" have no words, save a few "cautions." Trying to explain the difficulty verbally without being able to show Britax/Brenda was nearly impossible. You can see from the pictures that the opening on the cupholder clip where you slide the holder down onto the car seat appears to be about half as long as it needs to be, as I see it. She kept telling me to just push/shove it down through the crack/gap where the seatbelt would go, and it would "click" in. It never did, and when I push it down, it pulls the gray plastic section of the car seat away, bending it. That seems like a terrible design if that's how it's supposed to attach, or terrible instructions if it's not. I finally got it clicked in, just to find that when I went to close my car door, it hit the cup holder and wouldn't close. This doesn't happen with car seats w/ built-in cup holders (as this seat should absolutely have for the price). So I had to detach it and struggle all over again to put it on the other side of car seat. The rubber piece on the cup holder would hold cups/bottles so tightly that I finally had to take it off so my kiddo could actually get her cup out. Of course, to do this, you have to take the cup holder off again. There isn't a cup/liner within the cupholder that's easily removable, like if drinks spill or the holder gets dirty, so if you ever want to clean it, you have to remove it again. Then struggle to put it back on. It's SUCH a pain in the #*@, I can't truly convey it. I just tried putting it back on yesterday, and after several minutes trying to remember how I'd done it, which I thought was just really jamming it down, as Brenda instructed, it broke. I'm going to call Britax about replacing it... and hope to get someone who's not Brenda.

Another little tidbit they don't tell you is when you push down the cover and it "clicks," securing the seat, when you want to open it, you can't just turn the dial--I wasted a lot of sweat and cussing struggling with that until I realized you need to push down on the cover, then the dial turns pretty easily. I've read other users who've found the same thing. If this is just how it works, why doesn't Britax TELL US THAT?? Seriously, this company needs a friggin' seminar on COMMUNICATION!

Also, as I mentioned above, if you try to take this on an airplane, it's very heavy. You'll want to buy the Britax wheeled cart to go with it... except wait, don't. Because even though that cart is made BY BRITAX, FOR THEIR SEATS, these Clicktights don't have the normal, newer anchor strap connections, so you cannot tighten it onto the cart, meaning not only can your kid not sit in it as you wheel it through the airport, but the seat itself slides off at every turn because it can't be tightened on. My husband and I spent so much time in the airport parking lot trying to figure out how the hell to attach the car seat to the cart that we ended up missing the cutoff for our flight by four minutes. It was a nightmare.

This is the most CAPS-filled review I've ever written. SO ANNOYED with Britax right now. SO annoyed.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing
Installation Type: seatbelt, Clicktight
Harness Type: straps

Review:
I take car seat safety VERY seriously so I really did my research when it came to making this purchase. My son is only 6 months but weighs 24lb and is 30" so we had to get him out of his infant seat earlier than we hoped. We were looking for something that hopefully wouldn't need replaced again that could transition from rear to front facing after a few years. We also didn't want to buy the cheapest seat out there, but didn't want to be duped into buying a $400 car seat either. This seat is the perfect middle ground.
Here's what I really LOVED:
Installation was a breeze
Seperate latch system for rear and forward facing
Comfy inserts for bum and neck support
No assembly required- just pop the two bottom pieces out for rear install and you're ready to go
Not too bulky
Bulky enough to seem very safe
Fits well in our midsize car (2012 Hyundai Sonata)
5 point harness has crotch buckles that insert separately (if you've ever had the ones that need placed together then inserted you know what a blessing that is)
My son LOVES it. No more fussing about

If you're on the fence about buying this seat- go for it! You won't regret it!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear to front facing
Weight Range of Child: 24lb
Installation Type: Latch
Harness Type: 5 point harness

Review:
I saw the designer give a presentation for this seat at a Child Passenger Safety Conference and decided to give it a try. I bought one as a test seat for our 2 children who still need seatbelt adjustment. Our intention was to buy another if it worked for both kids as we have a smaller back seat and the space saving design was a huge bonus for us and their older brother who has been cramped by several booster seat trials. We have 2 very different sized children: a wirey boy, age 10, 4'4", 65 lbs; and a tough as bricks girl, age 6, 3'4”, 70 lbs
What we determined:
This is a great seat for my small framed 10 year old. He loves that he is not in a little kid booster seat and I love that he is being protected. He also loves that he has more padding in the seat than his previous booster seat. Long rides were always a struggle as he begged to stop frequently to get a break from his previous seat.
However, our 6 year old, who is built differently, weighing more and with a wider hips, hated this seat. She complained that the plastic, adjustable sides pinched her and she really struggled with getting the seatbelt threaded correctly.
Overall, we are pleased with the purchase and will continue to use the Mifold for our son as long as we can.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: booster seat
Weight Range of Child: 65 lbs, 70 lbs
Material: plastic, padding

Review:
I can't believe that I almost bought that $80 contraption from One Step Ahead. This was awesome. After reading the bad review about the woman who had the horrible experience, I was nervous. I was traveling alone with my 10-month old for the first time and had the jitters. I had to practice at home first and think the whole scenario through; Going through security was my biggest fear. Turns out, it wasn't bad at all, and mind you, I was at ATL, the busiest airport in the world.

Key points:

-I know they tell you to not let your child stay in the seat when you detach the strap...(in a whisper voice) they're just covering themselves. DO NOT remove your child unless there is someone to hold them. Mine would have crawled away immediately. All you have to do is keep one hand on the seat just in case it tips(mine didn't budge, but just in case) while you unhook the strap.

-Once I had it tightened to my liking, it took one hand to unhook the top and one side. Then I just tucked the whole thing, with one side still hooked(there are 3 rings) into my carseat.

-In a nutshell, security went like this: Unhooked TT from carseat(4 seconds), took liquids out of carry-on(2 seconds) Unbuckled backpack diaper bag off me (2 seconds). Then I took my son out of his seat and with one hand, was able to lift all of my items that were lined up next to each other(purse, diaper bag, liquids bag, carry-on bag, and carseat) onto the conveyor belt and in the bins in like 10 seconds. I even took my out my baby food, while bouncing my little guy in my arm. Of course it was more of an ordeal than if it was just me, but hey, I had baby. People and security understood and gave me consideration...well actually, I demanded it, I'll never see them again. I didn't allow myself to get flustered and it went fine.

-After I walked through, I just did everything in reverse. Took my items off the belt, strapped my little guy in, hooked my carry-on to the seat, and went on my merry way.

-It was even easier coming back because I felt seasoned.

So in conclusion(LOL)it took a little planning in my head before hand, but worked great!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: Strap, Hook

Review: So I have been wanting this car seat for a few weeks now and finally I purchased it during prime day! I love this car seat! My l.o is 2 weeks from being 1 years old weighs 29ish pounds and 30ish something inches. He was due for an upgrade from the infant seat. As you can see before the Graco SnugRide fit perfect in the center. But the Graco Extend2Fit did not, well it would if the seats were scooted all the way up. The car I have is a 2010 Kia Soul! I found no other reviews about it fitting or not so I had to find out. It fits on the outside seat with the passenger seat scooted forward some. Luckily my husband and I have been looking at bigger vehicles, because I will not be able to use  the extend feature in my current vehicle! And that was the sole purpose of buying it to keep him facing rear longer! I was able to get it to recline to the 2nd notch! No messing with adjusting straps, they move up with the height adjustment! The crotch strap can be accessed by reclining seat on the last position and unhooking it through the hole under the seat. Pretty easy after I read the manual! That’s all I looked at it for. The material is padded very well. The cup holders were hard to snap in. Bottles we use are Playtex VentAire and there is still plenty of side room for a little bigger bottle or cup. I would not recommend this if you drive a 2010 Kia Soul! And the Solar color is bright orange! I love it

Review:
My only complaint about the seat is the crotch buckle is way too short for a toddler! It is so uncomfortable for my child and it is a huge pain getting her in or out. Britax will not be coming out with a longer buckle either.
The pros: the clicktight is awesome. So easy - especially when used with the seatbelt as it is designed for. The no rethread harness is great. It has higher rear facing limits also. The fabric is nice and padding great. I like that the padding is in sections so if needed I can pull one section and wash it without having to wrestle with the seat to get the cover on or off.
Overall I don't feel I will get as much use out of the seat as I would have with a longer crotch buckle and probably wouldn't purchase it again because of that.

Review: You will not find an easier car seat to install and it doesn't move at all once it's in. It literally takes less then a minute to install and there is nothing to it. We have several Britax car seats and this one is the best one so far. I tried to install one of the other ones the other day and this car seat makes you spoiled with how simple it is to install. The cup holders are great and it's super comfy. My only complaint is that it is hard to tighten the belt once they are in it. In the other ones, you can tighten them in much easier and make sure that they are extra snug. You really have to pull hard to get it to tighten. Overall I am extremely happy with this seat and plan to get a second one for my husband's vehicle. You will not be disappointed with this seat plus you cannot beat the safety features on it. That is the main reason we only buy Britax. We bought it for our two year old son (our one year old got the two Britax car seats he was using). They are both in the 100th percentile for height so it's nice finding a car seat that is so spacious and he won't outgrow. Don't hesitate to buy it. It's slightly more expensive than others out there and bigger but it's comforting to know that they are in the safest car seat on the market if something happens and your kid will love it.

Review:
This car seat is far superior to any car seat we have owned and is worth every penny. In fact, I would say it is a bargain for its quality. With 4 kids, we have owned 2 infant seats, 2 convertible, and 4 boosters, all from manufacturers. This Britax Roundabout is, by far, the most sturdy and comfortable. Here are the characteristics that set it apart from the others:

1. Sturdy / immoveable: We use the LATCH system and once it is in place, it does not move. No jiggling and wiggling.

2. Comfort: The engineers at Britax really THOUGHT about the comfort of the child and include such things as extra padding in the back, shoulder pads, and a pad for the buckle between the legs, so that his legs don't get pinched or rubbed. All of these features are added without compromising safety. The material is soft, not scratchy.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: convertible
Installation Type: LATCH
Material: soft, not scratchy, extra padding, shoulder pads, pad for the buckle

Review: I read the reviews and bought this car seat and I love it. It looks huge but it fits in my CRV without needing to adjust my passenger seat from the old car seat. I love the it rotates and my son fits comfortably for the most part. The only reason why I didn't do 5 stars is because of the buckle. I wish it came out farther and that the buckles to snap in weren't as wide. I wish there was some cushion on the seatbelt buckle so they don't hurt him. The ends dig into my son's thighs a little and he doesn't like the initial getting in and buckled up. He's completely content once we get moving though.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: buckle, buckles, seatbelt buckle
Material: cushion

Review: Very secure and confortable seat. Besides the typical holes to be used with the car belt this convertible seat has 2 extra sort of belts at the rear side to attach it to the car seat. These extra belts have small hooks at the end.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible
Installation Type: car belt, extra belts at the rear side with small hooks

Special Features: Removable Tray, Safety Harness, Folds for Easy Transport and Storage
Review: This thing is perfect for any family who wants to include their child at the table while in a restaurant rather than put their child at the edge of the table and in the aisle. This has different heights and the buckles are easy to do. The only thing I would say that I wish it did better with was folding back up when finished. You need both hands and something else to push the back of the seat flat. But once it's folded it is flat and tucks away nicely in the car. Takes up hardly any room.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: Clicktight

Review: There's not much to these seats, really was just looking for one at a good price and this did the trick. Only thing I could see as an improvement would be a cup holder but hard to beat it for the price.
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Review: I had read reviews saying that there is no possible way this car seat would fit a 65lb child but due to its great safety ratings, I ignored and bought anyways. Well my son is now almost 40lbs and hardly fits with a light jacket on. It's a great car seat, but do not expect to use it until 65lbs.
Attribute_Related_Content: Weight Range of Child: 65lb child, 40lbs, until 65lbs

Review: The decription of this product is different on Amazon and Mifold website than the seat itself. The seat says 33 to 80 pounds and 36 inches to 59 inches tall and the website says 40 to 100 pounds and 40 inches to 59 inches tall. This is totally misleading, I will be using my normal booster seats for traveling instead of these. I can't take the risk of my children's safety with these seats.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Booster seats
Weight Range of Child: 33 to 80 pounds, 40 to 100 pounds

Review: Worth every penny. Light. Durable. High quality. Snaps into the Vista easily. Lifts out both the stroller and car seat base at the push of a button. Levels in seconds and you don’t have to readjust the chest straps every time.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: Snaps into the Vista easily, Lifts out both the stroller and car seat base at the push of a button, Levels in seconds
Harness Type: you don’t have to readjust the chest straps every time

Review:
This is my first ever and only Amazon review. I’ve had this car seat now for 1.5ish years and cannot say enough good things:
1. My 2-year-old is the last of her friends still rear-facing. I thought the extend2fit platform was kinda a gimmick - but it gives my daughter lots of legroom, PLUS a platform to place her toys and loveys on trips, PLUS it makes it easier for me at 5 months pregnant to fit her in the car seat.
2. We’ve had a few spills and vomit situations and it’s a breeze to clean. I take off the fabric pieces, throw them in the wash, and hose down the base.
3. I have friends who say they don’t know how to install their car seat. This is a breeze to take in and out of my car when I need to.
4. It’s comfortable! We live in Texas and the car can get super hot in a parking lot. The fabric is always cool to the touch when we get back to the car - NOT like her chicco infant seat, which I had to cover with a towel when parked in the sun.
5. This is a common feature in most car seats, but a non-rethread harness is a MUST. I can adjust the car seat for any growth spurt without even taking her out of the car!
6. Can you beat the price? I laugh at anyone who buys a $200+ car seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, extend2fit platform
Weight Range of Child: 2-year-old
Installation Type: a breeze to take in and out
Harness Type: non-rethread harness
Material: fabric, cool to the touch, easy to clean

Special Features: Machine Washable Seat Pad, LATCH Compatible, Forward Facing Seat
Review: This seat is great! My almost 4 year old (super tall) daughter LOVES this seat. I ordered it to fly to grandma's with and have for our visit. My Daughter actually sat in her seat for a week on the couch because she was so excited for her new special seat. The color of the fabric is great and very nice feeling. For the airport I was able to use a big carabiner that I had to hook the handle of the seat to the stroller handle bar(big jogging stroller)--- GREAT way to get through the airport with a wild little and all the stuff. She has been in Chicco seats since she was born- KeyFit30, NextFit, Myfit and now this GoFit. 10/10!!!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: GoFit
Material: fabric

Special Features: Super Easy, Car Rental inflatable packable portable luggage travel
Review: We bought two of these in January 2018 to replace an older BubbleBum and another type of booster. Both of the new BubbleBums leak air and won't stay inflated for more than a day of use. Our last BubbleBum lasted all the way through it's expiration date so I'm very disappointed in the current quality control. I'm not sure if we got a defective batch (the two new ones were ordered separately but within a week of each other).
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Review: In order for the seat to be rear facing the front seat has to be all the way up making the adults in the car have no leg room. Also the angle it's at I can't imagine being comfortable for any toddler who is extended rear facing. The only thing I like about this car seat is the colors which I could have found for a WAAY better seat. So disappointed in this.
Attribute_Related_Content: Seat Type: Rear Facing

Review:
Easy on the eyes. The fabric shell comes loose regularly which is quite frustrating. The sun canopy is VERY difficult to manage and doesn't extend very far. The few spots of Velcro designed to hold the rear of the canopy in place don't actually hold it leaving floppy fabric which can cover baby's face if you try to pull the canopy too far forward.
Also, this model does NOT fit any graco products you might still have from previous children. This led to unexpected costs (totally my fault but I didn't realize this in time or I would have continued using our older infant seat.)

The car seat IS lightweight which is super helpful!!
Attribute_Related_Content: Material: The fabric shell comes loose regularly. The sun canopy is VERY difficult to manage and doesn't extend very far. The few spots of Velcro designed to hold the rear of the canopy in place don't actually hold it leaving floppy fabric. The car seat IS lightweight.

Review: I dislike how HARD it is to pull the straps tight. I ordered this car seat for my baby’s grandparents so they’d have one for their car & damn it’s hard for all of us to pull it tight enough to fit him correctly.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: hard to pull the straps tight

Review: I really like this car seat.  We have a 17 month old who out grew who infant car seat.  Our goal was to get something that didn't require us to buy another car seat before she could sit in the car by herself.  This does that.  Install is simple.  We use the BRICA Seat Guardian Car Seat Protector underneath it - which has saved my car already from the inevitable baby mess that happens from time to time.  We liked this so much we have purchased one for my car, my wife's car and also one from the grandparents who live a plane flight away (cheaper than paying check it on the airline).
Attribute_Related_Content:
**Seat Type:** Convertible  
**Weight Range of Child:** 17 month old (outgrew infant seat)

Review: We use this car seat when we travel - it's light weight and easy to carry with a toddler in one hand and a stroller in the other! Also, when taking a taxi or uber, this is awesome to be able to carry around with us for a day in the city.
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Review: The advocate is great! I have had the older version for 3 years and my daughter who is now 4 1/2 is still riding comfortably with lots of room and still has 5 or 6 inches of height left and will not reach the weight limit as she is 38 pounds now and 41 inches. I think the height limit is around 48 inches but is an average. If your child is longer torso then they will outgrow quicker and vice versa. This seat fit great in our old 2005 nissan pathfinder rear facing(didnt leave much room for the driver but i didnt have any issues at 5'5". We now have it in a 2013 armada forward facing and there are no space issues at all. My daughter was able to rear face to 4 years old but turned her forward about 3 1/2 when we got the new car. She was still ok and comfortable even though people often commented that she should be forward facing at her age. Research shows to those who don't know that rear facing as long as possible is the most safe. We should still be able to use this seat for another year or more which will bring my daughter to 5 or near 6. This may be on the older end for sure of using a 5 point harness seat but if shes comfy then im ok with the extra safety! Shes small and seems unsafe to me to get a booster for her when her very awesome 5 point harness seat still fits. My 15 month old gets to use this new version and i know the expensive cost is worth it because she will get many years use out of hers as well.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: 38 pounds
Harness Type: 5 point harness

Review:
I bought this carseat because it rear faces to 40 lbs while the scenera only rear faces to 35 lbs. My son is tall and weighs 32 lbs. In the Scenera he still has a couple of inches above his head, but he is coming close to the 35 lb limit. The highest strap slots are about 1/2 an inch above his shoulders.

In this seat, he has exactly one inch above his head and the strap slots are just below his shoulders.

I don't understand making the seat with the higher weight limit smaller than the one with the lower limit.

We returned the seat and will stick with the Scenera for my mom's car for as long as we can and then buy another Radian like we have for our car.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear faces
Weight Range of Child: 40 lbs, 35 lbs, 32 lbs

Review: Well giving this an honest review it’s a very sturdy unit but lacks in a couple areas.. the seat to me is not cushioned very well from the sides and bottom. Also there are a couple Velcro’s pieces to hold material but are lacking to do so big time. Also not sure if it’s just me but can’t seem to get the belt quite tight enough. Comparing this unit to a popular “racing” brand seat that we have, it has all to be desired. My wife picked this unit out and I agreed as the price was in our range but I guess with an all in one this is what we get.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Material: not cushioned very well from the sides and bottom; Velcro pieces to hold material but are lacking
Installation Type: can’t seem to get the belt quite tight enough

Review: I  have three adult children and the car seats we had for them were adequate and safe.  We also had two Britax car seats for my older grandchildren who are now 7 and 8 and 9 and 12.  Unfortunately my daughter in law discarded them saying they were no longer safe.  (Doubtful) This past April I paid $323.00 for a Britax Convertible car seat for my two new grandchildren,  and I do not like it.  We have two cars:  a Cadillac STS and a Subaru Crosstrek.  The installation of the new car seat in either car is problematic.  The biggest problem seems to revolve around the Click Tight.  For starters you need thumbs of steel to turn the lever when the seat is in the car.  In order to get the click tight to click into place you have to kneel in the car seat with your full weight which is not an easy task with so little head room and maneuver space.  It is also difficult to remove the seat so you have to kneel in the seat again to get the click tight to unclick.  This is truly a horrible device.  The leveling of the seat is also a problem.  You have to readjust it several times when you put the seat in the car which is difficult given the soft nature of the back seat.  My daughter called customer service this morning and the representative was not particularly helpful or interested in our problem.  She had my daughter bring the seat into the house and maneuver the click tight in the house while the seat was on the floor.  Well it works fine when it is on a floor but who needs a car seat that only works well in the living room.
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: The installation of the new car seat in either car is problematic. The biggest problem seems to revolve around the Click Tight. For starters you need thumbs of steel to turn the lever when the seat is in the car. In order to get the click tight to click into place you have to kneel in the car seat with your full weight which is not an easy task with so little head room and maneuver space. It is also difficult to remove the seat so you have to kneel in the seat again to get the click tight to unclick. This is truly a horrible device. The leveling of the seat is also a problem. You have to readjust it several times when you put the seat in the car which is difficult given the soft nature of the back seat.

Review: My 2 year old was in a serious car accident and this car seat totally did it’s job. Ive gone through about 4 car seats in last week trying to find one that was easy to put in the car but most importantly safe. I ordered two more!
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Review:
I like everything about it but it was rough figuring it out where the release was to buckle between legs. Hidden toggle to adjust it. Video didn't highlight that.
It's a good car seat and will last for the stages needed.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: Hidden toggle to adjust it, rough figuring out where the release was to buckle between legs

Review:
This car seat is great. So far, no accidents and I hope we never have to say "this saved my baby", but the shear size of the thing leads me to believe it would protect quite well. Unfortunately, that is it's biggest downside as well. I did however get it to install properly, rear facing in a Toyota Camry. While not a small car, it's not an SUV either.
The seat also has some "could be hidden better" sharp hard plastic underneath the adjustable head rest. It's not a likely spot for hands to go while in the seat, but it's easy enough to find when out of the seat. I don't think it will cut even an infant's skin, but if for any reason the head rest was adjusted while a hand was in there, I'm sure there would be screaming involved...
My only other concern is that the cup holder is not well secured to the seat, it just seems like it would be easy to break off or tip over, but who rates a car by its cup holders?

That's it for the negative, now for more positive. The head rest is easy to adjust and has plenty of positions to make this useful for a number of years. However, it is quite useful on a daily basis when dealing with jackets of varying thickness. One handed adjustment leads to a perfect fit each time.

The head rest itself is very soft and wraps around a very large portion of the head for safety and comfort.

The straps and buckles are pretty standard, but they work. Although, they could use strap cushions, we just added our own.

It's not the best seat out there, but it is a good compromise between the super cheap ones, and the super expensive ones.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear facing
Installation Type: install properly
Material: sharp hard plastic, soft

Review:
This car seat has met our needs very well. Our child became to big for his infant seat at 7 months so we needed a car seat that could still grow with him i.e. front and rear facing. He sustained a neck injury at birth so comfort was also a concern but we didn't have the money to spend on a Britax.

I love this seat because:

* Most everything on the car seat is straightforward and easy to use
* In rear facing there are 3 adjustable recline settings
* In forward facing 2 adjustable recline settings are available. We still use the most recline we can to help with sleeping in the car and all around comfort.
* 5 point harness fits snug and secure
* Harness buckles are not too tight and difficult to use like some cheaper car seat models we have tried.
* Though the built in pillow doesn't prevent his head from slouching to the side during sleep it offers a nice padded and safe wedge to hold his head up when a blanket roll is placed beneath it.
* He is very comfortable in the seat.
* The shoulder straps adjust as needed for the child's growth but also remain snug even though they are adjustable.
* Safe up to 50 Lb.

Improvements could be made on:
* The shoulder straps by the neck have no padding and can become abrasive the the baby's neck.
* Obviously a better instruction manual.
* The cup holder is floppy and kind of worthless.

He is old enough to be forward facing now and the seat provides a nice height for him to enjoy the outside world but also be snug within the car. We drive a Chevy Malibu. This seat is worth the extra $20 to $30 you might spend on a cheaper model.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: front and rear facing, forward facing
Weight Range of Child: Safe up to 50 Lb
Harness Type: 5 point harness, shoulder straps

Review: We bought 3 of these on Prime Days to swap out our bulkier carseats now that our son is appropriate for the safety recommendations.  We love them and feel henis safe.  They are extremely easy to assemble and install.  My son feels so grown up to be able to buckle himself while we just supervise the belt positioning.  Great product at a great price!

Review: So far so good! We love it our little guy hasn't adjusted yet but he will. This is so nice! And for the price it's great! The holes for the belt are a little small tear up our hands putting seat belt in but seriosuly that's my only complain this thing is awesome
Attribute_Related_Content:

Review: This chair is so easy to install and move around between the cars. I like how easy it is to reverse it too. The recline option is great (makes it easy for different seat widths in multiple cars) and the head rest is so easy to slide up and down. We are super satisfied with this purchase and would highly recommend it.

Review: Love this carseat, this is the second one we've gotten.  We needed a spare that wasn't too expensive, and thankfully I caught this one on sale!  We had a problem with an older carseat we had purchased, so we contacted Graco, they reimbursed us and we bought a new one!  Graco is the best!
Attribute_Related_Content: No

Review: My 3 month old hated his infant car seat, so we decided to try a convertible to see if it would help us stay sane on car rides. Needless to say, this carseat is now his "throne". We feel like this was the safest option for our little one, and upon arriving we thought is was the most well built car seat we'd ever seen. That being said, I do have two issues. One, the leg straps are incredibly tight. Two, it's pretty difficult to unbuckle the crotch buckle to get them out. It's taken some time to figure it out, and it's still difficult. Regardless, thanks Britax for making awesome and safe "thrones" for our babies!
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: leg straps are incredibly tight; difficult to unbuckle the crotch buckle

Review: We have an almost five year old purple Radian RXT and recently were rear-ended by an elderly gentleman when his foot slipped on the gas pedal and he accelerated quickly into the back of my Honda Odyssey. We were at a complete stop when the impact happened so we all snapped forward quite violently. I sustained whiplash and hyper-extension injuries to my neck and Trapezius muscles whereas my 5-year-old daughter in the Radian was not hurt at all. I attribute this to her Diono car seat considering the stark contrast between my injuries and her sustaining absolutely none. We will be replacing the car seat and will buy another Diono as we know first hand that they do their job.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Radian RXT
Weight Range of Child: 5-year-old
Material: purple

My almost 2 year old is 35' tall (long torso) and only has one more harness level before he outgrows it. I intend to keep him in a harness until at least age 5 so I will have to buy another car seat. It is great for smaller children, though.

Now that she has grown, it is time to move the straps up a bit and the entire seat needs to be taken out to adjust the straps. Poorly designed.
